How did other members react when you asked?

outcomes.response: No financial statements. They say they file them with the regional office. I called the regional office — they said the local chapter handles its own reporting. Everyone points somewhere else.
outcomes.feedback: Classic runaround but no concrete evidence of misuse.
outcomes.note: They said the local chapter handles its own reporting

outcomes.response: The fund is supposed to cover strike support, legal aid, and member education. But there hasn't been a training session in two years. No strike fund has been paid out. And Göransson just bought a summer cottage on Öland. On a shop floor salary.
outcomes.feedback: The chairman's new property versus frozen fund activities. Circumstantial but newsworthy.
outcomes.note: Göransson just bought a summer cottage on Öland

outcomes.response: I got a look at the bank statements. A friend at Handelsbanken. There are regular withdrawals — cash — by Göransson himself. Three, four thousand at a time. And the 'conference expenses' line? The last three conferences were at a resort hotel. Göransson went alone.
outcomes.feedback: Bank records showing cash withdrawals plus fake conference expenses. Documentary proof.
outcomes.note: By Göransson himself

friendly.q1_note: Göransson told me to 'trust the process.'

direct.q1_response: Two hundred forty thousand kronor a year. Fifty per member, four hundred members. It's supposed to go to the solidarity fund — strike support, legal aid, training. Nothing's been spent on any of that since '72.
direct.expression_hint: Counting on fingers with precision

q2_options.text: That's almost half a million in two years with no spending. Where's the money sitting?
Who controls the fund? Is there a board or just one person?
Have you requested an audit from the regional office?

outcomes.response: Göransson controls it. He's chairman, treasurer, and signatory. Nobody else has access. I asked for an audit and was told 'the books are in order.'
outcomes.feedback: One-man control with no oversight. Structural problem confirmed.
outcomes.note: Göransson controls it

outcomes.response: I requested an audit. Göransson said the regional office handles it. The regional office said they don't audit local funds. So I went to Handelsbanken myself. The account balance doesn't match what it should be. It's about 180,000 kronor short.
outcomes.feedback: 180,000 kronor gap in the fund. That's embezzlement territory.
outcomes.note: It's about 180,000 kronor short

outcomes.response: Here's what I found — the account balance is 58,000 kronor. After two years of collecting 240,000 annually with zero legitimate expenses, it should be close to half a million. And the withdrawals are all in Göransson's name. Cash. No receipts filed.
outcomes.feedback: Documented gap of ~400,000 kr with cash withdrawals traced to one person. Iron-clad.
outcomes.note: Receipts filed

direct.q1_note: Nothing's been spent on any of that since '72

pressure.q1_response: Stealing? That's... I mean, I don't want to say that. But something is very wrong. The numbers don't add up. And Göransson gets very angry when anyone asks.

q2_options.text: I understand the hesitation. What specifically doesn't add up?
What happens when someone asks? Has anyone been retaliated against?
Göransson's anger — is it because the answer would be damaging?

outcomes.response: Four hundred members paying fifty kronor. No workshops, no strike fund payouts, no legal aid. The money goes in. Nothing comes out. That's what doesn't add up.
outcomes.feedback: The math problem is clear but she pulled back from the accusation.
outcomes.note: The money goes in

outcomes.response: Lena Forsberg asked at the September meeting. Next week, her shift was changed to nights. Her husband works days. Now they never see each other. Göransson didn't say it was punishment. He didn't have to.
outcomes.feedback: Retaliation against a questioner. The fear is part of the story.
outcomes.note: Göransson didn't say it was punishment

outcomes.response: Two people have asked. Both got their shifts changed. And I heard from someone at Handelsbanken — the account is nearly empty. Almost half a million should be in there. It's not. You do the math.
outcomes.feedback: Retaliation pattern plus a near-empty account. The union is being robbed.
outcomes.note: I heard from someone at Handelsbanken

pressure.q1_note: Göransson gets very angry when anyone asks

silence.q1_response: ... I know what you're thinking. Why would a union member go to the press? Because the union won't listen. My own union.
silence.expression_hint: Voice cracking slightly

q2_options.text: That must feel like a betrayal.
What did you try before coming here?

outcomes.response: I wrote to the regional office. They said to take it up at the local meeting. I did. Göransson told me I was 'undermining solidarity.' The irony, right?
outcomes.feedback: She's been stonewalled but only has the runaround story.
outcomes.note: Göransson told me I was 'undermining solidarity.' The...

outcomes.response: I asked at meetings. I wrote to the region. I even tried to look at the books. Göransson keeps them in a locked drawer in his office. But his neighbor told me about the summer cottage. And the boat. On a paper mill worker's salary.
outcomes.feedback: Lifestyle doesn't match income. The circumstantial case builds.
outcomes.note: On a paper mill worker's salary

outcomes.response: I went to everyone. Nobody wanted to hear it. So I started keeping records myself. Every month's dues, every member's payment. Compare that to the bank balance — a friend checked for me. Almost 400,000 kronor has vanished. I have it all written down.
outcomes.feedback: She built her own audit. Hand-written evidence of 400,000 kr missing.
outcomes.note: Almost 400,000 kronor has vanished

silence.q1_note: My own union

title: The Schoolyard
description: Parents near the Ståhlberg steel mill worry about dust settling on the school playground.
lead_text: My daughter comes home with grey dust in her hair every day. The school is 200 meters from the slag heap.
preview: A concerned woman approaches you outside the school gates, holding a child's hand.

interview.opening_line: Look at her hair. See the grey? That's not dirt. That's from the factory. And they play outside every day.

q1_options.text: That's alarming, Astrid. How long has this been going on?
Is it metal dust? Has anyone tested it?
Are the children getting sick? Is the school covering it up?

friendly.q1_response: Since they expanded the slag heap in the spring. The wind carries it right over. Little Maja coughs every night now. And she's not the only one — half the kids in her class have the same cough.
friendly.expression_hint: Stroking her daughter's hair protectively

q2_options.text: Have other parents complained? What does the school say?
Has a doctor looked at the coughing children?
How close is the slag heap to the playground exactly?

outcomes.response: The school says it's autumn colds. Normal, they say. But it's not normal. It started when the slag heap got bigger. We all see it.
outcomes.feedback: Concerned parent testimony but no medical or environmental evidence.
outcomes.note: It started when the slag heap got bigger

outcomes.response: Dr. Lindqvist at the health center has seen seven children this month with 'respiratory irritation.' Same class, same school. She won't say it's the dust on the record, but she told me privately it's not normal.
outcomes.feedback: Doctor sees the pattern. Off-the-record medical opinion strengthens the case.
outcomes.note: She won't say it's the dust on the record, but she...

outcomes.response: I collected dust from the playground in a jar. Brought it to the pharmacy — the pharmacist said it looks like it contains heavy metals. And the headmaster? He got a letter from Ståhlbergs last month asking him not to 'alarm parents unnecessarily.' I saw a copy.
outcomes.feedback: Physical evidence plus corporate pressure on the school. The company knew.
outcomes.note: He got a letter from Ståhlbergs last month asking him...

friendly.q1_note: Little Maja coughs every night now

direct.q1_response: Nobody's tested it. That's the problem. The slag heap is 200 meters from the school. The wind blows from the west — straight over the playground — about three days a week. And the dust settles on everything.
direct.expression_hint: Pointing toward the factory stack visible above rooftops

q2_options.text: Has the school or the municipality measured air quality?
What's in a slag heap? Could it be toxic?
Who owns the land between the school and the factory?

outcomes.response: No measurements. The municipality says the factory has all required permits. End of discussion, as far as they're concerned.
outcomes.feedback: Municipality hiding behind permits. Bureaucratic deflection.
outcomes.note: The municipality says the factory has all required...

outcomes.response: The municipality hasn't measured anything. But I found out the school was built in 1962 — before the slag heap existed. The heap started in '68, expanded in '73. No environmental review was done when they expanded it. I checked.
outcomes.feedback: The school came first. No review when slag heap expanded. Procedural failure.
outcomes.note: The heap started in '68, expanded in '73

outcomes.response: No review was done. And here's why — the land between the school and the slag heap belongs to Ståhlbergs. They donated it to the municipality in '61 to build the school. Then they built the slag heap 200 meters away. The municipality can't complain about their biggest taxpayer.
outcomes.feedback: The school is on company land. The municipality is trapped. Structural corruption.
outcomes.note: Then they built the slag heap 200 meters away

direct.q1_note: The dust settles on everything

pressure.q1_response: Sick? My Maja coughs every night. But covering it up? The school isn't evil — they're scared. Ståhlbergs employs half the parents. Nobody wants to make a fuss.
pressure.expression_hint: Lowering her voice, glancing at other parents

q2_options.text: What are the parents afraid of specifically?
Has the school been told not to raise concerns?
If the factory employs the parents, who protects the children?

outcomes.response: Afraid of rocking the boat. My husband works at the mill. If I make noise, what happens to his job? That's what everyone thinks.
outcomes.feedback: The fear is real but it's just a parent's worry, not evidence.
outcomes.note: My husband works at the mill

outcomes.response: The headmaster got a call from Bergström's office. 'Don't create unnecessary alarm.' I know because I was in the office when it happened. The headmaster went white.
outcomes.feedback: Direct corporate pressure on a public school. That's the story.
outcomes.note: The headmaster went white

outcomes.response: Bergström's office called the headmaster AND the health center. 'Don't create alarm.' Dr. Lindqvist was told not to link the children's symptoms to the factory. I know because she told me — off the record. She's terrified too. Everyone is.
outcomes.feedback: Coordinated suppression of both school and medical professionals. Explosive.
outcomes.note: 'Don't create alarm.' Dr

pressure.q1_note: Nobody wants to make a fuss

silence.q1_response: ... You see that grey on the climbing frame? That's not paint. Touch it. Feel it. My daughter plays on that every day.
silence.expression_hint: Walking to the fence, scraping dust with her finger

q2_options.text: How many children play here every day?
Has anyone tried to get the dust analyzed?

outcomes.response: Eighty-five children. Kindergarten through sixth grade. They eat lunch and then they go outside. Into this. Every. Single. Day.
outcomes.feedback: The scale is clear but you need more than a worried parent.
outcomes.note: They eat lunch and then they go outside

outcomes.response: I scraped some into a jar. Brought it to Ekström at the pharmacy. He said it's not ordinary dust — it's metallic. Could contain chromium, iron oxide, maybe worse. But he can't do a proper analysis. You'd need a lab.
outcomes.feedback: Pharmacist confirms metallic content. A lab test away from proof.
outcomes.note: Brought it to Ekström at the pharmacy

outcomes.response: I kept a jar of it. Ekström at the pharmacy says it's metallic. And last week I found something else — a letter in the school office waste bin. From Ståhlbergs to the headmaster. 'We appreciate your discretion regarding the expansion. The dust levels are within our internal targets.' They knew. They knew and they said nothing.
outcomes.feedback: Company letter acknowledging dust and requesting silence. This is the smoking gun.
outcomes.note: A letter in the school office waste bin

silence.q1_note: My daughter plays on that every day

title: The Mill Water
description: A retired worker says the factory's been dumping waste in the river since the sixties.
lead_text: The fish died ten years ago. We used to swim there as boys. Now it smells like chemicals.
preview: A wheezing old man at the local café insists on buying you coffee.

interview.opening_line: I worked there thirty-two years. I've seen what they put in the river. Sit down — I'll tell you everything.

q1_options.text: Thirty-two years — you must have seen a lot, Gösta. I'm listening.
What specific substances are they dumping? When did it start?
If you knew they were poisoning the river, why didn't you say something sooner?

friendly.q1_response: Started in '62 when they built the new acid bath. The runoff goes straight into Svartån. No treatment, no filter. Just a pipe into the river. Everyone knew.
friendly.expression_hint: Settling into his chair, glad someone's finally listening

q2_options.text: What kind of acid? Is the pipe still there?
When you say 'everyone knew' — does that include management?
Have you noticed any health effects in the people living near the river?

outcomes.response: Hydrochloric acid from the pickling process. The pipe's behind the loading dock — you can see it from the bridge if you know where to look. It runs at night, mostly.
outcomes.feedback: The pipe exists and you know where it is. A good start.
outcomes.note: It runs at night, mostly

outcomes.response: Hydrochloric acid, chromium rinse, and the cooling water from the furnace. The pipe runs into the river at night. And management knows — I was there when Bergström's father ordered it installed. 'Cheaper than treatment,' he said. I remember because my foreman laughed.
outcomes.feedback: Three pollutants, a management order, and a direct quote. Strong sourcing.
outcomes.note: I was there when Bergström's father ordered it...

outcomes.response: In '71, the county did a water test downstream. The results were bad — heavy metals, pH levels way off. Bergström sent his lawyer to meet with the county inspector. After that meeting, the report was 'revised.' The final version said 'within acceptable parameters.' I know because the original inspector quit over it. He's still alive. Name's Holmgren.
outcomes.feedback: Falsified county report plus a named whistleblower. Massive story.
outcomes.note: After that meeting, the report was 'revised.' The...

friendly.q1_note: Started in '62 when they built the new acid bath

direct.q1_response: Hydrochloric acid from the pickling line. Chromium from the plating wash. And whatever comes out of the cooling system — metals, oils, who knows what. Since 1962, through a 15-centimeter pipe into Svartån.
direct.expression_hint: Drawing a map on a napkin

q2_options.text: Is the pipe still active? Does anyone regulate it?
Have there been any official inspections of the discharge?
What volume are we talking about? How much goes in daily?

outcomes.response: Still active. They run it at night. The county is supposed to inspect annually but I haven't seen an inspector at that pipe in years. They inspect the front gate — not the back.
outcomes.feedback: Pipe is active, inspections are superficial. But it's his word.
outcomes.note: The county is supposed to inspect annually but I...

outcomes.response: Still pumping every night. About 2,000 liters goes through between midnight and four AM. The county inspected in '71 — found violations. Then Bergström's lawyer showed up and the report was 'adjusted.' The violations disappeared from the final version.
outcomes.feedback: Volume estimate plus a falsified inspection report. Documentary angle.
outcomes.note: Then Bergström's lawyer showed up and the report was...

outcomes.response: Two thousand liters a night, twelve years straight. Do the math — that's almost nine million liters of contaminated water. In '71 the county found violations and Bergström had the report changed. The inspector who filed it — Stig Holmgren — was pressured to resign. He lives in Karlstad now. I have his address if you want to talk to him.
outcomes.feedback: Nine million liters, falsified report, and a named witness. This could bring the factory down.
outcomes.note: In '71 the county found violations and Bergström had...

direct.q1_note: Since 1962, through a 15-centimeter pipe into Svartån

pressure.q1_response: Why didn't I? Because I had a family to feed! You try being a whistleblower when the factory is the only employer in town. I waited until I retired. Are you going to listen or judge?

q2_options.text: You're right. I'm sorry. Tell me what you saw.
You're safe now though. What exactly did they dump?
Other workers must have seen it too. Who else knows?

outcomes.response: Acid and metal wash. Through a pipe into the river. Everyone on the night shift knew. We just... didn't talk about it.
outcomes.feedback: Basic facts confirmed but he's holding back after the aggressive start.
outcomes.note: Didn't talk about it

outcomes.response: Fine. Hydrochloric acid and chromium waste. A pipe behind the dock. Two thousand liters a night. I know because I maintained the pump for seven years. And every time there was an inspection, we'd shut it off the day before. Someone always tipped us off.
outcomes.feedback: Inside knowledge of the concealment system. He maintained the pump.
outcomes.note: Someone always tipped us off

outcomes.response: I maintained that pump for seven years. I know exactly what went through it. And I kept a logbook — dates, volumes, what they ran. My own record, hidden at home. Because I knew this day would come. I also know the inspector who tried to report it and was forced out. Holmgren. He'll talk.
outcomes.feedback: Seven years of personal logbooks plus a willing second source. Explosive investigative material.
outcomes.note: I also know the inspector who tried to report it and...

pressure.q1_note: I waited until I retired

silence.q1_response: ... Smart. You wait. Like I waited. Thirty-two years I waited. The river turned grey. The fish died. My grandchildren can't swim where I swam. And the factory keeps pumping.
silence.expression_hint: Staring at his coffee, then at the window toward the river

q2_options.text: The river turned grey.
What changed that made you want to talk now?

outcomes.response: Grey and sometimes green. Depends on what they're running. The acid turns it grey. The chromium gives it a shimmer. You can still see it from the bridge on a moonlit night.
outcomes.feedback: Vivid description but it's an old man's memory. You need more.
outcomes.note: You can still see it from the bridge on a moonlit night

outcomes.response: My grandson asked me why the river smells. I couldn't lie to him. So I'll tell you instead. Two thousand liters a night. Acid and metals. And the county knew — they tested it in '71. The results disappeared.
outcomes.feedback: The grandson triggered it. Emotional and factual — the disappeared results give it weight.
outcomes.note: They tested it in '71

outcomes.response: I'm dying. Doctor says the lungs. Thirty-two years of breathing what they put in the water and the air. I kept a logbook. Seven years of dates and volumes. And I know who else can confirm it — Stig Holmgren, the county inspector they pushed out. Here. Take this.
outcomes.feedback: A dying man's logbook and a second source. This is the biggest environmental story in the county.
outcomes.note: Stig Holmgren, the county inspector they pushed out

silence.q1_note: The fish died

title: The Wage Slip
description: A leaked document shows management planned to reject the wage increase before negotiations even started.
lead_text: They had the answer ready before we even sat down. The whole negotiation was a show.
preview: An envelope slipped under the office door overnight, containing a photocopied memo.

interview.opening_line: I typed that memo. I know what it says. They decided the outcome before the union even entered the room.

q1_options.text: That took courage, Kerstin. What exactly did the memo say?
When was the memo dated? Who wrote it and who received it?
This looks like bad-faith bargaining. Is that what you're saying?

friendly.q1_response: Two weeks before the wage negotiations. Director Bergström to the board: 'The request will be denied regardless of presentation. Prepare conciliatory language for the press release.' They had the press release written before the meeting.
friendly.expression_hint: Speaking quietly, checking the door

q2_options.text: A press release already written? Can you describe it?
What was the union asking for? Was it unreasonable?
Were there other memos like this? Is it a pattern?

outcomes.response: The press release said management had 'carefully considered the proposal' and found it 'incompatible with current market conditions.' Word for word what they said after the meeting. They didn't consider anything.
outcomes.feedback: Pre-written rejection language. Embarrassing but not illegal.
outcomes.note: They didn't consider anything

outcomes.response: The union asked for a 4% raise. Industry standard. The memo said: 'Offer 1.5% with improved canteen facilities as compromise. Cost of canteen improvements: negligible. Optics: positive.' They planned the whole kabuki.
outcomes.feedback: Scripted negotiation with calculated optics. Shows contempt for the process.
outcomes.note: The memo said: 'Offer 1.5% with improved canteen...

outcomes.response: The memo included a line I'll never forget: 'Union leadership will accept 1.5% — Göransson has been briefed and will recommend acceptance.' The union chairman was in on it. They fixed the negotiation from both sides.
outcomes.feedback: Collusion between management and union leadership. Both sides betrayed the workers.
outcomes.note: The memo included a line I'll never forget: 'Union...

friendly.q1_note: Director Bergström to the board: 'The request will be...

direct.q1_response: October 14th. From Bergström to the board — Lundgren, Ståhl, and Franzén. CC'd to the company lawyer. Marked 'strictly confidential.' I have the carbon copy.
direct.expression_hint: Tapping a plain brown envelope on the table

q2_options.text: Can I see the carbon copy?
What specifically does the memo instruct the board to do?
Why was the company lawyer CC'd?

outcomes.response: The memo says to reject any increase above 1.5%. The rest is strategy language — 'maintain firm position,' 'express sympathy for worker concerns.' Standard manipulation.
outcomes.feedback: Clear rejection strategy but could be defended as normal negotiation prep.
outcomes.note: 'maintain firm position,' 'express sympathy for worker...

outcomes.response: Here — read it yourself. 'Reject any increase above 1.5%. If union threatens action, remind them of the oil crisis and potential layoffs. Layoffs are not planned but the threat is useful.' They weaponized job insecurity.
outcomes.feedback: Written admission of using false layoff threats as leverage. This is the story.
outcomes.note: 'Reject any increase above 1.5%

outcomes.response: Read it. The last paragraph: 'Union chairman has indicated willingness to settle at 1.5% provided management supports his re-election bid at the April meeting.' Bergström and Göransson made a deal. The workers never had a chance.
outcomes.feedback: Management-union chairman pact. Corruption on both sides of the table.
outcomes.note: The last paragraph: 'Union chairman has indicated...

direct.q1_note: Marked 'strictly confidential.' I have the carbon copy

pressure.q1_response: Bad-faith? That's exactly what it is. But try proving it. The original memo is in Bergström's safe. I only have the carbon copy. And if they find out I gave it to you, I'm finished.

q2_options.text: I'll protect your identity. What does the carbon copy say?
If you're this scared, why come forward at all?
Would anyone else corroborate what you're telling me?

outcomes.response: It says to reject anything above 1.5%. 'Express regret, cite market conditions.' The usual corporate script. But the fact that they wrote it two weeks before the meeting — that's the point.
outcomes.feedback: The timing is the story, but it's thin without more context.
outcomes.note: It says to reject anything above 1.5%

outcomes.response: Because 340 workers deserved a fair negotiation. The memo tells the board to threaten layoffs if the union pushes back. But there are no planned layoffs — it says so right there. 'Layoffs are not planned but the threat is useful.' I typed those words.
outcomes.feedback: The false layoff threat in writing. She typed it — she's a direct witness.
outcomes.note: The memo tells the board to threaten layoffs if the...

outcomes.response: Because I also typed the follow-up memo — where Bergström thanks Göransson for his 'cooperation' and promises to 'ensure his continued leadership position.' The union chairman sold out his own members for a handshake deal with the boss.
outcomes.feedback: Two memos proving collusion. The secretary typed them both. Devastating.
outcomes.note: Where Bergström thanks Göransson for his 'cooperation'...

pressure.q1_note: I only have the carbon copy

silence.q1_response: ... I thought you'd have more questions. Most people do. But I suppose the document speaks for itself. I'll just say this: I type everything in that office. Everything.
silence.expression_hint: Sliding the envelope across the table

q2_options.text: Everything. What else have you typed?
This document — when was it written relative to the negotiations?

outcomes.response: The memo is dated October 14th. The negotiations were October 28th. Fourteen days. They knew exactly what they'd say.
outcomes.feedback: Clean timeline. Pre-planned rejection.
outcomes.note: The negotiations were October 28th

outcomes.response: Termination lists. Two sets. One real — for the oil crisis contingency. One fake — designed to scare the union during negotiations. 'Show them the list but don't file it.' Bergström's instructions.
outcomes.feedback: Fake termination lists as intimidation. Written evidence of deception.
outcomes.note: Designed to scare the union during negotiations

outcomes.response: I type everything. Including the letter from Göransson to Bergström — the union chairman writing to the factory director, asking for 'mutual understanding on the wage question.' Dated October 10th. Four days before the rejection memo. They coordinated. And I have carbons of both.
outcomes.feedback: The union chairman initiated the collusion. Carbon copies of both sides. Nuclear.
outcomes.note: Including the letter from Göransson to Bergström

silence.q1_note: I suppose the document speaks for itself

title: The Fire Drill
description: A fire drill at the paper mill revealed emergency exits blocked by stored materials.
lead_text: We couldn't get out. Three exits, all blocked. The fire chief was furious.
preview: A mill worker approaches you outside the library, looking over his shoulder.

interview.opening_line: Last Thursday's fire drill. It was a disaster. But nobody's talking about it because the company 'resolved it internally.'

q1_options.text: That sounds serious, Rune. Tell me what happened during the drill.
Which exits were blocked? What was blocking them?
If there had been a real fire, how many people would have died?

friendly.q1_response: Fire bell rings at 14:00. My section — forty-three men — start moving to the exits. Exit B: pallets of raw paper stacked floor to ceiling. Exit C: a forklift parked across the door. Exit D: chained shut. We had to go all the way back to the main entrance.
friendly.expression_hint: Counting exits on his fingers, getting agitated

q2_options.text: What did the fire chief say when he saw this?
How long did it take everyone to get out?
Who authorized storing materials in front of the exits?

outcomes.response: Twelve minutes for full evacuation. Standard should be under four. The fire chief told the production manager it was 'unacceptable.' Next day, the pallets were moved. Problem solved, they said.
outcomes.feedback: Three times the evacuation standard. Quick fix but no accountability.
outcomes.note: Twelve minutes for full evacuation

outcomes.response: Fire chief Bengtsson was livid. He wrote a formal violation report. I saw him hand it to the production manager. But here's the thing — when I asked about it this week, the production manager said 'no formal report was filed.' It vanished.
outcomes.feedback: Disappeared violation report. The cover-up is the story.
outcomes.note: When I asked about it this week, the production...

outcomes.response: Bengtsson filed a violation report. It disappeared. But what they don't know is that I was there when he filed it, and I wrote down the reference number — FV-74-019. You can call the fire department and ask for it. If it's not in their files either, then someone in the municipality is covering for the factory.
outcomes.feedback: Reference number you can verify independently. If it's missing from fire department records too, it's a conspiracy.
outcomes.note: Bengtsson filed a violation report

friendly.q1_note: Exit B: pallets of raw paper stacked floor to ceiling

direct.q1_response: Exit B: raw paper pallets, about three meters high. Exit C: forklift parked sideways, keys removed. Exit D: padlocked. A padlock on a fire exit. The fire code is very clear about that.
direct.expression_hint: Speaking precisely, a supervisor's attention to detail

q2_options.text: Who has the key to Exit D? Why was it locked?
Does the fire department know about this? Was it reported?
Is the fire code violation still ongoing, or did they fix it?

outcomes.response: They moved the pallets and the forklift the next day. Exit D was unlocked. The production manager called it a 'temporary storage solution' that 'unfortunately coincided with the drill.'
outcomes.feedback: Quick fix with corporate language. No accountability trail.
outcomes.note: The production manager called it a 'temporary storage...

outcomes.response: Exit D was locked because of theft. Someone was stealing paper stock. Instead of hiring a guard, they chained the exit. The fire chief filed a violation — number FV-74-019. When I checked this week, the production manager denied any report was filed.
outcomes.feedback: Locked exit to prevent theft, disappeared violation report.
outcomes.note: When I checked this week, the production manager...

They copied and pasted away our health.

outcomes.note: Seventeen households reporting respiratory problems

outcomes.response: Fine. you need to know. The mill applied for a production increase permit in 1972. My neighbor Olle climbed the fence last month and photographed the filter housing. The seals are original — from 1969. They never replaced them. They submitted a false certificate.

outcomes.note: She's afraid of losing her job

title: The Immigrant Barracks
description: Yugoslav guest workers at the steel mill are housed in former military barracks. Conditions are reportedly dreadful.
lead_text: Twenty men in a barracks built for ten soldiers. No heating after midnight. Shared toilet for forty.
preview: A note in broken Swedish, pushed under the newspaper office door.

interview.opening_line: Please — not my name in the paper. They send us home if we complain. But someone must know how we live.

q1_options.text: I understand, Dragan. I can protect your identity. Tell me what life is like in the barracks.
I won't print your name. How many workers are housed there? What are the exact conditions?
These conditions sound illegal. If the housing authority inspected, the company would be shut down.

friendly.q1_response: We came for better life. Back home I am teacher. Here I am piece of machine. We work, we sleep, we work again. The barracks has no hot water since October. Mold on walls. My friend Zoran is coughing all night. We can't see doctor — they say time off is contract violation.
friendly.expression_hint: Speaking slowly in accented Swedish, watching for the foreman

q2_options.text: What did you do back home? What brought you to Sweden?
Who manages the barracks? Is it the company or a housing provider?
You said no doctor visits — what happens when someone is seriously ill?

outcomes.response: The barracks is company property. The foreman has keys. We pay 800 kronor per month from our salary. For mold and cold water. Swedish workers get company apartments in town with central heating and their own bathroom.
outcomes.feedback: Two-tier housing system. Swedish workers get apartments, immigrants get barracks. But no proof of code violations.
outcomes.note: We pay 800 kronor per month from our salary

outcomes.response: Mirko broke his arm last month. Foreman drove him to hospital but told the doctor Mirko fell at home, not at work. No workers' compensation. Mirko paid the hospital bill himself — three months' savings. The foreman said if he reported it as workplace accident, his contract would be 'reviewed.'
outcomes.feedback: Fabricated accident reports to avoid workers' comp. The foreman is systematically covering up workplace injuries.
outcomes.note: The foreman said if he reported it as workplace...

outcomes.response: I have photographs. I borrowed camera from the church volunteer, Mrs. Engström. Mold, broken windows, electrical wires hanging. The toilet overflows twice a week. And here — the contract we signed in Belgrade. It promises 'furnished apartment with private facilities.' This is what they gave us instead. We were lied to before we even came.
outcomes.feedback: Photos of conditions plus a contract that promised something entirely different. Documentary proof of fraudulent recruitment.
outcomes.note: The contract we signed in Belgrade

friendly.q1_note: They say time off is contract violation

direct.q1_response: Forty-two workers in four barracks buildings. Originally military, from the war. Two toilets per building, one shower — cold water only since October. No insulation. Last week it was minus fifteen and the heating stopped at midnight. Company says energy savings.
direct.expression_hint: Cautious, speaking in precise measured facts

q2_options.text: How much rent are you paying for these conditions?
Has anyone from the housing inspection ever visited?
What does your employment contract say about housing?

outcomes.response: Eight hundred kronor each. Per month. Deducted from salary before we see it. For comparison, my colleague Sven — Swedish worker, same job — pays 650 for a two-room apartment in town with heating included.
outcomes.feedback: Workers paying more for worse housing. Discrimination visible but circumstantial.
outcomes.note: For comparison, my colleague Sven

outcomes.response: Housing inspection? Once. They came in April — warmest month. Everything looked acceptable. But they gave us two weeks' notice. Two weeks! The company repaired the worst things, brought in temporary heaters, fixed one toilet. Inspector came, checked boxes, left. Next day the heaters were removed.
outcomes.feedback: Stage-managed inspection with adequate notice to temporarily fix problems. Regulatory theater.
outcomes.note: Inspector came, checked boxes, left

outcomes.response: I kept records. In my language, hidden in my mattress. Fourteen months of daily logs. On December 3, the heating failed completely. Minus eighteen outside. We burned wooden pallets in a metal barrel inside the barracks. The fire department came. The company said 'the workers were careless.' We were trying not to freeze to death.
outcomes.feedback: Fourteen months of daily documentation. The pallet fire incident — workers blamed for trying to survive. Powerful narrative with documentary support.
outcomes.note: On December 3, the heating failed completely

direct.q1_note: Cold water only since October

pressure.q1_response: Illegal? Maybe. But who enforces? The inspector comes when the company says come. And we can't complain — our work permits are tied to this employer. If they cancel contract, we go home. Home is worse. That is how they control us.
pressure.expression_hint: Looking directly at you for the first time, fierce and sad

q2_options.text: So the work permit system traps you. Has anyone tried to change employers?
Are there documents proving the company controls the housing inspections?

outcomes.response: Two men tried to leave. Applied to another factory. Their foreman found out and reported them to immigration as 'abandoning contracted employment.' They were deported within a week. The message was clear.
outcomes.feedback: Deportation used as punishment. Modern serfdom. But you'd need to verify with immigration records.
outcomes.note: Their foreman found out and reported them to...

outcomes.response: Goran tried to join the union. The local chapter said his membership was 'under review' for six months. Six months. Swedish workers join the same day. When he finally got in, his foreman transferred him to the worst shift — nights, the dangerous press line. Coincidence, they said.

outcomes.note: Nights, the dangerous press line

outcomes.response: I want them to know this: the recruitment agency in Belgrade is run by the factory owner's cousin. They charge each worker 5,000 kronor — a year's salary in Yugoslavia — as 'placement fee.' We arrive in debt to the company. In Sweden. In 1974. And every month 200 kronor is deducted from our pay to 'repay' the fee. We work for free for the first six months.
outcomes.feedback: Debt bondage through a family-run recruitment scheme. Workers arrive pre-enslaved. This isn't a labor story — it's a human trafficking story.
outcomes.note: Every month 200 kronor is deducted from our pay to...

pressure.q1_note: If they cancel contract, we go home

silence.q1_response: ...I am afraid. Every day afraid. Afraid to sleep because of cold. Afraid to be sick because of contract. Afraid to talk because of deportation. And now afraid because I am talking to you. But Zoran is very sick and nobody helps him.

q2_options.text: What's wrong with Zoran?

outcomes.feedback: A desperately ill worker afraid to stop working. Human tragedy but you need medical documentation.
outcomes.note: He cannot stop working or they cancel contract

outcomes.response: All of us. Mrs. Engström from the church — she is only Swedish person who comes. She brings food, helps with letters home. She told the social worker. The social worker visited once, wrote a report. Nothing changed. I asked Mrs. Engström to get me a copy of that report. It says 'conditions adequate for temporary workforce.' Adequate.
outcomes.feedback: A social worker's report dismissing the conditions as 'adequate.' Official indifference documented.
outcomes.note: Engström to get me a copy of that report

outcomes.response: Mrs. Engström helped me write letters. One reply came back — from a labor researcher at the university. She said our situation is 'consistent with patterns of labor exploitation documented at twelve Swedish industrial sites.' Twelve sites. We are not alone. And she has data she wants to share with a journalist. Her name is Dr. Karin Vesterberg. Please — call her.
outcomes.feedback: A university researcher with data on systematic exploitation across twelve sites. This story goes from local to national. The researcher is offering her data.
outcomes.note: She said our situation is 'consistent with patterns of...

title: The Pension Raid
description: Retired mill workers say their pensions have been quietly reduced. The mill's pension fund was supposedly 'restructured.'
lead_text: Pension checks dropped by 30% in September. No one told them why.
preview: A letter from a pensioner's wife, written in a careful hand, asking for help.

interview.opening_line: Thirty-eight years I worked that mill. They promised a pension. In writing. And now they just... take it away? I can't pay the heating bill, son.

q1_options.text: Thirty-eight years is a lifetime, Gösta. Tell me what happened to your pension.
Do you have the original pension agreement and the new reduced amount?
If they reduced contracted pensions without notice, that's breach of contract.

friendly.q1_response: I retired in '71. Pension was 2,400 kronor a month. September comes, the check is 1,680. I called the personnel office. The girl said 'the fund was restructured.' What does that mean? I asked for someone who could explain. Put on hold. Hung up on. Three times.
friendly.expression_hint: Wheezing between sentences, wife hovering nearby

q2_options.text: How many other retirees have been affected?
Did you ever get a written explanation?
What was the pension fund invested in?

outcomes.response: I know at least ten others at the pensioners' club who got smaller checks. But some don't notice — their wives manage the money. And some are too proud to admit they're struggling.
outcomes.feedback: Multiple retirees affected but no documents or details on why.
outcomes.note: Their wives manage the money

outcomes.response: Written explanation? This is what they sent. A one-page letter, dated August 28. 'Due to portfolio adjustments, pension disbursements will be recalculated effective September 1.' Recalculated. Thirty percent cut and they call it 'recalculated.' No details on the 'adjustments.' No appeal process.
outcomes.feedback: The notification letter is vague — no details, no appeal. Publishable evidence of how they communicated a massive cut.
outcomes.note: A one-page letter, dated August 28

outcomes.response: My son-in-law is an accountant in Stockholm. He looked into it. The pension fund had 14 million kronor two years ago. Now it has 6 million. Eight million gone. He checked corporate filings — the mill took a 'loan' from the pension fund to finance the new production line. A loan. From our retirement money. With no plan to repay it.
outcomes.feedback: 8 million kronor taken from the pension fund to finance factory expansion. The workers' retirement money was used to grow the owners' profits.
outcomes.note: My son-in-law is an accountant in Stockholm

friendly.q1_note: I called the personnel office

direct.q1_response: Here. My employment contract from 1933. Section 12 — pension terms. 'Full pension equivalent to 60% of final salary, guaranteed by company pension fund, not subject to reduction.' Not subject to reduction. And here's the September check — 1,680 kronor instead of 2,400.
direct.expression_hint: Spreading papers across kitchen table with shaking hands

q2_options.text: Has anyone challenged the company legally on this?
Is there a pension fund board? Who oversees it?
Can I photograph these documents?

outcomes.response: Legal challenge? With what money? We live on the pension. Or what's left of it. The union said they'd 'look into it.' That was in October. Nothing since.
outcomes.feedback: Contractual violation clear but no legal action underway. Union passive.
outcomes.note: The union said they'd 'look into it.' That was in...

outcomes.response: The pension fund board has three members. Two are company-appointed: the CFO and the plant director. The third is supposed to be a worker representative — but it's the former union chairman, Arne Grip. Arne retired in '70 on a full pension. His pension wasn't cut. That tells you everything.
outcomes.feedback: The pension board is stacked with company men. And the one 'worker representative' got his full pension — while others were cut.
outcomes.note: It's the former union chairman, Arne Grip

outcomes.response: Photograph them. Here's something else — my son-in-law got the pension fund's annual report through the corporate registry. In 1972, the fund held 14.2 million kronor. In 1973, it was 8.1 million. The annual report lists 'investment in company operations' of 6 million. The auditor signed off on it. Same auditing firm that handles the company's books.
outcomes.feedback: Pension fund raided for 6 million to buy equipment. Auditor conflict of interest. The retirees financed the very expansion that makes the owners richer while their pensions shrink.
outcomes.note: My son-in-law got the pension fund's annual report...

direct.q1_note: 1,680 kronor instead of 2,400

pressure.q1_response: Of course it's breach of contract. But who's going to enforce it? The company has lawyers. We have a rusty coffee pot and each other. You want to know how scared we are? Last week Evert refused to accept the reduced check. They told him he could 'take it or leave it.' Leave thirty-eight years of earned pension.
pressure.expression_hint: Coughing, then speaking with quiet fury

Would the retirees be willing to be named in print?

outcomes.note: If everyone lost 30%, that's

outcomes.response: Eight of us will talk. We met at Evert's kitchen last week. He's the bravest — he served in the merchant navy during the war, not afraid of the company. And Signe, widow of a mill worker, she'll talk. Her husband died on the job in '68 and she depends entirely on the survivor's pension. That was cut too.
outcomes.feedback: Group of named sources including a war veteran and a worker's widow. Human faces for the story.
outcomes.note: Her husband died on the job in '68 and she depends...

outcomes.response: One of the pensioners — I won't say who — used to be the fund administrator before he retired. There's no repayment schedule. And the fund's bylaws require a two-thirds majority to change pension terms — the vote was 2-1. The worker representative voted against but was overruled. They broke their own rules.
outcomes.feedback: 'Temporary' reallocation with no repayment, approved by a 2-1 vote when bylaws require two-thirds. They violated their own governance to raid the fund.
outcomes.note: He told me the board approved a 'temporary...

pressure.q1_note: Last week Evert refused to accept the reduced check

silence.q1_response: ...My wife cried when that check came. We already live on potatoes and herring most days. I promised her a good retirement. I worked for it. And now I sit here and I can't even... I can't even keep her warm.

Have other retirees reached out to each other?
Do you still have your original pension documents?

outcomes.response: Seven hundred kronor a month. That's what we lost. It's the heating bill. It's medicine. It's whether I can buy my grandchildren Christmas presents. Small things that make life worth living.
outcomes.feedback: The human cost is clear but you need more than one man's story. Get the documents.
outcomes.note: Small things that make life worth living

outcomes.response: We've started meeting at the church on Tuesdays. Last week, twenty-three showed up. Some of them brought their pension letters. All identical wording. Same date. Same cut. This was planned. Coordinated. They did this to all of us at once so no one could fight it alone.
outcomes.feedback: Twenty-three retirees organized. Identical letters prove a coordinated action. Group testimony.
outcomes.note: Some of them brought their pension letters

outcomes.response: I found something in my papers last night. From 1965, when they set up the pension fund. The founding document. Two lawyers and an accountant could turn this into a criminal case. Will you print that clause?
outcomes.feedback: The founding document requires unanimous consent for any non-pension use of fund assets. They had no consent at all. This is the legal bombshell.

title: Poisoned Wells
description: Residents near the chemical plant report brown water and dead fish in the creek.
lead_text: Three families on Fabriksgatan have stopped drinking tap water. Their well water turned brown last month.

title: The Silent Deaths
description: Workers at the chemical plant have been dying at unusually high rates, but the company's health records show nothing unusual.
lead_text: Five funerals in two years from the chromium division. All men under fifty-five. The company says it's coincidence.
preview: A widow stands at the factory gate holding a photograph.

interview.opening_line: My husband Erik worked in the chromium division for eighteen years. He died in March. Forty-seven years old. They said it was 'general health decline.' He was strong as an ox before he started there.

q1_options.text: I'm sorry for your loss, Gunhild. Can you tell me about Erik?
Five deaths in two years from one division. What do the death certificates say?
The company is calling these coincidences. Do you believe that?

friendly.q1_response: Erik loved fishing. Weekends at the lake, always. When he started losing weight, he said it was the shift work. Then the coughing started. Then the blood. It took fourteen months from the first symptom to the funeral.
friendly.expression_hint: Holding the photograph against her chest
friendly.q1_note: Then the blood

q2_options.text: Did Erik ever talk about conditions in the chromium division?
Have you spoken to the other widows? Are their stories similar?
What did the doctors say was the cause?

outcomes.response: He said the ventilation never worked properly. Yellow dust on everything. They gave them paper masks — flimsy things that fell apart in an hour. He'd come home with yellow fingers.
outcomes.feedback: Poor ventilation and inadequate masks suggest exposure, but no direct link to deaths established.
outcomes.note: They gave them paper masks

outcomes.response: Maja Lindqvist lost her husband in September. Britta Holm, hers in January. We talk. All the same — weight loss, coughing, blood. And all the death certificates say different things. 'Respiratory failure.' 'Liver disease.' 'Cardiac arrest.' Never the word 'chromium.' Never 'occupational.'
outcomes.feedback: Three widows, same symptoms, but different causes of death on certificates — a pattern of avoiding the occupational link.
outcomes.note: Maja Lindqvist lost her husband in September

outcomes.response: Erik kept a diary. He wrote down every day his eyes burned, every nosebleed, every time the ventilation broke down. And he wrote this, three months before he died: 'Foreman Berg said if we report the ventilation we'll be moved to the loading dock at half pay. So we breathe the dust and shut up.'
outcomes.feedback: The diary is firsthand documentation — a worker recording his own poisoning, plus the foreman's threat against reporting. Devastating.
outcomes.note: He wrote this, three months before he died: 'Foreman...

direct.q1_response: I have Erik's death certificate here. 'Respiratory failure due to chronic pulmonary condition.' No mention of chromium. No mention of occupation. I checked with Maja Lindqvist — her husband's says 'liver disease.' Britta Holm's husband: 'cardiac arrest.' Same division, same symptoms, different causes.
direct.expression_hint: Unfolds documents with careful, practiced movements
direct.q1_note: Her husband's says 'liver disease.' Britta Holm's...

q2_options.text: Did anyone request an independent autopsy or occupational health review?
Who signed the death certificates? The same doctor?

outcomes.response: I asked for a review. The company doctor — Dr. Wennerholm — said there was 'no evidence of occupational causation.' The union rep said he'd look into it. That was four months ago. Nothing.
outcomes.feedback: Same company doctor blocking investigation as in the insurance story. Pattern of suppression, but no proof.
outcomes.note: Said there was 'no evidence of occupational...

outcomes.response: Different doctors signed them, but the cause-of-death summaries all came through Dr. Wennerholm's office first. He reviews all worker deaths at the mill. He decides what to write. And he never writes 'occupational.'
outcomes.feedback: Wennerholm acting as gatekeeper for cause-of-death classification. He filters out occupational causes before other doctors sign.
outcomes.note: Different doctors signed them, but the cause-of-death...

outcomes.response: A doctor in Gothenburg — not connected to the mill — told me hexavalent chromium is a known carcinogen. Banned in many countries. Not here. And I found this in Erik's locker. *hands over a paper* Air quality measurements from 1971. Someone at the mill tested it once. The chromium levels were fourteen times the recommended limit. This paper was never shown to the workers.
outcomes.feedback: Internal air quality test showing 14x the safe limit — the company knew and buried the evidence. Combined with five deaths, this is front-page material.
outcomes.note: This paper was never shown to the workers

pressure.q1_response: Coincidence? Five men, same division, same symptoms, all dead before fifty-five? If that's coincidence, then I'm the Queen of Sweden. The company knows. They've always known.

pressure.q1_note: If that's coincidence, then I'm the Queen of Sweden

q2_options.text: What proof do you have that the company knew about the danger?
Has anyone tried to hold the company accountable? Any legal action?

outcomes.response: I went to the personnel office. They gave me a condolence letter and Erik's last paycheck. When I asked about the chromium, the woman behind the desk said she didn't know what I was talking about. 'We don't use chromium here.' They do. Everyone knows they do.
outcomes.feedback: The company denying chromium use when it's common knowledge shows institutional lying, but it's her word against theirs.
outcomes.note: They gave me a condolence letter and Erik's last...

outcomes.response: A lawyer in Gothenburg agreed to look at it. But he needs proof of exposure. The company controls all the records. Erik's personal doctor documented the symptoms but couldn't prove the cause without the company's workplace data. They won't release it.
outcomes.feedback: Company withholding workplace data from legal proceedings — obstruction that itself is newsworthy.
outcomes.note: Erik's personal doctor documented the symptoms but...

outcomes.response: I'll tell you what happened. Bergström himself called me. Personally. Offered 15,000 kronor. He called it a 'goodwill payment.' On the condition I sign a paper saying Erik's death was 'not related to his employment.' Fifteen thousand kronor for my husband's life. And my silence.
outcomes.feedback: Bergström personally offering hush money is explosive — it proves the company knows the deaths are work-related. Why pay for silence if there's nothing to hide?
outcomes.note: He called it a 'goodwill payment.' On the condition I...

silence.q1_note: The priest doesn't say anything either

q2_options.text: I'm here to listen, Gunhild.
Why do you think no one speaks up?

outcomes.response: Because the mill is everything. It's the jobs, the housing, the school, the football team. You don't speak against the mill. You just... bury your husbands and keep quiet.
outcomes.feedback: Captures the company-town dynamic perfectly, but no evidence of wrongdoing. Just the silence itself.
outcomes.note: Bury your husbands and keep quiet

outcomes.response: Erik's foreman — Berg — he came to the funeral. Stood in the back. Didn't sign the guest book. After the service he pulled me aside and said: 'It should have been better. The ventilation. I told them.' Then he left. That was his confession.
outcomes.feedback: The foreman's admission at the funeral — he told management about the ventilation. An inside witness who confirms the company was warned.
outcomes.note: I told them.' Then he left

outcomes.response: Because last time someone spoke, they were destroyed. Sven Bergqvist — the train driver — he reported the loading violations. They blacklisted him. But Erik... Erik was smarter. He wrote everything down. *hands over a small notebook* Dates. Symptoms. Names. Air that tasted like metal. He knew he was dying. He documented it for someone like you.
outcomes.feedback: Erik's daily log is a martyred worker's testimony — he documented his own death, knowing someone would eventually read it. Powerful and legally significant.
outcomes.note: He documented it for someone like you

title: The Double Agent
description: The local union chairman has been secretly negotiating with management — trading wage increases for personal benefits.

interview.opening_line: Folke Dahlberg sold us out. I found the papers in his desk when he was in Stockholm. Secret agreements. The membership voted for a 12% raise. Folke settled for 4% — and a company car for himself.

title: The Harbor's Secret
description: Suspicious cargo has been moving through the harbor at night — drums of industrial waste being loaded onto unmarked barges.
lead_text: A dockworker says unmarked barges arrive after midnight. The cargo stinks of chemicals. No manifests. No records.
preview: A dockworker slips you a note at the pub: 'Pier 4, midnight. Bring a camera if you dare.'

interview.opening_line: I operate the night crane when they need me. Three times this month — unmarked drums. No shipping documents. The foreman says it's 'surplus materials.' Surplus doesn't burn your eyes when a drum leaks.

q1_options.text: That sounds dangerous, Sven. How long has this been going on?
How many drums? Where are they going? What markings, if any?

friendly.q1_response: Since September, at least. Maybe longer — I only work the night shift twice a week. But when I'm there, it's always the same. Flatbed trucks arrive around one AM. No license plates. Drums get loaded onto barges that head south. No paperwork.

outcomes.note: Not a word.' Unsigned, but I know the handwriting

direct.q1_response: I counted thirty-two drums last Tuesday alone. Standard industrial 200-liter size. Mark on the side — a white X, nothing else. The barge 'Elsa-Marie' takes them. Registered in Gothenburg but I've never seen it in daylight.
