title: Stranded Tourists
description: A group of German tourists were left stranded on the island overnight after the last ferry was cancelled without warning.
lead_text: We waited three hours at the pier. No ferry. No announcement. A fisherman eventually gave us a ride back. In the dark.
preview: An angry tourist stopped you outside the harbor café.

interview.opening_line: Those poor Germans. They ended up at my pub at ten at night, freezing. I gave them soup and blankets and called around for someone with a boat. Bengt's ferry just... never came.

q1_options.text: That was kind of you, Inger. Does this happen often?
Why was the ferry cancelled? Was there any official notice?
Is the harbor authority deliberately cutting island services to save money?

friendly.q1_response: More than it should. This autumn, five cancellations. No storm, no mechanical failure. Just... no ferry. The islanders are used to it, but tourists? They don't know what to do.
friendly.expression_hint: Wiping the bar, shaking her head
friendly.q1_note: Five cancellations this autumn, no clear reason

q2_options.text: What do the islanders think is causing the cancellations?
Has anyone complained officially?
How is this affecting your business on the island?

outcomes.response: Everyone talks about it. Bengt — the captain — says he gets hold orders from the harbor master's office. Radio calls telling him to wait. Sometimes the wait turns into a cancellation. Nobody tells the passengers.
outcomes.feedback: Confirms the hold-order pattern from the ferry captain himself. Harbor master office issuing radio cancellations.
outcomes.note: Bengt confirms harbor office radio cancelpations

outcomes.response: The island council sent a letter to the county transport authority. That was in September. No reply. They sent another in October. A form letter came back saying 'the matter is under review'.
outcomes.feedback: Bureaucratic stonewalling. Two letters, one form response. No action.
outcomes.note: Two complaint letters, form letter reply

outcomes.response: We're dying out here. The tourists don't come back. The summer café closed early. Two families moved to the mainland this year because they couldn't rely on the ferry.
outcomes.feedback: Island decline. Good community story but no investigation angle yet.
outcomes.note: Two families moved to mainland, café closed early

direct.q1_response: No notice. Nothing. The last ferry just didn't arrive. When you call the harbor office after hours, you get an answering machine that says 'normal service resumes tomorrow.' That's it.
direct.expression_hint: Arms crossed, frustrated
direct.q1_note: No notice — harbor office answering machine only

q2_options.text: Is there a legal requirement for the ferry to maintain its schedule?
Who at the harbor office decides on cancellations?
What time was the ferry supposed to arrive that night?

outcomes.response: There is! The county concession agreement requires minimum four daily return trips. I got a copy from the library. They're violating their own contract and nobody's enforcing it.
outcomes.feedback: Concession contract violation. Four daily trips required. Documentary evidence available.
outcomes.note: County concession requires 4 daily trips — being violated

outcomes.response: Lindqvist. Who else? He controls everything in this harbor. The harbormaster's office, the scheduling, the channel access. One man with too much power.
outcomes.feedback: Points to Lindqvist but no specific evidence of his decision-making.
outcomes.note: Lindqvist controls scheduling

outcomes.response: The 18:30. It's the last crossing. Those tourists had been at the fortress all day. Came down to the pier at 18:00 as the schedule says. Nobody there.
outcomes.feedback: Timeline established but doesn't explain the cancellation.
outcomes.note: 18:30 ferry, tourists arrived at 18:00

pressure.q1_response: Save money? The ferry is subsidized! It costs them nothing to run it. This isn't about money — it's about Lindqvist running this harbor like his personal kingdom.
pressure.expression_hint: Voice rising, hands on the bar
pressure.q1_note: Ferry is subsidized — not a cost issue

q2_options.text: What does Lindqvist gain by cancelling ferry services?
Do the islanders feel like they've been abandoned by the authority?
Could the cancellations be connected to something else happening in the harbor?

outcomes.response: Control. He likes knowing that nothing moves in this harbor without his say-so. The ferry, the cargo ships, the fishing boats. All of it goes through Axel Lindqvist.
outcomes.feedback: Character portrait of Lindqvist but no concrete evidence of wrongdoing.
outcomes.note: Lindqvist runs harbor as personal kingdom

outcomes.response: Abandoned? We were abandoned when the school closed. When the doctor stopped coming. The ferry was the last thing connecting us. And now even that's unreliable.
outcomes.feedback: Island isolation. Emotional but won't drive an investigation piece.
outcomes.note: School closed, doctor stopped coming

outcomes.response: *lowers voice* I don't know what it's connected to. But I'll tell you this — every time the ferry is cancelled, there's a ship at pier 7 the next morning that wasn't there the night before. I can see it from the pub window. Ask yourself what arrives in this harbor after the ferry stops running.
outcomes.feedback: Pier 7 activity correlated with ferry cancellations. Line of sight from the pub window. That's an independent witness to the pattern.
outcomes.note: Pier 7 vessels appear after ferry cancellations — seen from pub

silence.q1_response: *sighs* ...I've run this pub for twenty years. The island used to be alive. Families, tourists, fishing boats. Now... it's just me and the regulars, wondering if the ferry will come.
silence.expression_hint: Looking out the window at the empty pier
silence.q1_note: Twenty years on the island — slow decline

q2_options.text: What changed?
What does the island need most right now?
What do you see from your window that worries you?

outcomes.response: Lindqvist. He became harbor master six years ago. Before him, the ferry ran like clockwork. The harbor was open. Fishermen came and went. Now everything goes through one desk.
outcomes.feedback: Timeline: Lindqvist became harbor master 6 years ago. Decentralized harbor became a one-man operation.
outcomes.note: Lindqvist became harbor master 6 years ago — everything changed

outcomes.response: Someone to fight for us. The county doesn't care. We're 142 people on a rock. But we have a contract that says four ferry trips a day. If someone would just enforce it, we'd be fine.
outcomes.feedback: 142 islanders, legal contract, no enforcement. This is a public service failure with documentary evidence.
outcomes.note: 142 islanders, four-trip contract unenforced

outcomes.response: Ships in the dark. After the last ferry is cancelled, I see lights at pier 7. Loading or unloading, I can't tell. But it's always on nights when the ferry doesn't run. I started writing down the dates. Here.
outcomes.feedback: Dated observations of pier 7 activity correlating with cancelled ferries. Written log from an independent witness.
outcomes.note: Written log of pier 7 activity on cancelled ferry nights

title: The Light That Went Out
description: The lighthouse lamp failed and wasn't repaired for two weeks. The keeper says the harbor authority refused to pay for parts.
lead_text: The lamp has been dark for twelve nights. I've reported it every day. They say it's 'low priority'. Tell that to the fishermen coming in at night.
preview: An old man in a knitted sweater waiting for you on the office steps.

interview.opening_line: Twelve nights without a light. Do you know what that means for the boats coming in through the strait? It means guesswork. And guesswork kills.

q1_options.text: Twelve nights is a long time, Viktor. What went wrong with the lamp?
Who refused the repair? What's the official reason for the delay?
Is the harbor authority deliberately letting the lighthouse deteriorate to close it down?

friendly.q1_response: The rotating mechanism. Old but reliable — if you maintain it. It needed a bearing replacement. Simple job. I could do it myself if they'd authorize the part. 2,400 kronor. That's all.
friendly.expression_hint: Thick hands, knows his machinery
friendly.q1_note: 2,400 kronor bearing replacement, simple repair

q2_options.text: That's not much money. Why won't they approve it?
Have boats been in danger since the light went out?
How long have you been the keeper here?

outcomes.response: Because the lighthouse budget was 'reallocated'. Lindqvist moved it to 'harbor infrastructure upgrades'. I asked what upgrades. Nobody could tell me. There's no budget left for maintenance.
outcomes.feedback: Budget redirected from lighthouse safety to unnamed 'upgrades'. Financial paper trail exists.
outcomes.note: Lighthouse budget 'reallocated' to unnamed upgrades

outcomes.response: Erik Sjögren's trawler scraped the rocks last Thursday night. He was navigating blind. Missed the channel by fifty meters. He's lucky his hull held. Next time he might not be.
outcomes.feedback: Real danger — a trawler hit rocks. Good incident but you need to prove the systemic failure.
outcomes.note: Trawler scraped rocks navigating without lighthouse

outcomes.response: Thirty-one years. My father was keeper before me. This light has burned every night since 1897. Until now.
outcomes.feedback: Heritage angle — 77 years of unbroken service. Emotional but not investigative.
outcomes.note: 31 years as keeper, light burning since 1897

direct.q1_response: Lindqvist's office. I submitted form HM-7 for emergency repair authorization. Denied. Stamp says 'insufficient budget allocation for peripheral infrastructure.' Peripheral! It's a lighthouse!
direct.expression_hint: Pulls a stamped form from his jacket pocket
direct.q1_note: Repair denied on form HM-7, 'peripheral infrastructure'

q2_options.text: Can I see that denied form? That's evidence.
Where did the lighthouse maintenance budget go?
Is there a higher authority that oversees lighthouse operations?

outcomes.response: Here. Look at the stamp. 'Denied — insufficient allocation.' Signed by Lindqvist himself. Dated November 13th. The lamp went out November 12th.
outcomes.feedback: Dated, signed denial form. Good document but the story is why the budget was redirected.
outcomes.note: Denial form signed by Lindqvist, November 13th

outcomes.response: Interesting you should ask. I went to the county archives. The harbor authority received the same allocation as last year. But the line item for 'safety and navigation' was cut to zero. The money went to 'construction consultancy fees.' Who's consulting? For what?
outcomes.feedback: Safety budget zeroed out, money moved to mystery consultancy fees. Follow the money.
outcomes.note: Safety budget zeroed, moved to 'construction consultancy fees'

outcomes.response: The Swedish Maritime Administration. But they only inspect annually. Next inspection is March. Five months away. A lot of dark nights until then.
outcomes.feedback: Annual oversight only. Gap in accountability. But no document trail.
outcomes.note: Maritime Administration inspects annually, next in March

pressure.q1_response: Close it down? *clenches jaw* Over my dead body. But... you might be right. Land values. That's what I keep hearing. The lighthouse land is worth something to developers.
pressure.q1_note: Lighthouse land has development value

q2_options.text: Who wants the lighthouse land? Are there development plans?
Has anyone approached you about selling or moving?
Is Lindqvist connected to any development interests?

outcomes.response: I've seen a man from NordSjö AB measuring the headland. Twice. Nobody asked my permission. When I confronted him, he said he had 'authorization from the harbor authority.' Lindqvist, again.
outcomes.feedback: NordSjö surveying lighthouse land with harbor authority authorization. Development angle uncovered.
outcomes.note: NordSjö man surveying lighthouse headland with Lindqvist's authorization

outcomes.response: A letter. 'Regarding the future of the Kuststad lighthouse facility.' Talked about 'modernization alternatives' and 'automated navigation systems.' That's corporate language for tearing it down.
outcomes.feedback: Coded language for closure. But no direct evidence of a deal.
outcomes.note: Letter about 'modernization alternatives'

outcomes.response: I don't know about Lindqvist's connections. I know about lighthouses. You're the reporter — you figure out who's behind it.
outcomes.feedback: He bounced it back to you. Fair point but no new information.
outcomes.note: Shut down on connections

silence.q1_response: *looks up at the dark lighthouse tower* ...My father used to say, 'The light is a promise. It says: you'll make it home.' I can't keep that promise anymore.
silence.expression_hint: Eyes on the unlit tower, hands still
silence.q1_note: Emotional — father's legacy, broken promise

q2_options.text: What would your father say about all this?
What happens to this coast without the lighthouse?
What aren't they telling you about the lighthouse's future?

outcomes.response: He'd fight. Like he fought when they tried to automate it in '58. 'A lighthouse needs a keeper,' he said. 'Not a timer.' He won that battle. I'm not sure I'll win mine.
outcomes.feedback: History repeating. Good for the human story but needs the systemic angle.
outcomes.note: Father fought automation in 1958

outcomes.response: Ships die. People die. Last week's near-miss with the trawler was lucky. The strait has rocks that'll tear a hull apart. The light isn't decorative — it's the difference between a safe passage and a coffin.
outcomes.feedback: Maritime safety case. Near-miss documented. Stakes are life and death.
outcomes.note: Strait rocks can kill, trawler near-miss last week

outcomes.response: *very quiet* I found a county planning document in the harbor office dustbin. Someone threw it away. It's a proposed land rezoning — the lighthouse headland reclassified from 'navigation' to 'mixed commercial use.' Dated three months ago. They're not fixing the light because they've already decided to tear it down.
outcomes.feedback: Land rezoning document proves premeditated closure. They killed the budget because the lighthouse is already marked for demolition and development.
outcomes.note: Rezoning document: lighthouse land → mixed commercial use

title: The Rigged Auction
description: The daily fish auction prices keep dropping suspiciously. Someone seems to be suppressing bids.
lead_text: The herring went for 40 öre a kilo yesterday. 40 öre! That's half what we got in September. And every time, the same buyer wins.
preview: A woman in a stained apron grabbed your arm at the fish market.

interview.opening_line: I run the auction board. I see every bid. And I'm telling you — the numbers don't add up. Someone is keeping the price down on purpose.

q1_options.text: You sound worried, Vanja. What's been happening at the auction?
Who is winning the auctions? And how are they suppressing the bids?
Is the main buyer threatening other bidders to stay away?

friendly.q1_response: Since October, one buyer — Nordic Fresh AB — wins almost everything. Used to be four or five regular bidders. Now the others just... don't show up. And the prices drop every week.
friendly.expression_hint: Nervous, glancing at the auction hall
friendly.q1_note: Nordic Fresh AB winning most auctions since October, competitors disappeared

q2_options.text: Where did the other buyers go? Did they say why they stopped coming?
How much have prices dropped since October?
Who runs Nordic Fresh AB?

outcomes.response: I called one of them — Hansson from Malmö. He said he got a visit. Two men. Told him 'Kuststad fish is spoken for.' He didn't want to say more. He was scared.
outcomes.feedback: Intimidation of rival buyers. Named witness (Hansson). This is bid rigging through threats.
outcomes.note: Rival buyer Hansson from Malmö visited by two men, intimidated

outcomes.response: Herring down 55%. Cod down 40%. The fishermen are losing money on every haul. They can't cover diesel costs at these prices.
outcomes.feedback: Price data establishes the scale. But you need who and why.
outcomes.note: Herring down 55%, cod down 40%

outcomes.response: Some company from Göteborg. The buyer is always the same man — big, quiet, pays cash. No company card, no paperwork. Just 'Nordic Fresh AB' on the bid sheet.
outcomes.feedback: Anonymous cash buyer. Shell company feel. But no trail.
outcomes.note: Cash buyer, no paperwork, Göteborg company

direct.q1_response: Nordic Fresh AB. Every auction, same bid — always just one krona above minimum. Nobody outbids them because nobody else comes. The other buyers stopped showing up in October.
direct.expression_hint: Pointing at the bid sheet, voice low
direct.q1_note: One-krona-above-minimum bids, no competition

q2_options.text: Do you have copies of the bid records showing the pattern?
Why did the other buyers stop coming?
Does the auction have rules about minimum competition?

outcomes.response: I keep carbons of every bid sheet. Twenty-three auctions. Nordic Fresh won twenty-one of them. The two they didn't win, someone from Landskrona bid blind — he didn't know the rules had changed.
outcomes.feedback: Twenty-three auction records. 21 wins by one buyer. Documentary proof of monopoly.
outcomes.note: Carbon copies of 23 auctions — Nordic Fresh won 21

outcomes.response: I don't know. They just stopped. One day there were five bidders. The next week, only Nordic Fresh. Like someone flipped a switch.
outcomes.feedback: Sudden competitor disappearance confirms coordination but no mechanism explained.
outcomes.note: Competitors vanished abruptly

outcomes.response: The rules say the auction is valid with one bidder. Lindqvist set that rule last year. Before that, you needed at least two.
outcomes.feedback: Rule change by the harbor master enabled single-bidder auctions. Deliberate setup.
outcomes.note: Lindqvist changed auction rules to allow single bidders

pressure.q1_response: Threatening? I didn't say... *looks around* ...maybe. Some of the old buyers told me things. I shouldn't repeat them in public.
pressure.expression_hint: Pulling her apron tighter, scanning the market
pressure.q1_note: Hints at threats to rival bidders

q2_options.text: Vanja, fishermen's families depend on fair prices. If there's intimidation, it needs to come out.
Who specifically was threatened? I need names.
Is somebody at the harbor authority protecting Nordic Fresh?

outcomes.response: I know the families need this. That's why I'm here. But I also need THIS job. If Lindqvist finds out I talked to the press...
outcomes.feedback: She's afraid of Lindqvist. Confirms harbor authority connection but stops short of details.
outcomes.note: Afraid of Lindqvist finding out

outcomes.response: I'm not giving you names. These people trusted me. You want names, do your own digging. I've said enough.
outcomes.feedback: Too direct. She clamped up to protect her sources.
outcomes.note: Won't give names

outcomes.response: *whisper* Nordic Fresh AB. Register it in Göteborg. Then look up the board members. You'll find a name you recognize. Lindqvist's wife. She's a silent partner. The harbor master is rigging his own fish auction through his wife's company.
outcomes.feedback: Lindqvist's wife is a board member of Nordic Fresh AB. Conflict of interest. Bid rigging. Self-dealing. That's the story.
outcomes.note: Lindqvist's wife is a silent partner in Nordic Fresh AB

silence.q1_response: *stacks some fish crates, doesn't look up* ...The fishermen trust me. I'm supposed to get them a fair price. And I can't. Every morning I write down numbers I know are wrong.
silence.expression_hint: Working while talking, guilt visible
silence.q1_note: Guilt — can't get fair prices for fishermen

q2_options.text: Why do you think the prices are wrong?
How are the fishermen coping?
What would happen if the real story came out?

outcomes.response: Because I check the market price every day. Herring at 40 öre? The Göteborg wholesale is 85. Someone is getting fish at half price and reselling at market rate. That's a 100% margin.
outcomes.feedback: Price gap proves someone is profiting enormously from suppressed auction prices.
outcomes.note: 40 öre auction vs 85 öre wholesale — 100% margin

outcomes.response: Barely. Two boats didn't go out last week — couldn't afford diesel at these prices. One family is talking about selling their boat. Thirty years of fishing, gone.
outcomes.feedback: Economic devastation. Boats idled. But you need the mechanism, not just the impact.
outcomes.note: Two boats didn't go out, one family selling

outcomes.response: The fishermen would finally understand why they're losing money. And Nordic Fresh would have to answer questions. I heard from Hansson — a buyer from Malmö — that two men visited him and told him to stay away from Kuststad. That's not market competition. That's organized.
outcomes.feedback: Intimidation confirmed through a second source. Organized bid suppression with enforcement.
outcomes.note: Hansson visited and warned off by two men

title: The Broken Pipe
description: Raw sewage is leaking into the harbor near the fish market. The smell is terrible and nobody will claim responsibility.
lead_text: There's a pipe under pier 3 that's been leaking for weeks. Brown water. The fish market is twenty meters away. I called the county but they say it's the harbor authority's problem.
preview: A note from a concerned citizen, slightly damp.

interview.opening_line: You can smell it from here, can't you? That's raw sewage. Twenty meters from where I sell fish. I've been complaining for three weeks and all I get is blame-shifting.

q1_options.text: That sounds awful, Greta. Three weeks is a long time. Who have you talked to?
Where exactly is the leak? And whose pipe is it — the county's or the harbor authority's?
Is someone covering up the leak because fixing it would expose a bigger problem?

friendly.q1_response: The county says it's the harbor authority's pipe. The harbor authority says it's the county's pipe. Meanwhile, the fish market stinks and my customers are going to Landskrona instead.
friendly.expression_hint: Apron stained, hands on hips
friendly.q1_note: County and harbor authority blame each other for the pipe

q2_options.text: Is there a map or record showing who owns the pipe infrastructure?
How much business have you lost?
Has anyone actually inspected the pipe?

outcomes.response: My brother-in-law works at the county water office. He pulled the infrastructure map. The pipe IS the harbor authority's. It was transferred in 1968 when the harbor expanded. Lindqvist knows this. He's stalling.
outcomes.feedback: Infrastructure map proves ownership. Harbor authority is responsible and dodging. Documentary evidence.
outcomes.note: Infrastructure map shows harbor authority owns the pipe since 1968

outcomes.response: Thirty percent down since the smell started. The herring sellers next to me are worse off — nobody wants to buy fish that close to sewage. This is my livelihood.
outcomes.feedback: Economic impact is clear but the story needs the accountability angle.
outcomes.note: Business down 30%, herring sellers worse

outcomes.response: I asked Lindqvist to send someone. He said 'it's on the schedule.' That was two weeks ago. Nobody has come. The pipe is still leaking.
outcomes.feedback: Promises without action. Bureaucratic delay but more of the same.
outcomes.note: Harbor master promised inspection two weeks ago, nothing happened

direct.q1_response: Under pier 3, west side. There's a concrete junction where the old town sewer meets the harbor drain. The junction is cracked — you can see the raw sewage flowing into the basin. It's a 200mm main pipe. Harbor authority property.
direct.expression_hint: Drawing a map on a napkin
direct.q1_note: Concrete junction cracked under pier 3 — 200mm main pipe

q2_options.text: How do you know it's the harbor authority's pipe?
Is the sewage reaching the water where fishing boats dock?
What would it cost to fix?

outcomes.response: It's labeled! There's a cast-iron plate on the junction that says 'Kuststad Hamn, 1968.' Their pipe, their responsibility. But they keep claiming it was never transferred from the county.
outcomes.feedback: Physical label on the pipe. They can't claim it's not theirs. But that's just ownership, not cover-up.
outcomes.note: Cast-iron plate on pipe reads 'Kuststad Hamn, 1968'

outcomes.response: It reaches the fish basin. Where the boats unload their catch. I tested it with a dye tablet — red dye in the pipe leak, red water at the fishing pier thirty minutes later. This isn't just a smell — it's contaminating the catch zone.
outcomes.feedback: DIY dye test proves contamination reaches the catch area. Public health angle escalated.
outcomes.note: Dye test proves sewage reaches fish catch zone in 30 minutes

outcomes.response: A plumber told me fifteen thousand kronor. For a junction repair. That's nothing in a harbor budget. They're not fixing it because they don't care, not because they can't afford it.
outcomes.feedback: Low repair cost makes the inaction more damning but stays at incompetence level.
outcomes.note: 15,000 kr repair estimate

pressure.q1_response: Covering up? I hadn't thought of that. But now you mention it... when the county inspector came last year, Lindqvist's office suddenly fixed three things in one week. Then nothing for months.
pressure.q1_note: Repairs only happen before inspections

q2_options.text: When is the next county inspection?
What else was broken that they only fixed for the inspector?
Could the pipe problem be connected to the harbor construction work?

outcomes.response: February, I think. So they'll probably fix it in January. Just in time. And I'll have lost four months of business by then.
outcomes.feedback: Cosmetic repairs before inspections. Pattern of deception. But not enough for the pressure angle.
outcomes.note: Inspection in February, will probably fix just before

outcomes.response: The fire suppression system at the warehouse was broken for a year. Fixed the week before the inspector arrived. The dock safety railings — same thing. Eight months broken, fixed in a day. He's running this harbor on appearances.
outcomes.feedback: Pattern of deferred maintenance timed to inspections. Systematic safety fraud.
outcomes.note: Fire system and railings both fixed only for inspections

outcomes.response: The construction work! When they dug the new foundations for pier 7 — the expansion project — they hit the sewer main. I saw it happen. The foreman told his crew to 'patch it and move on.' That was September. The leak started two weeks later.
outcomes.feedback: Pier 7 construction caused the pipe break. The harbor authority damaged its own infrastructure and covered it up. That's the story.
outcomes.note: Pier 7 construction crew broke the sewer main in September

silence.q1_response: *wrinkles her nose* ...My grandmother sold fish from this same stall. Sixty years. The harbor used to smell like saltwater and herring. Now it smells like a cesspool. And nobody cares.
silence.expression_hint: Rearranging fish on ice, mechanical
silence.q1_note: Three generations of fishmongers, harbor degradation

q2_options.text: What has this harbor lost?
Is this about more than a pipe?
What would it take to fix things around here?

outcomes.response: Its dignity. This was a working harbor. Proud fishermen, clean water, honest trade. Now it's... politics. Everything is about who knows who and who owes what.
outcomes.feedback: Mood piece about decline. Good color for the article but needs facts.
outcomes.note: Harbor lost its dignity

outcomes.response: It's about a harbor authority that doesn't serve the harbor. Lindqvist runs it for himself, not for us. A broken pipe is just the symptom. The disease is deeper.
outcomes.feedback: Big picture critique. True but editorial, not evidence.
outcomes.note: Harbor authority doesn't serve the harbor

outcomes.response: Accountability. Someone to check if the harbor authority is actually doing its job. Because I checked. The annual maintenance budget is 400,000 kronor. I filed a public records request. Actual spending on maintenance last year? 47,000. Where did the other 353,000 go? Nobody will tell me.
outcomes.feedback: Massive budget discrepancy — 353,000 kronor unaccounted for. Public records request filed. That's embezzlement-level mismanagement.
outcomes.note: 400,000 kr budget, only 47,000 kr spent on maintenance — 353,000 missing

title: The Strike Threat
description: Dock workers are threatening to strike over safety conditions. The union representative says management is ignoring their demands.
lead_text: The dock crane hasn't been inspected in two years. The loading platform has a crack the width of my hand. We've given them six months of warnings. Now we strike.
preview: A typed letter from the Kuststad dock workers' union, delivered by hand.

interview.opening_line: We don't want to strike. Strikes cost us money too. But when a crane could drop a container on someone's head, you stop talking and start acting.

q1_options.text: Nobody wants a strike, Olov. What safety issues are we talking about?
What specific equipment failures have you documented? Give me the list.
Has anyone been injured because of the unsafe conditions?

friendly.q1_response: The main cargo crane — 15 tons capacity — hasn't had a certified inspection since 1972. The steel cables are fraying. The loading platform at pier 2 has stress cracks. The safety rails on the upper dock are rusted through. That's just the top three.
friendly.expression_hint: Pulls out a folded union report
friendly.q1_note: Crane, platform, and rails — all failing. Crane not inspected since 1972.

q2_options.text: Who is responsible for ordering the inspections?
How have the workers been coping with these conditions?
What does management say when you raise these issues?

outcomes.response: Lindqvist. The harbor master approves all inspection contracts. We've submitted Form S-12 safety requests six times. Each time it comes back marked 'under review.' Six times in six months. That's a policy of inaction.
outcomes.feedback: Six formal safety requests, all stonewalled. Paper trail of deliberate negligence.
outcomes.note: Six S-12 forms submitted, all returned 'under review'

outcomes.response: We've jury-rigged what we can. Extra cables on the crane as backup. Wooden shoring under the platform crack. But we're dock workers, not engineers. One of these fixes will fail.
outcomes.feedback: Workers improvising safety. Good color but the story needs the institutional failure angle.
outcomes.note: Jury-rigged repairs — extra cables, wooden shoring

outcomes.response: Management says 'it's in the budget for next year.' Every year it's 'next year.' The prioritization always goes to cargo handling capacity, never safety.
outcomes.feedback: Perpetual deferral. Cargo revenue prioritized over worker safety.
outcomes.note: 'Next year' — budget always goes to cargo capacity

direct.q1_response: Here. Our safety assessment. We hired an independent inspector with union funds. Paid 8,000 kronor out of our own pockets because management wouldn't pay. Fourteen critical findings. The inspector said the crane should be taken out of service immediately.
direct.expression_hint: Hands over a stapled report
direct.q1_note: Independent inspection: 14 critical findings, crane should be stopped

q2_options.text: Can I have a copy of that report?
What did management say about the independent inspection?
What's the worst-case scenario if the crane fails?

outcomes.response: Take it. We had five copies made. One for us, one for the county, one for the press — that's you — one for the work safety board, and one for our lawyer. We're done being polite about this.
outcomes.feedback: Full independent safety report provided. Distributed to multiple authorities. This is solid documentary evidence.
outcomes.note: Independent safety report with 14 critical findings, distributed to authorities

outcomes.response: Lindqvist called it 'unofficial' and refused to recognize it. Said only harbor-authority-approved inspectors can certify equipment. Our guy had thirty years of experience and a state license.
outcomes.feedback: Management dismissed the inspection on a technicality. Defensive posture.
outcomes.note: Lindqvist refused to recognize independent inspection

outcomes.response: Fifteen tons of steel dropping from twelve meters. The kill zone is forty square meters around the crane. During loading, there are always workers in that zone. You do the math.
outcomes.feedback: Lethal risk established. But you need the political story.
outcomes.note: Kill zone of 40 square meters during loading

pressure.q1_response: Last month. A cable snapped on the crane during a container lift. Missed Erik's head by two meters. He went on sick leave. Stress. Nightmares. And management wrote it up as 'equipment fatigue' — not negligence.
pressure.expression_hint: Fist on the table, controlled anger
pressure.q1_note: Cable snap near-miss, worker on sick leave, classified as 'equipment fatigue'

q2_options.text: Was the near-miss reported to the work safety authority?
Did management investigate the cable failure?
Is there a pattern of reclassifying accidents to avoid liability?

outcomes.response: We reported it. Management was supposed to report it too — it's mandatory for near-misses with injury risk. They didn't. I confirmed with the safety authority myself. No record from the harbor authority.
outcomes.feedback: Failure to report a mandatory near-miss incident. That's a criminal offense under work safety law.
outcomes.note: Management failed to file mandatory near-miss report

outcomes.response: Investigation? They replaced the cable and put the crane back in service the next day. No root cause analysis. No engineer review. Just a new cable and 'carry on.'
outcomes.feedback: No investigation. Cable replaced, operations continued. Negligent but common in small ports.
outcomes.note: Cable replaced same day, no investigation

outcomes.response: That's exactly what they do. I've been keeping a record. Eleven incidents in two years. Six were reclassified from 'accident' to 'equipment fatigue' or 'worker error.' The real safety record at this harbor is twice as bad as the official one.
outcomes.feedback: Eleven incidents, six reclassified. Systematic falsification of workplace safety records. This is criminal.
outcomes.note: 11 incidents in 2 years, 6 reclassified — falsified safety record

silence.q1_response: *looks at his hands* ...I've been a dock worker for twenty-two years. I've seen what happens when equipment fails. It's not pretty. And it's not theoretical. It's a matter of time.
silence.expression_hint: Old scars on his forearms visible
silence.q1_note: Twenty-two-year veteran, personal experience with equipment failure

q2_options.text: What happened to you?
What would it take for management to listen?
What keeps you fighting for safety after all these years?

outcomes.response: 1966. Loading beam collapsed at the old dock. Broke my arm in three places. They called it 'user error.' I was nineteen. I've never trusted management since.
outcomes.feedback: Personal history. Powerful for the article but it's an old story, not evidence of current failures.
outcomes.note: 1966 loading beam collapse, broken arm, blamed on worker

outcomes.response: A death. That's what it would take. And I'm terrified it's coming. The county won't act on our reports. The harbor master won't spend the money. The only thing that changes policy in this country is a body on the front page.
outcomes.feedback: Devastating quote. The prediction of a fatal accident as the only thing management will listen to. That's your lead.
outcomes.note: 'A death — that's what it would take'

outcomes.response: The people working next to me. Every morning we check the crane together. We tap the cables. We look at the cracks. We take care of each other because nobody else will.
outcomes.feedback: Solidarity portrait. Workers self-monitoring because management won't. Good color.
outcomes.note: Workers inspect crane themselves every morning

title: The Missing Sailor
description: A sailor from a foreign cargo ship hasn't been seen since his vessel left port. His belongings were found at the harbor.
lead_text: His bag is still at pier 4. Clothes, a Bible, photographs. The ship left without him. Nobody filed a report.
preview: Overheard the harbor priest talking to a fisherman outside the church. Something about a missing man.

interview.opening_line: His name is Ibrahim. He came to the seamen's mission on Saturday. Kind man, tired. His ship — the Vanadis — was supposed to stay three days. It left after one. He wasn't on it.

q1_options.text: That's troubling, Pastor. How did you come to know Ibrahim?
When did the ship leave, and who authorized an early departure?
Did the ship leave Ibrahim behind deliberately? Was he trying to escape?

friendly.q1_response: He came to my evening service. Some foreign sailors do — the seamen's mission is open to all faiths. He was quiet. Sat in the back. After the service he asked if I could help him post a letter. To his family in Aden.
friendly.expression_hint: Folding her hands, remembering
friendly.q1_note: Ibrahim from Aden, attended seamen's mission, wanted to post a letter

q2_options.text: What was in the letter?
Did Ibrahim say anything about his situation on the ship?
When did you realize he was missing?

outcomes.response: I didn't read it. But he was writing in the mission hall for a long time. Several pages. And he looked... relieved when it was done. As if he'd been carrying something heavy.
outcomes.feedback: Long letter to family suggests something significant. But you don't have the content.
outcomes.note: Long letter to family in Aden — seemed relieved after writing

outcomes.response: He said 'they don't pay us.' Four words. Then he looked at the door and didn't say more. 'They don't pay us.' The other sailors I've met from ships like the Vanadis — they tell similar stories. Contracts that promise one thing and deliver nothing.
outcomes.feedback: Unpaid wages on the Vanadis. Pattern across similar ships. This is a labor exploitation story.
outcomes.note: 'They don't pay us' — pattern of unpaid wages on ships

outcomes.response: Monday morning. I went to pier 4 to check on him — I'd promised to help with the letter. The ship was gone. His bag was sitting on the bollard. Neatly placed. Nobody had touched it.
outcomes.feedback: Bag left behind, neatly placed. Suggests intentional rather than accidental abandonment.
outcomes.note: Bag left on bollard, ship gone, neatly placed

direct.q1_response: The Vanadis departed Sunday night. It was scheduled for Tuesday. The harbor log shows departure at 23:40. No reason given. The departure was authorized by Lindqvist's night deputy.
direct.expression_hint: Has clearly done her research
direct.q1_note: Early departure Sunday night at 23:40, authorized by night deputy

q2_options.text: Who is Lindqvist's night deputy? Did they follow proper departure protocol?
Is it normal for ships to leave two days ahead of schedule?
Was a crew manifest checked at departure?

outcomes.response: A man named Persson. He handles nights and weekends. He signed the departure clearance. Whether he checked the crew against the manifest — I doubt it. Nobody does at night.
outcomes.feedback: Night deputy waved the ship through without crew verification. Procedural failure.
outcomes.note: Night deputy Persson signed clearance, no crew check

outcomes.response: Not normal. Not legal, in some cases. If a ship has open port charges or customs holds, early departure is a violation. I checked — the Vanadis had an open inspection notice from customs. They left before the inspection could happen.
outcomes.feedback: The ship fled a customs inspection. That changes everything — they left because they had to, not because they wanted to.
outcomes.note: Vanadis left before scheduled customs inspection

outcomes.response: Crew manifest? The last one on file at the harbor is from Gdańsk — the previous port. It lists fourteen crew. Ibrahim's name is on it. Whether all fourteen left Kuststad... nobody counted.
outcomes.feedback: Nobody verified the crew count at departure. A man could vanish without anyone noticing.
outcomes.note: 14 crew on manifest, nobody counted at departure

pressure.q1_response: Escape? From a ship? *pauses* ...Yes. I think so. The conditions on some of these vessels... you don't want to know. But the word 'escape' implies he had somewhere to go. He didn't. He was just... left.
pressure.expression_hint: Looking at her hands, choosing words carefully
pressure.q1_note: Possible escape attempt from poor conditions — no plan

q2_options.text: What conditions are you talking about? What happens on these ships?
Where is Ibrahim now? Has anyone seen him since the ship left?
Is this the first time a sailor has been abandoned in Kuststad?

outcomes.response: I've seen them come to the mission. Thin. Exhausted. Some haven't been paid in months. The ships are registered under flags of convenience — Panama, Liberia. No oversight. The crew are from Yemen, the Philippines, Eritrea. Invisible men on invisible ships.
outcomes.feedback: Flags of convenience, unpaid international crew. Systematic exploitation. The individual case opens a systemic story.
outcomes.note: Flags of convenience, unpaid crews from Yemen, Philippines, Eritrea

outcomes.response: No one has seen him. He could be hiding — some abandoned sailors live in the woods or find work in black. Or he could be... I pray every night that he's alive.
outcomes.feedback: Missing person, no leads. The silence is the story but you need it to point somewhere.
outcomes.note: Ibrahim not seen since Sunday — possibly hiding or worse

outcomes.response: Third time in two years that I know of. The other two found their way to Malmö eventually. Social services there handles destitute seamen. But the system assumes they'll come forward. Some don't.
outcomes.feedback: Third case in two years. Pattern. But each case faded without attention.
outcomes.note: Third abandoned sailor in two years

silence.q1_response: *looks at the harbor through the church window* ...I keep thinking about his Bible. It was in his bag. Worn thin. A man doesn't leave his Bible behind unless he had no choice.
silence.expression_hint: Hands on the windowsill, watching the water
silence.q1_note: Worn Bible left behind — suggests no choice

q2_options.text: What was in the rest of his bag?
Have you tried to find Ibrahim?
What will happen to him if nobody tells this story?

outcomes.response: Clothes. The photographs I mentioned — family, children. And a document. It's in Arabic, I can't read it. But it looks official. Stamped. I think it's a contract. If someone could translate it, we might understand what he was running from.
outcomes.feedback: A contract in Arabic — the terms of his employment. That document could prove exploitation or trafficking.
outcomes.note: Arabic contract document in bag — possible evidence of exploitation

outcomes.response: I've walked the harbor. Asked at the hostels, the shelters in Landskrona. Nothing. A man with no papers, no language, no money... this town is very small when you have nowhere to go.
outcomes.feedback: Active searching but no results. The vulnerability is clear.
outcomes.note: Pastor searched harbor, hostels, shelters — nothing

outcomes.response: He'll disappear. Like the others. And the ships will keep coming, and the crews will keep being invisible, and Lindqvist will keep clearing vessels without checking who gets left behind. Because there's no profit in caring about foreign sailors. But I have the bag. I have his name. And now, you have it too.
outcomes.feedback: The harbor master clears ships without crew checks. Foreign sailors are invisible to the system. And now you have a name, a bag with evidence, and a pastor willing to talk.
outcomes.note: Harbor clears ships without verifying crews, bag preserved as evidence

tier_2.text: Cargo ship fled Kuststad to avoid customs inspection — sailor left behind

tier_3.text: INVISIBLE CREWS: harbor authority clears ships without verifying who gets left behind

title: The Smuggling Route
description: An old smuggler hints that the harbor's old tunnels are being used again. Customs hasn't inspected them in decades.
lead_text: The tunnels under the old customs house? They sealed them in '55. Or they said they did. I was down there last month. Fresh footprints.
preview: A man at the harbor pub, three beers in, started talking about tunnels.

interview.opening_line: I'm eighty-two years old. I've done things I'm not proud of. But what's happening now makes my old business look like a church picnic.

q1_options.text: You've seen a lot, Bertil. What's changed about this harbor?
Where are the tunnels, and what did you see down there?
Are you still involved in smuggling, Bertil? Or just watching from the sidelines?

friendly.q1_response: In my day, we smuggled coffee and cigarettes. Small boats, moonlit nights. Risky, but honest dishonesty, if you know what I mean. What's going on now — it's organized. Big money. And it involves people who are supposed to be keeping order.
friendly.expression_hint: Swirling his coffee, rheumy eyes sharp
friendly.q1_note: Current smuggling is organized, involving authorities

q2_options.text: What makes you think authorities are involved?
What's being smuggled now?
How do you know about the tunnels being used again?

outcomes.response: Because the routes can't work without someone looking the other way. The channel, the pier, the customs checkpoint — it all has to be clear. In my day, I bribed one man. Now one man runs the whole system. And he doesn't need bribing because he's at the top.
outcomes.feedback: One person controls channel, pier, and customs checkpoint. That's the harbor master. Institutional corruption enabling smuggling.
outcomes.note: One man runs the system — controls channel, pier, customs

outcomes.response: Not coffee anymore. I don't know exactly. Whatever comes in crates and doesn't appear on any manifest. I've heard things at the pub. Alcohol, maybe. Electronics. Some say worse.
outcomes.feedback: Vague on the contraband. Pub rumors but no specifics.
outcomes.note: Unknown contraband — alcohol, electronics, 'maybe worse'

outcomes.response: Curiosity, mostly. The old customs house is my territory. I used those tunnels in the '40s. When I heard noises down there last month, I found the old entrance and went in. Fresh boot prints. New cable running along the wall. Someone refurbished the route.
outcomes.feedback: Fresh boot prints. New cable. Someone invested in reopening the tunnels.
outcomes.note: Fresh boot prints, new cable in the tunnels

direct.q1_response: Under the old customs house at the east end of the harbor. The main entrance was bricked up in '55 but there's a secondary entrance through the coal cellar of the warehouse next door. I used it thirty years ago. It still works.
direct.expression_hint: Drawing routes on a beer mat
direct.q1_note: Secondary entrance through coal cellar of adjacent warehouse

q2_options.text: Where do the tunnels lead? How far do they extend?
What exactly did you see when you went down there?
Could we go down there together so I can document it?

outcomes.response: From the customs house, the main tunnel runs 200 meters to pier 7. There's a branch that goes to the old fish storage — the cold rooms. Another branch leads to the harbor master's office basement. That branch was sealed in my day. It's been reopened.
outcomes.feedback: Tunnel to pier 7 AND to the harbor master's basement. That's a direct connection between smuggling infrastructure and the harbor authority.
outcomes.note: Tunnel connects pier 7 to harbor master's office basement

outcomes.response: Boot prints in dry dust. New electrical cable — modern stuff, not old wiring. A ventilation fan that was humming. And scrape marks on the floor. Like crates being dragged.
outcomes.feedback: Active infrastructure: cable, ventilation, crate marks. Recent use confirmed.
outcomes.note: New cable, working ventilation fan, crate drag marks

outcomes.response: I'm eighty-two. I barely made it down the stairs last time. But I can tell you exactly where the entrance is. You'll need a torch and rubber boots. And maybe someone you trust.
outcomes.feedback: He'll share the location but won't go himself. You'd need to investigate physically.
outcomes.note: Will share entrance location

pressure.q1_response: Involved? *chuckles* I'm eighty-two and I can barely lift a coffee cup. No. I'm not involved. But I recognize the business when I see it. I wrote the playbook, after all.
pressure.q1_note: Not currently involved, recognizes the patterns

q2_options.text: Who's running the operation now? Do you recognize anyone?
Why are you telling me this? What do you want?
If you wrote the playbook, who inherited it?

outcomes.response: I saw a man at the tunnel entrance. Two weeks ago. Night. Didn't see his face. But I recognized the car. It was the harbor master's. The black Volvo 145 with the dented fender. Everyone at the harbor knows that car.
outcomes.feedback: Harbor master's identifiable car at the tunnel entrance at night. Physical evidence of his involvement.
outcomes.note: Harbor master's black Volvo 145 seen at tunnel entrance at night

outcomes.response: Because I'm old and I'm tired and whatever happens to me doesn't matter anymore. But this harbor — it mattered to me once. I don't want to see it turned into... whatever it's becoming.
outcomes.feedback: Motivation is genuine but doesn't advance the investigation.
outcomes.note: Motivated by loyalty to the harbor

They told me it was a boating accident, but I knew. I always knew. And now the same tunnels are open again. And I can't let it happen to another family.

title: The Insurance Job
description: A fishing boat sank under suspicious circumstances. The insurance claim was filed before the salvage report was complete.
lead_text: Svensson's boat sank in calm water. Flat calm. No storm, no rocks. The insurance paid out within two weeks. Something doesn't add up.
preview: An insurance adjuster from Göteborg asked to meet you privately.

interview.opening_line: I'm not supposed to talk to the press. My company would fire me. But this claim went through faster than anything I've seen in twenty years. Someone wanted it closed before anyone asked questions.

q1_options.text: Thank you for coming forward, Henrietta. What made this claim unusual?
How fast was the payout? And who authorized it?
Was the boat sunk deliberately for the insurance money?

friendly.q1_response: A total loss claim normally takes six to eight weeks. Investigation, salvage assessment, witness interviews. This one was filed on Wednesday and paid on Friday. Two days. My regional manager approved it without asking me — and I'm the assigned adjuster.
friendly.expression_hint: Tight lips, folder in her lap
friendly.q1_note: Two-day payout instead of typical 6-8 weeks, adjuster bypassed

q2_options.text: How much was the payout?
Did your manager give a reason for bypassing you?
What was suspicious about the sinking itself?

outcomes.response: 285,000 kronor. For a fishing boat that was worth maybe 120,000 on a good day. The policy was taken out six months ago. Doubled the coverage from the original. Classic over-insurance.
outcomes.feedback: Over-insured by 165,000 kronor. Policy upgraded six months before sinking. Classic fraud markers.
outcomes.note: 285,000 payout on 120,000 boat, policy upgraded 6 months prior

outcomes.response: He said 'client relations.' That's our code for 'someone important asked nicely.' I checked the call log — my manager received a call from the Kuststad harbor authority the day before he approved it. Harbor authority doesn't normally call insurance companies about fishing boats.
outcomes.feedback: Harbor authority called the insurance company before the expedited approval. Direct interference.
outcomes.note: Harbor authority called insurance company before fast-tracked approval

outcomes.response: Flat calm. Experienced fisherman. The boat had passed its annual inspection two months earlier. Boats don't just sink in calm water. The captain says he 'noticed water in the bilge and couldn't find the source.' That's textbook.
outcomes.feedback: Conditions that rule out accident. But you need proof of deliberate scuttling.
outcomes.note: Calm water, passed inspection, textbook 'mystery leak' claim

direct.q1_response: Filed Wednesday November 6th. Approved Friday November 8th. 285,000 kronor. Authorized by my regional manager in Göteborg. No investigation, no site visit, no salvage report required. I was told the file was 'handled.'
direct.expression_hint: Precise, professional, angry
direct.q1_note: 285k paid in 2 days, no investigation required, file 'handled'

q2_options.text: Is there a salvage report at all? Can the wreck be examined?
Who is Svensson? Is he connected to anyone at the harbor?
Can you provide copies of the claim documents?

outcomes.response: No salvage report was ordered. The wreck is at the bottom of the harbor basin near pier 5. Nobody has gone down to look at it. The company said 'the policyholder's account is sufficient.' That's never sufficient.
outcomes.feedback: No salvage. No investigation. Wreck accessible but unexamined. The company accepted the claim at face value.
outcomes.note: No salvage report, wreck at pier 5, company accepted claim at face value

outcomes.response: Svensson. Karl Svensson. He's on the harbor advisory board. Sits next to Lindqvist at every meeting. They go fishing together — or they used to, before the boat conveniently sank.
outcomes.feedback: Svensson is on the harbor advisory board with Lindqvist. Personal connection. Corruption indicator.
outcomes.note: Karl Svensson on harbor advisory board, fishing buddies with Lindqvist

outcomes.response: I have copies. The original claim form, the payout authorization, and the phone log showing the harbor authority call. If this goes to court, my career is over. But someone needs to see these.
outcomes.feedback: Complete document package including phone logs. Physical evidence of interference in a fraud case.
outcomes.note: Copies of claim form, payout authorization, and phone log

pressure.q1_response: That's what I think, yes. But 'think' isn't enough in my business. You need the boat. You need a diver to look at the hull. And my company has decided not to look.
pressure.q1_note: Believes deliberate sinking but needs hull evidence

q2_options.text: Why is your company choosing not to investigate?
What would a diver find on the hull if it was scuttled?
Is someone at the insurance company part of this?

outcomes.response: Because 285,000 isn't worth the legal fight. That's what my manager said. 'It's cheaper to pay than to investigate.' But it's not just one claim. I checked the archives. Three boats insured through our Kuststad branch have sunk in the last eighteen months. All paid out fast. All Lindqvist's circle.
outcomes.feedback: Three suspicious sinkings in 18 months. All fast payouts. All connected to Lindqvist. Serial insurance fraud.
outcomes.note: Three boats sunk in 18 months, all fast payouts, all Lindqvist's circle

outcomes.response: Open seacocks. Drilled holes below the waterline. Removed bilge plugs. A scuttled boat looks different from an accidental sinking. The damage pattern tells the story. But only if someone dives down.
outcomes.feedback: Technical expertise on how to identify scuttling. But the wreck needs examination.
outcomes.note: Open seacocks, drilled holes, or removed bilge plugs would prove scuttling

outcomes.response: Part of it? No. My company is just lazy. They get a call from someone important, they take the path of least resistance. It's not conspiracy, it's cowardice.
outcomes.feedback: She got defensive about her company. Push on the external connections instead.
outcomes.note: Company is cowardly, not complicit

silence.q1_response: *opens the folder, then closes it again* ...In twenty years, I've never seen a claim move this fast. I've seen fires, collisions, storms. Everything takes time. This took two days. That's not efficiency. That's pressure.
silence.expression_hint: Folder on the table, undecided
silence.q1_note: Twenty years experience — this is unprecedented speed

q2_options.text: Where is the pressure coming from?
What's in that folder?
What happens if you give me those documents?

outcomes.response: Higher up. My manager got a call. He won't tell me from whom. But he was shaken afterward. Someone with authority leaned on him.
outcomes.feedback: Pressure from above. Don't know the source specifically.
outcomes.note: Manager was shaken after a call from someone with authority

outcomes.response: *opens it* The claim form. The phone log showing an eight-minute call from the Kuststad harbor authority. And something I found this morning — the same insurance broker who wrote this policy wrote the other three suspicious policies. All Kuststad boats. All Lindqvist's contacts. The broker's name is Lindqvist. Anna Lindqvist. His daughter.
outcomes.feedback: Lindqvist's daughter is the insurance broker writing policies for boats that conveniently sink. Family network running a systematic insurance fraud operation.
outcomes.note: Lindqvist's daughter is the insurance broker for all four suspicious policies

outcomes.response: I'll probably lose my job. But you know what? I checked this morning. Three other claims — same pattern. Fast payouts, no investigation. Boats owned by people in Lindqvist's harbor advisory circle. This isn't one bad claim. It's a system.
outcomes.feedback: Three more claims with the same pattern. All harbor advisory circle. Systematic insurance fraud.
outcomes.note: Three more fast-paid claims from Lindqvist's advisory circle

title: The Weather Report
description: The weather station operator says the harbor authority is altering her storm warnings before publishing them.
lead_text: I sent a gale warning at 14:00. By the time the harbor office posted it, it said 'moderate wind.' Three boats went out. Two almost didn't come back.
preview: A hand-delivered note on official weather service letterhead, sealed.

interview.opening_line: My reports go from my station to the harbor master's office, and from there to the notice board and the radio. What arrives on the board is not what I sent.

q1_options.text: That's alarming, Gunvor. How did you first notice the changes?
Do you have copies of what you sent versus what was posted?
Is the harbor master downgrading storm warnings to keep cargo ships on schedule?

friendly.q1_response: Stig Petersson — the fishing captain — came to me after a rough day. He said, 'Your forecast said moderate winds.' I said, 'No, Stig, I sent a gale warning.' We compared notes. His notice board said 'moderate.' My carbon copy said 'gale force 8.'
friendly.expression_hint: Adjusting her glasses, precise and frustrated
friendly.q1_note: Gale force 8 changed to 'moderate' between station and notice board

q2_options.text: How many times has this happened?
Who changes the reports between your station and the notice board?
Were the fishermen endangered by the downgraded warning?

outcomes.response: I've confirmed seven alterations since September. I started keeping carbon copies of every report. Each time, the harbor board shows a lower wind speed or 'improved conditions' that don't match my data.
outcomes.feedback: Seven confirmed alterations with carbon copies as evidence. Systematic falsification of weather data.
outcomes.note: Seven altered reports since September, carbon copies preserved

outcomes.response: Only the harbor master's office has access to the notice board. My reports go by phone and sealed envelope. Someone at that office is changing them before posting.
outcomes.feedback: Chain of custody clear — alterations happen at the harbor office. But no proof of who specifically.
outcomes.note: Only harbor office accesses the notice board

outcomes.response: Stig's trawler took waves over the bow. He said he wouldn't have gone out if he'd known it was force 8. His crew was terrified. This isn't bureaucracy — it's endangering lives.
outcomes.feedback: Direct endangerment. Fishermen making decisions based on falsified data. But you need the why.
outcomes.note: Fishermen endangered by downgraded warnings

direct.q1_response: Yes. Here. *hands over a folder* Seven pairs. My original carbon on the left. Photograph of the harbor notice board on the right. Date-stamped. Wind speeds altered. Storm warnings downgraded. Every single one.
direct.expression_hint: Folder organized meticulously, color-coded
direct.q1_note: Seven pairs of evidence: carbon copies vs photographs of altered notices

q2_options.text: This is remarkable evidence, Gunvor. Can I keep copies?
Is there a pattern to when the alterations happen?
What weather data do cargo ships use to decide on harbour entry?

outcomes.response: Keep the folder. I have duplicates at home and I've sent one to the Swedish Meteorological and Hydrological Institute. They haven't responded yet. But the chain is documented.
outcomes.feedback: Full evidence package. Backup copies distributed. Professional-grade documentation.
outcomes.note: Evidence folder provided, duplicates at home and with SMHI

outcomes.response: Always on cargo days. When NordSjö or another big ship is scheduled. If I send a storm warning, the notice board shows 'moderate.' The cargo ships need calm conditions or they pay demurrage — waiting fees. Someone is sacrificing safety for shipping schedules.
outcomes.feedback: Alterations correlated with cargo ship schedules. Motive is demurrage costs. Financial incentive to falsify weather data.
outcomes.note: Alterations happen on cargo days — avoids demurrage fees

outcomes.response: The harbor notice board is one source. Captains also call the harbor office directly. If the office is giving false information verbally too, there's no record. Just my word against theirs.
outcomes.feedback: Verbal weather information may also be falsified. Harder to prove.
outcomes.note: Verbal weather data to captains may also be false

pressure.q1_response: That's exactly what I think. A gale warning means ships can't enter the channel safely. That costs the shipping companies money — and it costs Lindqvist his harbor fees. So the storm becomes 'moderate wind' and the ships come in anyway.
pressure.q1_note: Motive: harbor fees and shipping schedule profitability

q2_options.text: How much money is at stake when a cargo ship is delayed?
Has a ship entered the harbor in conditions your data said were dangerous?
Could Lindqvist face criminal charges for falsifying weather warnings?

outcomes.response: A day of demurrage for a medium cargo vessel is maybe 15,000 kronor. The harbor fee for entry is around 8,000. So every ship that comes in instead of waiting saves the system 23,000 kronor. Seven altered reports. That's over 160,000.
outcomes.feedback: Financial math: 23,000 per ship, 160,000+ total. But this is estimation, not evidence of payment.
outcomes.note: ~23,000 kr per ship saved, 160,000+ total from seven alterations

outcomes.response: November 12th. I sent force 9 — near storm conditions. The board said force 6. The NordSjö container ship entered the channel anyway. It hit the breakwater wall. Minor damage — this time. The incident report? Lindqvist wrote it himself. 'Unexpected local gusts.' It wasn't unexpected. I forecasted it eight hours before.
outcomes.feedback: Ship hit the breakwater because of a downgraded warning. Lindqvist wrote a false incident report. You have the original forecast that proves he knew.
outcomes.note: NordSjö ship hit breakwater after warning downgraded from force 9 to 6

outcomes.response: Under maritime law, falsifying safety information is a criminal offense. But who investigates? The maritime authority trusts the harbor master. My complaint would go to the same system that altered the data.
outcomes.feedback: Legal framework exists but enforcement is circular. The system protects itself.
outcomes.note: Criminal offense but investigation goes through the same system

silence.q1_response: *looks out at the sky* ...I've been reading weather for this coast for eighteen years. I know what force 8 looks like. I know what it sounds like, what the barometer does. And I know what I send. It's being changed.
silence.expression_hint: Calm certainty of someone who trusts her data
silence.q1_note: Eighteen years of experience, complete confidence in her data

q2_options.text: What keeps you doing this job when your reports are being ignored?
Has anyone else noticed the discrepancies?
What would happen if you went public with your evidence?

outcomes.response: Because the day I stop sending accurate reports is the day someone dies. I can't control what they do with my data. But I can control what I send.
outcomes.feedback: Powerful professional ethics. Good for character portrait but not investigation.
outcomes.note: 'The day I stop, someone dies'

outcomes.response: The Swedish Meteorological Institute contacted me last week. They noticed discrepancies between my filed reports and the harbor's published data. They're starting an inquiry. But it's slow. Government pace.
outcomes.feedback: SMHI has noticed and started an inquiry. External validation of the discrepancies. Authoritative source.
outcomes.note: SMHI noticed discrepancies, starting an inquiry

outcomes.response: I'd probably lose my station. Lindqvist controls the harbor infrastructure including my tower. He could shut me down for 'facility maintenance' and delay the reopening for months. He's done it to the lighthouse keeper already.
outcomes.feedback: Lindqvist uses infrastructure control to silence people. Pattern across multiple harbor staff.
outcomes.note: Lindqvist could shut her station for 'maintenance' — same pattern as lighthouse

title: The Processing Plant
description: Workers at the fish processing plant are getting sick. The ventilation hasn't worked in months and toxic fumes are building up.
lead_text: Three women went to the hospital last week. Breathing problems. The factory owner says it's a cold going around. It's not a cold.
preview: A typed letter from an anonymous plant worker, mailed to the office.

interview.opening_line: I've worked at Kustfisk AB for six years. I can taste chemicals when I breathe. Three of us were hospitalized. The owner says we're 'sensitive.' We're poisoned.

q1_options.text: I'm sorry to hear that, Katarina. What chemicals are you exposed to?
When did the ventilation stop working, and who is responsible for maintaining it?
Has the plant owner been hiding health violations from the work safety inspectors?

friendly.q1_response: Formaldehyde. It's in the preservative solution. When the ventilation works, it's manageable. When it doesn't, the fumes accumulate. You can feel your eyes burning after twenty minutes. After an hour, your throat closes.
friendly.expression_hint: Coughing lightly, covering her mouth
friendly.q1_note: Formaldehyde fumes from preservative, ventilation failure

q2_options.text: How long has the ventilation been broken?
What did the hospital say about the workers who were admitted?
How are the other workers coping?

outcomes.response: Since August. The fan motor burned out. The owner, Sandström, was told the replacement costs 12,000 kronor. He said 'open a window.' We're processing fish in November. With windows open. In a building designed for closed-air circulation.
outcomes.feedback: Three months without ventilation. Owner refused a 12,000 kr repair. Specific, documented negligence.
outcomes.note: Ventilation broken since August, owner refused 12,000 kr repair

outcomes.response: Chemical respiratory irritation. All three. The doctor wrote 'workplace exposure suspected' on the discharge notes. Sandström told us not to show those to anyone.
outcomes.feedback: Medical documentation implicating workplace. Owner trying to suppress evidence.
outcomes.note: Hospital notes say 'workplace exposure suspected' — owner suppressing

outcomes.response: Some bring wet rags to breathe through. Others hold their breath during the worst tasks. Two women quit. They couldn't afford to, but they couldn't breathe either. That's how bad it is.
outcomes.feedback: Workers improvising protection. Two quit. Clear health crisis.
outcomes.note: Workers use wet rags, two quit

direct.q1_response: Fan motor died August 15th. I know because I wrote the maintenance request. The owner, Sandström, is responsible — it's his building, his equipment. The request came back with 'pending' stamped on it. Still pending.
direct.expression_hint: Pulls out a stamped form
direct.q1_note: August 15th — maintenance request returned 'pending'

q2_options.text: Do you have that maintenance request? Can I see it?
Has the workplace safety authority inspected the plant?
Are there legal limits for formaldehyde exposure in a workplace?

outcomes.response: Here. Dated August 15th. 'Ventilation fan motor replacement — URGENT.' Stamped 'pending' by Sandström's office. It's been three months of 'pending.'
outcomes.feedback: Dated form proving three months of ignored urgent request. But you need the health measurement data.
outcomes.note: Dated maintenance request, three months unanswered

outcomes.response: They were supposed to come in October. Sandström called and rescheduled. Said 'seasonal production demands.' The inspector didn't push back. Next available date: February. By then we'll all be sick.
outcomes.feedback: Inspection postponed at the owner's request. Inspector complied. Regulatory failure.
outcomes.note: Inspection postponed from October to February at owner's request

outcomes.response: Yes. The workplace exposure limit is 0.5 ppm for an eight-hour shift. I borrowed a testing kit from the chemistry teacher at the school. Our air measured 2.3 ppm. Nearly five times the legal limit.
outcomes.feedback: DIY air quality test: 2.3 ppm vs 0.5 limit — nearly five times over. That's criminal negligence.
outcomes.note: Air test: 2.3 ppm formaldehyde vs 0.5 legal limit

pressure.q1_response: Hiding? He cancelled the inspection! Called the safety authority and said October was 'inconvenient.' They believed him. Or they didn't care. Same result.
pressure.q1_note: Owner cancelled the safety inspection

q2_options.text: Can you prove the inspection was cancelled at his request?
What would the inspectors have found if they'd come in October?
Is Sandström connected to anyone who could protect him from consequences?

outcomes.response: I have the original inspection notice that came to the plant in September. It was posted on the break room wall, then removed the next day. I took a photograph before it was taken down.
outcomes.feedback: Photograph of removed inspection notice. Evidence of concealment attempts.
outcomes.note: Photographed inspection notice that was removed from break room

outcomes.response: Broken ventilation. Chemical fumes five times the legal limit. Three hospitalizations. Incomplete first aid logs — he tears out pages when incidents happen. I've seen him do it.
outcomes.feedback: First aid log manipulation. Destruction of workplace injury records. Criminal offense.
outcomes.note: Sandström tears pages from first aid log after incidents

outcomes.response: *pauses* His cousin is on the town council. Hans Granlund. The one who oversees municipal business permits. When workers complain, Sandström says 'I'll call Hans.' And things go quiet. Every time.
outcomes.feedback: Town council member is the owner's cousin. Controls business permits. Threats of political protection used to silence workers.
outcomes.note: Sandström's cousin Hans Granlund on town council — controls business permits

silence.q1_response: *coughs into her sleeve* ...Sorry. That's... that's from six years of breathing that air. My lungs aren't what they were. And I'm thirty-four.

outcomes.feedback: 72% lung capacity at 34. Chronic damage from occupational exposure. Powerful but you need the institutional failure.

outcomes.response: Because it's the only factory in town. The fish plant or nothing. Twenty-two women work there. Most of us are sole earners. We can't strike, we can't quit. He knows that.

Cash payments of 5,000 kronor each with a signature that says 'the worker acknowledges no workplace fault.' He bought their silence. I didn't sign. That's why I'm here.

title: The Teen Deckhand
description: A 16-year-old dock worker discovered something odd about the nighttime cargo operations. Now he's been threatened.
lead_text: They told me to stop asking questions. I'm sixteen. I just wanted to know why the vans come at 2 AM when nobody is supposed to be working.
preview: A boy, almost a man, fidgeting on the bench outside your office.

interview.opening_line: I work weekends at the dock. Mostly cleaning, coiling rope. Last week I stayed late to finish up and I saw... things. Now someone slashed my bicycle tires and left a note in my locker.

q1_options.text: That sounds scary, Joakim. Tell me what happened, take your time.
What did you see, and what did the note say?
Are the people who threatened you the same ones running the nighttime operations?

friendly.q1_response: I was coiling rope at pier 4 around nine o'clock. Dark already. I heard an engine — not a boat, a van. A panel van backed up to the loading ramp by pier 7. Two men started unloading crates. I watched from behind the rope locker.
friendly.expression_hint: Picking at his nails, nervous energy
friendly.q1_note: Panel van at pier 7, two men unloading crates at 9 PM

q2_options.text: Could you describe the van or the men?
What happened after they saw you?
Where were the crates taken?

outcomes.response: White van, no markings. The men wore dark clothes, work boots. One of them was big — really big. The other was shorter, smoked constantly. Couldn't see faces. Too dark.
outcomes.feedback: Descriptions but no ID. Common van, dark clothing. Enough for a witness sketch but nothing identifiable.
outcomes.note: White unmarked van, big man + shorter smoker

outcomes.response: They didn't see me that night. But the next morning, my locker — the one only the dock staff can access — had a note in it. Handwritten: 'Curiosity gets boys fired.' My bike tires were slashed in the rack outside.
outcomes.feedback: Access to the dock lockers means the threat came from inside. Someone who works at the harbor knows what he saw.
outcomes.note: Threat note in dock-staff-only locker, bike tires slashed

outcomes.response: Into the tunnel entrance. The coal cellar door at the old warehouse. They propped it open and carried the crates inside. Six trips. Then the van left and the door was locked.
outcomes.feedback: Crates going into the smuggling tunnels. Confirms the route. But you had the tunnel story already.
outcomes.note: Crates carried into coal cellar tunnel entrance

direct.q1_response: Two men, white van, pier 7. Unloading crates through the coal cellar door. Nine PM last Thursday. The note in my locker on Friday said 'Curiosity gets boys fired.' Someone slashed my tires.
direct.expression_hint: Straight-backed, trying to be brave
direct.q1_note: Thursday 9 PM pier 7, note on Friday, tires slashed

q2_options.text: Do you still have the note? Can I see it?
Who knew you were at the dock late that night?
Have you told your parents or the police?

outcomes.response: Here. *hands over a folded piece of paper* 'Curiosity gets boys fired.' Written in black marker on a dock receipt form. The kind only the harbor office uses.
outcomes.feedback: Threat written on harbor office stationery. The threat came from inside the harbor authority.
outcomes.note: Threat on harbor office dock receipt form

outcomes.response: That's what scares me. I didn't tell anyone I stayed late. I just... did. Which means either they saw me and I didn't know, or someone checked the security log. The gate card system records entry and exit times.
outcomes.feedback: Gate card access logs could identify who was there. But they also identified Joakim. Someone with system access found him.
outcomes.note: Gate card system logged his presence — someone with system access found him

outcomes.response: My mum would pull me out of the dock job. I need the money. And the police... in this town? Lindqvist puts on the awards dinner for the police chief every year. They're friends.
outcomes.feedback: Can't go to police because of Lindqvist connection. Economic need keeps him working at the docks.
outcomes.note: Police chief and Lindqvist are friends, can't report

pressure.q1_response: I don't know who threatened me. That's the point — I don't know who at the dock to trust. If it's the guys running the night operation, they work here in the day. They're around me.
pressure.q1_note: Night operators are likely day dock workers — surrounded by them

q2_options.text: Have you noticed anyone at the dock acting differently toward you since that night?
Could the harbor master be involved in the nighttime operations?
Are you safe? Do you need help?

outcomes.response: Lars. One of the senior dock workers. He never talked to me before. On Friday he put his hand on my shoulder and said, 'You're a smart kid, Joakim. Smart kids know when to look away.' It didn't feel like advice. It felt like a message.
outcomes.feedback: Senior dock worker delivered a verbal warning. Named individual connected to the operation or relaying for someone.
outcomes.note: Senior dock worker Lars told him to 'look away'

outcomes.response: The harbor master? I don't know. But the gate card system, the locker access, the dock receipt paper — those all come from the harbor office. Draw your own line.
outcomes.feedback: Circumstantial but logical. Harbor office resources used for the threat.
outcomes.note: All threat infrastructure (gate card, lockers, forms) is harbor office

outcomes.response: I'm okay. Just... watching my back. I come in during the day now. Never alone. And I don't go near pier 7. But I can't keep this up forever.
outcomes.feedback: He's scared and managing it. But no new information.
outcomes.note: Avoiding pier 7, only working daytime, never alone

silence.q1_response: *fidgets, looks at his shoes* ...I'm sixteen. I just wanted a weekend job to save for a moped. I didn't ask to see any of this.

outcomes.feedback: Bertil sent him. The old smuggler is protecting the boy by directing him to the press. Connection established.

outcomes.response: The loading manifests don't match. I know because I help file them. Friday morning, I counted twelve crates unloaded from the NordSjö ship. The manifest said eight. I mentioned it to the foreman. He said 'you miscounted.' I didn't.
outcomes.feedback: Manifest discrepancy — 12 crates vs 8 documented. The boy caught the phantom cargo. That's the paper trail.

outcomes.feedback: Photographs of the van, the men, and the license plate. Physical evidence from a teenage witness. This is brave and dangerous.
