title: The Marine Biologist
description: A marine biologist studying harbor pollution has been denied access to the harbor by the harbor authority.
lead_text: The herring stocks are declining and nobody wants to know why. My water samples show elevated mercury. The harbor master revoked my research permit.
preview: A letter from Lund University's marine biology department, requesting a meeting.

interview.opening_line: I've been studying the harbor basin ecology for my doctoral research. My permit was revoked after I shared preliminary results with the county. Someone doesn't want this data public.

q1_options.text: That must be frustrating for your research. What did your data show?
Who revoked your permit? And what specifically is in the water?
Is the harbor authority trying to suppress evidence of industrial pollution?

friendly.q1_response: Mercury levels in the harbor sediment are three times above the safe threshold. That's not from fishing boats. That's industrial contamination. Something is leaching into the basin from the harbor infrastructure or from vessels that dock here.
friendly.expression_hint: Opens a laptop with bar graphs and data tables
friendly.q1_note: Mercury three times safe threshold — industrial contamination

q2_options.text: What could be the source of the mercury?
What does mercury contamination mean for the fishing industry?
How solid is your data?

outcomes.response: I traced the highest concentrations to the sediment near pier 7. The readings get worse the closer you sample to the pier foundations. Something there — or under there — is leaching mercury into the water.
outcomes.feedback: Pier 7 is the epicenter. Scientific data pointing to the same pier that keeps appearing in smuggling stories.
outcomes.note: Highest mercury concentrations at pier 7 foundations

outcomes.response: At these levels, bioaccumulation in fish tissue is certain. Herring ingest contaminated plankton. The mercury concentrates up the food chain. Anyone eating Kuststad herring regularly is at risk.
outcomes.feedback: Public health implications are severe. But you need the source, not just the impact.
outcomes.note: Herring bioaccumulation — public health risk

outcomes.response: Eighteen months of sampling. 47 collection points. Lab-verified at Lund University. This isn't amateur work — it's peer-reviewable science. And they shut me down because they don't like the results.
outcomes.feedback: Rigorous methodology but the story is about why they shut her down, not just that they did.
outcomes.note: 18 months, 47 points, lab-verified at Lund

direct.q1_response: Axel Lindqvist. The harbor master. My permit was issued by the county. But Lindqvist controls physical site access. He changed the gate codes and told the dock staff I was 'not authorized to enter harbor premises.' Letter dated November 12th.
direct.expression_hint: Holds up the letter, precise and calm
direct.q1_note: Lindqvist revoked physical access via gate code change, November 12th

q2_options.text: Do you have that letter? What reason did he give?
What were the specific results that triggered the ban?
Can the county overrule Lindqvist's access restriction?

outcomes.response: Here. 'Dear Dr. Lind, due to upcoming infrastructure works, research access to harbor premises is suspended until further notice.' No end date. No specific infrastructure works. Just a door slammed shut.
outcomes.feedback: Vague excuse. No timeline. Transparent suppression but packaged as routine.
outcomes.note: Ban letter cites 'infrastructure works' — no specifics

outcomes.response: I sent the county a preliminary report on October 28th. Mercury data. Location maps. My hypothesis about pier 7 as the likely source zone. Lindqvist's letter arrived two weeks later. Someone at the county tipped him off.
outcomes.feedback: Timeline: report to county → two weeks → access revoked. Information leak from county to harbor master.
outcomes.note: County received report Oct 28, access revoked Nov 12 — information leak

outcomes.response: In theory, yes. My county permit is still valid. But Lindqvist controls the physical gates. I tried going through the county but they said 'we'll look into it.' That was two weeks ago.
outcomes.feedback: County won't enforce its own permit. Institutional paralysis.
outcomes.note: County permit valid but county won't enforce access

pressure.q1_response: Suppress? They're actively obstructing scientific research to protect the harbor's reputation. Or to protect something at pier 7. Mercury doesn't appear from nowhere. Something is wrong at that pier.
pressure.q1_note: Active obstruction of science — pier 7 is the key

q2_options.text: What could be at pier 7 that produces mercury contamination?
Have you encountered obstruction like this at other research sites?
Is someone besides Lindqvist involved in blocking your research?

outcomes.response: I've been thinking about that. Mercury in harbor sediment can come from old industrial waste, ship paint, or stored chemicals. Remember the dredging operation in August? If they disturbed old industrial deposits — or worse, dumped contaminated material — that would explain both the timeline and the location.
outcomes.feedback: The August dredging disturbed or dumped contaminated material near pier 7. That connects to the fishermen's torn nets AND the chemical barrels. Everything converges on pier 7.
outcomes.note: August dredging may have disturbed or dumped industrial waste at pier 7

outcomes.response: Never. In ten years of research. This is the first time a local authority has revoked access. It's extraordinary. My professor at Lund called it 'unprecedented obstruction.'
outcomes.feedback: Unprecedented action flagged by the university. Unusual response implies something to hide.
outcomes.note: Lund professor called it 'unprecedented obstruction'

outcomes.response: The NordSjö shipping company sent a legal letter to my university. 'Cease and desist from publishing data that could harm the commercial reputation of Kuststad harbor.' They didn't threaten me — they threatened my university's industry partnerships.
outcomes.feedback: NordSjö using legal intimidation against the university. Corporate power used to suppress science.
outcomes.note: NordSjö sent cease-and-desist to Lund University

silence.q1_response: *stares at her data printouts* ...I became a marine biologist because I love the sea. And now I'm finding poison in a harbor where people catch fish that families eat.
silence.expression_hint: Printouts spread on the table, weight of responsibility
silence.q1_note: Personal mission — love of the sea, responsibility to the community

q2_options.text: What do people in Kuststad need to know?
What happens to your research now that you can't access the site?
Is there another way to get the data you need?

outcomes.response: They need to know that the fish in their harbor may not be safe to eat. That the herring they sell at the market swam in mercury-contaminated water. And that the people who are supposed to protect them are hiding the evidence.
outcomes.feedback: Public statement. Good for the article's weight but not new evidence.
outcomes.note: Fish may be unsafe — authorities hiding evidence

outcomes.response: I can publish what I have. Eighteen months of data. The university ethics board cleared me. But without current samples, I can't show whether the contamination is getting worse — which it almost certainly is.
outcomes.feedback: Publication possible with existing data. But the obstruction prevents monitoring escalation.
outcomes.note: 18 months of data publishable, can't monitor escalation

outcomes.response: There might be. Stig Petersson — the fishing captain — offered to take samples for me from his trawler. His boat passes through the sampling zone every day. If I give him collection kits, the harbor master can't stop a fisherman from fishing.
outcomes.feedback: Fisherman can collect samples the scientist can't. Collaboration that outflanks the harbor authority's access control.
outcomes.note: Stig Petersson will collect samples from his trawler

title: The Customs Man
description: A customs inspector was transferred out of Kuststad after filing a report about cargo irregularities. He wants to talk before he leaves.
lead_text: I'm being moved to Norrköping. Promotion, they call it. It's not a promotion. It's punishment for doing my job.
preview: A phone call from a man who said he was leaving town and needed to talk first.

interview.opening_line: I've been Kuststad's customs inspector for eleven years. Next week I'm in Norrköping. That transfer came three days after I filed a cargo discrepancy report. Coincidence? I don't think so.

q1_options.text: Eleven years is a long time. What was in the report that caused your transfer?
What discrepancy did you find? And who ordered your transfer?
Were you transferred because you caught someone important stealing cargo?

friendly.q1_response: I noticed a pattern. NordSjö ships consistently unload more containers than the manifest states. Sometimes two extra, sometimes five. The surplus never appears on any receipt. I documented eleven instances over four months.
friendly.expression_hint: Turning his coffee cup slowly, methodical
friendly.q1_note: Eleven instances of excess cargo over 4 months on NordSjö ships

q2_options.text: What happens to the phantom containers?
Who did you report this to?
What's in the extra containers?

outcomes.response: They're moved to pier 7. The 'closed' pier. At night. I've never been able to inspect one — by the time I get there in the morning, they're gone. Someone is moving them inland before customs hours.
outcomes.feedback: Phantom containers moved to pier 7 at night, gone before morning. Systematic customs evasion.
outcomes.note: Phantom containers moved to pier 7, gone before morning inspection

outcomes.response: My regional director in Stockholm. Standard Form 47-C. He acknowledged receipt. Three days later, I got the transfer order. Same director signed it.
outcomes.feedback: Same person received the report and ordered the transfer. Retaliatory transfer confirmed.
outcomes.note: Regional director acknowledged discrepancy report then signed transfer

outcomes.response: I never got to open one. That's the point. They arrive at night, they're moved at night, and by morning it's as if they never existed. Could be electronics, could be alcohol, could be anything. The not-knowing is the weapon.
outcomes.feedback: Contents unknown. The avoidance of inspection is the evidence itself.
outcomes.note: Contents unknown — never inspected

direct.q1_response: Over four months, eleven NordSjö cargo runs showed between two and five extra containers above the declared manifest. Total: 38 undocumented containers. I filed Form 47-C with my regional director. Transfer order came three days later.
direct.expression_hint: Papers arranged on the table in order
direct.q1_note: 38 undocumented containers in 4 months, transfer after reporting

q2_options.text: Do you have copies of the manifest comparisons?
Who has the authority to transfer an inspector over a discrepancy report?
Was anyone from the Kuststad harbor involved in the transfer decision?

outcomes.response: All eleven reports. Carbon copies of each manifest alongside my count sheet. Time-stamped. Some with photographs from the inspection dock. Thirty-eight containers that don't exist on paper but were physically there.
outcomes.feedback: Eleven manifest comparisons with time-stamps and photographs. Iron-clad documentary evidence of cargo smuggling.
outcomes.note: 11 manifest reports with photos — 38 ghost containers

outcomes.response: Only my regional director has that authority. But here's the thing — I called his secretary. She said the transfer was 'requested by local authority.' That means someone in Kuststad asked Stockholm to move me. Only one local authority interfaces with customs: the harbor master.
outcomes.feedback: Harbor master requested the transfer through official channels. Direct proof of retaliation for the cargo report.
outcomes.note: Transfer 'requested by local authority' — harbor master

outcomes.response: That's what I want to know. The transfer paperwork just says 'operational needs.' But eleven years in one post and suddenly operational needs require me in Norrköping? The timing speaks for itself.
outcomes.feedback: Circumstantial timing evidence. The specific channel was covered in the other questions.
outcomes.note: 'Operational needs' — suspicious timing

pressure.q1_response: Not stealing. Smuggling. Bringing cargo into the country without customs inspection. Thirty-eight containers in four months. Whatever NordSjö is bringing through Kuststad, they don't want anyone counting it.
pressure.q1_note: Smuggling, not theft — NordSjö bypassing customs

q2_options.text: Is the harbor master complicit in the customs evasion?
How much revenue is the state losing from 38 uninspected containers?
Will you testify about this if it goes to court?

outcomes.response: He controls the pier assignments. He decides which ships go to which dock. NordSjö always gets pier 7. The 'closed' pier. Closed to everyone — except NordSjö. Lindqvist isn't passive. He's directing traffic.
outcomes.feedback: Harbor master actively assigns NordSjö to the restricted pier. He's part of the logistics chain.
outcomes.note: Lindqvist assigns NordSjö to pier 7 exclusively — active participation

outcomes.response: Depends on what's inside. Alcohol duty alone — if those containers held spirits — would be hundreds of thousands. Electronics, textiles, pharmaceuticals — each has its own tariff rate. The state is losing money and my bosses don't want to know.
outcomes.feedback: Scale of tax evasion estimated but unknown. Depends on contents.
outcomes.note: Potential hundreds of thousands in lost tariffs

outcomes.response: Court? You think this goes to court? My own director got rid of me for finding it. The system protects itself. I'm not naive enough to think justice works that way.
outcomes.feedback: Cynicism about the system. Pushed too far into institutional critique — lost the cooperating witness tone.
outcomes.note: Shut down on court testimony

silence.q1_response: *stirs his coffee, doesn't drink* ...Eleven years I did this job honestly. Checked every manifest. Counted every container. And the one time I find something real, they ship me out like I'm the problem.
silence.expression_hint: Resignation mixed with stubborn anger
silence.q1_note: Eleven years honest work, punished for doing his job

q2_options.text: What do you want people to know before you leave?
What will happen to Kuststad's customs after you're gone?
What can't you bring yourself to say out loud?

outcomes.response: That this harbor is crooked. That the containers nobody counts are making someone very rich. And that the people who should be stopping it are the ones enabling it.
outcomes.feedback: A summary accusation. Good for a closing quote. Not evidence.
outcomes.note: Harbor is crooked — enablers at the top

outcomes.response: My replacement is a junior officer. Two years experience. He'll count what they tell him to count and sign what they tell him to sign. By the time he understands what's happening, the operation will be entrenched. That's the plan.
outcomes.feedback: Replacement is a compliant junior. Capturing customs for the long term. Strategic institutional degradation.
outcomes.note: Junior replacement — strategic institutional weakening

outcomes.response: *very quiet* The thirty-eighth container. It had diplomatic seals. That means I can't open it, nobody can. But diplomatic cargo through a commercial harbor? That's only legal if a government agency authorized it. And no Swedish agency did. Someone is using diplomatic cover to move cargo through Kuststad without any possible inspection.
outcomes.feedback: Diplomatic seals on commercial cargo. Uninspectable by law. No Swedish authorization. This is state-level smuggling infrastructure.
outcomes.note: Container with unauthorized diplomatic seals — uninspectable

title: The Fisherman's Wife
description: A fisherman's wife discovered that the harbor's emergency fund, meant for fishing families in crisis, has barely been disbursed.
lead_text: We applied for emergency support after Erik's boat was damaged. The fund has 180,000 kronor. Our application was denied. We checked — nobody's been approved in three years.
preview: A woman caught your arm at the general store, eyes red from crying.

interview.opening_line: The Kuststad Harbor Emergency Fund. 180,000 kronor sitting in an account. Supposed to help fishing families. Not one payout in three years. Where is the money going?

q1_options.text: That's terrible, Elin. What happened to your husband's boat?
How do you know the fund has 180,000 kronor? And who controls it?
Is Lindqvist using the emergency fund for something other than fishing families?

friendly.q1_response: The keel was damaged on the harbor debris — the same scrap from the dredging. Repair costs 15,000 kronor. We don't have it. Erik hasn't fished in two weeks. We heard about the fund and applied. Denied. 'Criteria not met.' What criteria?
friendly.expression_hint: Wringing her hands, coat too thin for November
friendly.q1_note: Keel damaged on harbor debris, 15,000 kr repair, fund denied — no criteria given

q2_options.text: What criteria did they say you didn't meet?
Have other fishing families applied and been denied too?

outcomes.response: Nobody knows! I asked at the harbor office for the fund criteria document. They said it was 'under revision.' I asked when it would be available. 'We'll notify you.' It's been two months. There is no criteria document. They deny everyone.
outcomes.feedback: No published criteria. 'Under revision' for two months. Means applications can be denied arbitrarily. Fund is locked.
outcomes.note: No criteria document exists — 'under revision' indefinitely

outcomes.response: At least four families. The Peterssons, the Erikssons, old Maja's family. All denied. Same letter. Same stamp. Nobody has received a single krona from that fund since Lindqvist took over three years ago.
outcomes.feedback: Four families denied. Pattern of universal rejection under current management.
outcomes.note: Four families denied, no payouts in 3 years

outcomes.response: I'm working double shifts at the processing plant. The children eat school lunches because dinner is thin. Erik sits on the pier every day looking at his broken boat. It's killing him.
outcomes.feedback: Human cost is devastating. Erik's mental health, children's nutrition. But you need the financial story.
outcomes.note: Double shifts at plant, children relying on school lunch

direct.q1_response: Public records. The fund is county-administered through the harbor authority. Annual balance sheet is a public document. I requested it at the library. 180,423 kronor as of September 30th. Zero disbursements in fiscal year 1973 or 1974.
direct.expression_hint: Pulls a folded document from her pocket
direct.q1_note: Balance sheet: 180,423 kr, zero disbursements 1973-1974

q2_options.text: Can I see that balance sheet?
Does the fund have incoming contributions? Where does the money come from?

outcomes.response: Here. Notice anything? The fund receives 20,000 kronor annually from harbor fees. Income: 20,000. Disbursements: zero. Administrative costs: 18,500. ADMINISTRATIVE COSTS? For a fund that pays out nothing? Where is 18,500 kronor of administration going?
outcomes.feedback: 18,500 kr in 'admin costs' for a fund that disburses zero. Someone is siphoning the fund through fees.
outcomes.note: 18,500 kr annual 'admin costs' on a zero-disbursement fund

outcomes.response: 20,000 kronor per year from harbor fee surcharges. Every fishing boat that uses the harbor pays into it. The fishermen fund the fund. And the fund pays no one.
outcomes.feedback: Fishermen pay into a fund that doesn't pay fishermen. Circular extraction.
outcomes.note: Fishermen pay into fund via harbor fees, get nothing back

outcomes.response: The harbor master is listed as sole administrator. No oversight committee. No board. One man decides who gets help and who doesn't. And he's decided: nobody.
outcomes.feedback: Lindqvist is sole administrator. No oversight. One-man control of the fund.
outcomes.note: Lindqvist sole administrator, no oversight committee

pressure.q1_response: I don't know what he's using it for. But I can count. 180,000 kronor that grows by 20,000 a year and pays out 18,500 in 'administration.' That money is going somewhere. It's not going to fishing families.

q2_options.text: What could 18,500 kronor of 'administration' possibly cover?
Has anyone challenged Lindqvist about the fund?

outcomes.response: I asked the county auditor. She said 'administration' for a dormant fund should be minimal — maybe 500 kronor for bank fees. 18,500? That requires an itemized breakdown. She's asked the harbor authority for one. They haven't responded.
outcomes.feedback: County auditor confirms admin costs are 37x what they should be. Formal audit requested. Documentary trail.
outcomes.note: County auditor: admin should be ~500 kr, not 18,500

outcomes.response: The fishermen's cooperative wrote to Lindqvist in August. He replied that the fund was 'operating as designed.' As designed to do what? Collect money and spend it on itself?

outcomes.response: I'm not accusing Lindqvist of theft. I'm saying the fund doesn't work. Don't put words in my mouth — I need to live in this town.
outcomes.feedback: She pulled back. Too direct on personal corruption. She lives with the consequences.

silence.q1_response: *looks down at her hands* ...Erik doesn't know I'm here. He'd say 'don't make trouble.' But trouble found us. Our nets are ruined, our boat is broken, and the fund that's supposed to help us won't give us a krona.

title: The Shipping Clerk's Ledger
description: A shipping company clerk found discrepancies between cargo manifests and actual deliveries. Someone is cooking the books.
lead_text: The numbers don't add up. We receive ten containers but the manifest says eight. The extra two go straight to warehouse 3 — no paperwork.
preview: A typed letter left in the office post box, no return address.

interview.opening_line: I've been doing the accounts for NordSjö for eleven years. The numbers always balanced. Until six months ago.

q1_options.text: Eleven years — you know those books better than anyone. What changed?
What specifically doesn't add up? Show me the discrepancies.
Is NordSjö deliberately importing undeclared cargo to avoid customs duties?

friendly.q1_response: In June, a new route opened. Baltic run — Gdańsk to Kuststad. The manifests from that route are always... light. Fewer containers listed than what actually arrives. I count them from my office window.

q2_options.text: How many extra containers are we talking about?

outcomes.feedback: Fifty undeclared containers in five months. Systematic, documented counting. Strong evidence.
outcomes.note: ~50 undeclared containers since June, 2 extra per shipment

outcomes.response: Warehouse 3. The old cold storage by the breakwater. It's supposed to be decommissioned. But trucks come at night and take things away. I've seen the lights from my window.
outcomes.feedback: Decommissioned warehouse as a staging area. Night transfers. Classic smuggling infrastructure.
outcomes.note: Warehouse 3 — decommissioned but active at night

outcomes.response: My supervisor, Göransson, handles the Baltic route personally. He told me not to reconcile those shipments. Said they're 'handled at the corporate level.' That's not how accounting works.
outcomes.feedback: Supervisor blocking reconciliation. Unusual but not proof of wrongdoing on its own.
outcomes.note: Supervisor Göransson blocks reconciliation of Baltic route

direct.q1_response: Here — I made copies. This is the manifest for October 14th. Eight containers listed. This is my count from the window: ten containers unloaded. Two went to warehouse 3 without dock receipts. I have six months of these.
direct.expression_hint: Opens a folder with photocopied documents
direct.q1_note: Six months of manifests vs actual counts — documented

q2_options.text: Can I keep these copies? This is strong documentary evidence.
What's in those extra containers? Did you ever check?
Who signs off on the manifests at the Kuststad end?

outcomes.response: Take them. I have another set at home. I also noted which customs officers were on duty each time — none of them ever inspected the Baltic ships. Every other route gets spot-checked. The Baltic route? Never.
outcomes.feedback: Documentary evidence plus customs inspection pattern. The Baltic route has special treatment.
outcomes.note: No customs inspections on Baltic route — pattern documented

outcomes.response: Once. In September. A container was left open by accident. I walked past. It was full of electronics. Sealed boxes. Brand new. No import stamps, no customs labels. That's smuggling. Duty-free smuggling through our port.
outcomes.feedback: Eyewitness account of undeclared electronics. That's not petty — duty-free electronics smuggling is organized crime.
outcomes.note: Container full of undeclared electronics — no customs labels

outcomes.response: Göransson signs the receiving documents. But the manifests come pre-signed from Gdańsk. Nobody checks if they match reality. I'm supposed to, but I was told to stop.
outcomes.feedback: Chain of paperwork that prevents verification. Designed to not be checked.
outcomes.note: Pre-signed manifests from Gdańsk, no verification

pressure.q1_response: I... can't say that on the record. I still work there. I have a daughter. But yes — something is being imported that nobody wants documented.
pressure.expression_hint: Looks at the door, clutches her folder
pressure.q1_note: Afraid but confirms undeclared imports

q2_options.text: Annika, this is bigger than one company. If goods are entering Sweden undeclared, it's a federal matter.
I'll protect your identity completely. But I need to know: who benefits from this?
What would happen if you reported this internally to NordSjö management?

outcomes.response: Federal? Then go to the federal police. I'm a clerk. I count containers and file papers. I can't fight NordSjö.
outcomes.feedback: You scared her with the scale. She's retreating to protect herself.
outcomes.note: Retreating — too much pressure

outcomes.response: *whispers* There's a man from Göteborg. Comes every two weeks. Meets with Göransson. They go to warehouse 3 together. He drives a Mercedes with dealer plates. I wrote down the plate number.
outcomes.feedback: Regular visits from a Göteborg contact. Plate number is traceable. This goes above the local level.
outcomes.note: Göteborg man visits biweekly, Mercedes dealer plates noted

outcomes.response: Report to whom? The CEO approved the Baltic route himself. The board is the Karlgren family. They own 80% of NordSjö. You don't report to the people running the operation.
outcomes.feedback: Ownership structure — Karlgren family controls NordSjö. But this is public information, not a scoop.
outcomes.note: Karlgren family owns 80% of NordSjö

silence.q1_response: *opens and closes her folder twice* ...I raised my daughter alone in this town. NordSjö is the biggest employer. If I lose this job... but I can't keep filing false accounts. My name is on those documents.
silence.expression_hint: Hands trembling slightly over the folder
silence.q1_note: Personal liability — her name on false accounts

q2_options.text: Your name on those documents — could you be held responsible?
What made you decide to come forward now, after six months?
What's in the folder, Annika?

outcomes.response: If customs ever audits, I'm the one who signed the receiving reports. Göransson told me to sign. If this blows up, I'm the fall person. Not him. Not the Karlgrens. Me.
outcomes.feedback: She's being set up as the scapegoat. Her motive for talking is self-preservation — that makes her credible.
outcomes.note: Being set up as the scapegoat for false accounts

outcomes.response: Last week, Göransson asked me to backdate three manifests. Change the dates so they wouldn't match a customs inquiry timeline. I did it. I hate myself for it. But I have a mortgage.
outcomes.feedback: Backdating documents — she's complicit now. Her fear is real and her testimony is complicated.
outcomes.note: Backdated three manifests under pressure

outcomes.response: *slides the folder across the table* Six months. Every shipment. Manifest copies, my window counts, dock photos I took with my camera, the plate number of the Göteborg car, and... a copy of an internal memo from Göransson telling the warehouse foreman to 'clear bay 3 before customs hours.' It's all here.
outcomes.feedback: The motherlode. Six months of documentary evidence plus an internal memo proving foreknowledge of customs avoidance. This is a career-ending, company-destroying package.
outcomes.note: Complete evidence folder: manifests, photos, plate number, internal memo

title: The Secretary's Silent Warning
description: The shipping magnate's secretary left a classified document in full view during an interview. It details insurance claims for ships that never sank.
lead_text: I found a document on the table after interviewing Karlgren. An insurance claim for a vessel listed as 'lost at sea.' The vessel is currently docked in Rotterdam.
preview: Sharp-eyed observation during a routine company visit.

interview.opening_line: I left that document there on purpose. I've watched this family lie and cheat for twelve years. I'm done being their filing cabinet.

q1_options.text: Twelve years is a long time to carry that. What finally made you decide?
The insurance claim — how many ships have the Karlgrens reported as lost that aren't actually gone?
Were you complicit in filing these fraudulent claims?

friendly.q1_response: Last month, old Henrik Karlgren had me type a condolence letter to a sailor's family. For a man who drowned when the MV Sigrid 'sank.' I typed it. Then I checked — the Sigrid is in dry dock in Rotterdam. The sailor is alive. Working on another vessel.
friendly.expression_hint: Perfectly composed, cold fury underneath
friendly.q1_note: Condolence letter for non-existent drowning — vessel and sailor both alive

q2_options.text: How did you verify the ship was in Rotterdam?
What happened to the insurance payout for the Sigrid?
What other documents have you seen that troubled you?

outcomes.response: I called the Rotterdam port authority. Pretended to be a shipping agent. They confirmed — MV Sigrid, registered to a company called Baltik Maritime GmbH. Same ship, different name, different flag. Reflagged and sold. While the insurance company paid out for a total loss.
outcomes.feedback: Ship reflagged and sold while insurance paid out for a 'sinking.' Classic maritime fraud, independently verified.
outcomes.note: MV Sigrid reflagged as Baltik Maritime GmbH, docked in Rotterdam

outcomes.response: 4.2 million kronor. I filed the claim myself — Karlgren dictated it. 'Total loss due to structural failure in storm conditions, November North Sea.' I have the carbon copy of the claim form with his signature.
outcomes.feedback: 4.2 million in fraudulent insurance. She has the carbon copy with Karlgren's signature. Physical evidence.
outcomes.note: 4.2 million insurance claim — carbon copy with Karlgren's signature

outcomes.response: There's a locked drawer in Karlgren's office. I've seen him put envelopes there after meetings with the insurance assessor. He has the only key. But I know where the spare is.
outcomes.feedback: Promising lead to more evidence but you'd need her to actually get the documents.
outcomes.note: Locked drawer with insurance-related envelopes

direct.q1_response: Three in the last five years. The MV Sigrid — 'sunk' in 1974. The coastal freighter Nordvåg — 'fire damage, total loss' in 1972. And a fishing vessel, the Havsbris — 'lost in storm' in 1971. Total insurance payouts: over 10 million kronor.
direct.expression_hint: Reciting from memory, secretary's precision
direct.q1_note: Three fraudulent sinkings: Sigrid, Nordvåg, Havsbris — 10 million in payouts

q2_options.text: Where are the other two ships now? Can any of them be located?
Who processed these claims? Was the insurance company in on it?
Do you have documentation for all three claims?

outcomes.response: The Sigrid is in Rotterdam — I verified it. The Nordvåg... Karlgren sold it to a Greek shipping family through an intermediary in Hamburg. I have the telex confirming the sale. Dated three weeks after the 'total loss' insurance payout. That's not incompetence. That's a crime.
outcomes.feedback: Telex confirming sale three weeks after 'total loss' payout. Documentary proof of insurance fraud on two vessels. This is a criminal case.
outcomes.note: Telex: Nordvåg sold to Greek family 3 weeks after insurance payout

outcomes.response: The insurance assessor is a man named Persson from Göteborg. He's been handling Karlgren's claims for twenty years. His reports always confirm total loss without independent survey. Draw your own conclusions.
outcomes.feedback: Complicit assessor — no independent surveys. The insurance company may be compromised too.
outcomes.note: Assessor Persson — 20 years, no independent surveys

outcomes.response: I have copies of everything I've typed in twelve years. Every letter, every claim, every memo. Filed chronologically in two boxes under my bed. If Karlgren ever threatens me, those boxes go to the police. Or to you.
outcomes.feedback: Twelve years of documentary evidence at her home. Insurance, comprehensive evidence package.
outcomes.note: Twelve years of copies in boxes at her home

pressure.q1_response: Complicit? I typed what I was told to type. I didn't design the fraud. But yes — my fingerprints are on those documents. That's why I'm here. I need this story public before Karlgren realizes his filing cabinet has a conscience.
pressure.expression_hint: Straightens her back, looks you in the eye
pressure.q1_note: Admits involvement but cooperation is self-protection

q2_options.text: If this goes public, you could face prosecution too. Are you prepared for that?
What would Karlgren do if he found out you were talking to a reporter?
Is there anyone else in the company who knows the truth?

outcomes.response: I've already spoken to a lawyer in Göteborg. She says a whistleblower who cooperates before charges are filed has protections. I'm cooperating. I'm also not stupid — I made four copies of everything.
outcomes.feedback: Legally prepared whistleblower with multiple evidence copies. She's credible precisely because she's protecting herself.
outcomes.note: Lawyer consultation, four copies of evidence

outcomes.response: Karlgren is seventy-three and he still has a temper. His son Erik is worse — cold, calculating. I've seen what they do to people who cross them. The last captain who questioned a manifest was blacklisted across every Swedish port.
outcomes.feedback: The Karlgrens retaliate against whistleblowers. Adds color but you need the documents more than the fear.
outcomes.note: Karlgren family retaliates — captain blacklisted

outcomes.response: The first mate of the Sigrid. He knows the ship didn't sink because he sailed it to Rotterdam under a false flag. But he won't talk — Karlgren pays him double salary to keep quiet.
outcomes.feedback: Another witness but an unreachable one. Double salary is a detail.
outcomes.note: Sigrid's first mate sailed it to Rotterdam — paid double to keep quiet

silence.q1_response: *smooths her skirt, looks at her clasped hands* ...You know what's funny? Henrik Karlgren writes Christmas cards to the widows. Women whose husbands 'drowned' on ships he sold. He writes them by hand. I address the envelopes.
silence.expression_hint: Perfect posture, voice like a pressed flower — flat and preserved
silence.q1_note: Christmas cards to widows of fabricated drownings

q2_options.text: How do you live with that, Margareta?
How many families has he deceived like this?
What's in the document you left for me?

outcomes.response: You don't. You file it. In your mind, in the drawer, in the boxes under your bed. And one day you walk into a newspaper office and you stop filing.
outcomes.feedback: Powerful human moment but the story needs the documents, not the emotion.
outcomes.note: Twelve years of compartmentalization ending

outcomes.response: At least six sailors were told their ships would be 'decommissioned' and they'd be transferred. Instead, the ships disappeared and the men were paid off. Three families got condolence letters for men who are alive. The lies are architectural.
outcomes.feedback: Six sailors, three fake condolence letters. The scope of the deception is institutional. 'Architectural lies' — she understands the system.
outcomes.note: Six sailors, three fake condolence letters, systematic deception

outcomes.response: The insurance claim for the MV Sigrid. 4.2 million kronor for a ship that's in Rotterdam. But that's just the top page. Underneath I left the internal accounts. The real books. They show where every payout went — Karlgren, his son Erik, Assessor Persson, and... the harbor master. Lindqvist gets 15% of every claim. He's been bribed to keep the port records clean.
outcomes.feedback: The real books. Insurance fraud connected to the harbor master. Lindqvist takes 15% of every fraudulent claim. This connects the shipping magnate to the harbor corruption you've been uncovering all week.
outcomes.note: Real books: Lindqvist gets 15% of every fraudulent insurance claim

title: The Drag-Net Boss
description: The boss of the drag-net crew claims his men are being forced to fish restricted waters to meet quotas set by the harbor authority.
lead_text: We're fishing where we shouldn't. Not because we want to — because Lindqvist says no catch, no mooring rights. It's fish or lose your berth.
preview: Angry words overheard at the harbor pub after closing time.

interview.opening_line: I've got twelve men on my crew. Every one of them has a family. Lindqvist says we fish the restricted zone or we lose our mooring rights. What would you do?

q1_options.text: That's an impossible choice, Ragnar. How long has this been going on?
Which restricted zone? And is this a verbal order or is there documentation?
You're admitting to illegal fishing. Are you willing to go on record?

friendly.q1_response: Since April. That's when the new quota system came in. Lindqvist ties your mooring rights to your catch numbers. Miss quota two months running and you're out. Berths are reassigned to 'higher-performing vessels.'
friendly.expression_hint: Big man, red-faced, controlled anger
friendly.q1_note: Quota system since April — miss twice and lose mooring rights

q2_options.text: Has anyone actually lost their mooring rights under this system?
Where is the restricted zone and why is it off-limits?
How do the other crew bosses feel about this?

outcomes.response: Old Bengtsson. Thirty years at this harbor. Missed quota in July and August — his wife was in hospital, he couldn't fish full days. Lindqvist revoked his berth in September. Gave it to a NordSjö supply vessel. A fishing berth to a cargo company.
outcomes.feedback: Berth revoked from a 30-year fisherman and given to the shipping company. That's the real game — displacing fishermen for commercial shipping.
outcomes.note: Bengtsson lost his berth after 30 years — given to NordSjö vessel

outcomes.response: The Skärgård spawning ground. Protected since 1968 for herring breeding. If we fish there, we destroy next year's stock. Lindqvist doesn't care. He needs the harbor's tonnage numbers up. It's his bonus.
outcomes.feedback: Protected spawning ground being fished to inflate harbor statistics. Environmental destruction for bureaucratic bonuses.
outcomes.note: Herring spawning ground protected since 1968 — fished for quota numbers

outcomes.response: Three of us talked about refusing together. Then Bengtsson lost his berth. Nobody talks about refusing anymore.
outcomes.feedback: Collective action crushed by example. The fear is real but this doesn't add documentary evidence.
outcomes.note: Collective refusal died when Bengtsson was made an example

direct.q1_response: The Skärgård. It's a protected herring spawning ground — off-limits since 1968. Lindqvist issued something he calls a 'supplementary fishing directive.' Typed on harbor authority letterhead. I have a copy on my boat.
direct.expression_hint: Reaches into jacket pocket, pulls out a folded paper
direct.q1_note: Skärgård spawning ground — 'supplementary fishing directive' on letterhead

q2_options.text: Can I see that directive? Does Lindqvist have the authority to override a protected zone?
How much of your catch comes from the restricted zone?
Has the county fisheries board been informed about this?

outcomes.response: Here — look at it. 'Supplementary fishing directive, by authority of the Harbor Master.' It's completely fabricated authority. Harbor masters don't control fishing zones — that's the county fisheries board. He made up a document that looks official and nobody questioned it.
outcomes.feedback: Fabricated authority document. The harbor master created a fake directive to override county-level environmental protection. That's forgery and environmental crime in one.
outcomes.note: Fabricated directive — harbor masters have no authority over fishing zones

outcomes.response: Thirty, forty percent. The open waters are fished out. The only place with decent herring stocks is the spawning ground — because nobody's supposed to fish there. We're eating the seed corn.
outcomes.feedback: Scale of the ecological damage, but you need the legal angle to make this story hit.
outcomes.note: 30-40% of catch from protected zone — depleting breeding stock

outcomes.response: Nobody told them. Lindqvist's directive says 'coordination with relevant authorities has been completed.' I called the county board myself — anonymously. They had never heard of any permission. They were furious.
outcomes.feedback: The directive claims coordination that never happened. County board unaware. You have the lie in writing.
outcomes.note: Directive claims county coordination — county says no, never happened

pressure.q1_response: I'm here, aren't I? I'm admitting it because it's wrong. Because someone has to. Because those herring won't breed next year and then we're all finished — not just my crew, every boat in this harbor.
pressure.expression_hint: Slams the table, then catches himself
pressure.q1_note: Willing to go on record — understands ecological consequences

q2_options.text: If I publish this, Lindqvist will know it was you. Your berth, your crew — everything at risk.
Is Lindqvist getting something from NordSjö in exchange for inflating the harbor's catch numbers?
Would your crew back you up if this went public?

outcomes.response: I talked to my men last night. Ten of twelve will sign a statement. Names on paper. We're done being afraid. Lindqvist can take our berths — we'll fish from the beach if we have to.
outcomes.feedback: Ten named witnesses willing to sign. That's a collective statement against institutional coercion. Very strong.
outcomes.note: Ten of twelve crew members will sign a statement

outcomes.response: The catch numbers go into the harbor's annual report. Higher tonnage means higher government infrastructure funds. Lindqvist gets a performance bonus tied to those numbers. He's destroying a spawning ground for his own salary.
outcomes.feedback: Follow the money: overfishing → inflated tonnage → government funds → harbor master's bonus. Systemic corruption with personal profit.
outcomes.note: Lindqvist's bonus tied to tonnage — inflated by illegal fishing

outcomes.response: My berth, my crew, my livelihood. I know the risk. But I also know what happens when the herring are gone. I've seen it in Norway. Dead harbors. Ghost towns. Kuststad is heading there.
outcomes.feedback: Environmental stakes with personal courage. Good human angle but you need the documents.
outcomes.note: Seen dead harbors in Norway — Kuststad heading same way

silence.q1_response: *stares at his hands — cracked, salt-stained* ...My father built this crew. Forty years of fishing these waters right. Now I'm the one destroying them. You think I sleep at night?
silence.expression_hint: Big hands flat on the table, head bowed
silence.q1_note: Family legacy, moral anguish

q2_options.text: What would your father have done?
What happens to these waters if no one speaks up?
Ragnar — what don't you want to tell me?

outcomes.response: He would've punched Lindqvist in the face. *grim smile* Different times. He didn't have twelve families depending on him staying out of trouble.
outcomes.feedback: Character moment. The weight of responsibility. But no new evidence.
outcomes.note: Father would have confronted Lindqvist directly

outcomes.response: Dr. Lind from the marine station ran numbers for me — off the books. At current rates, the Skärgård herring stock collapses in two breeding cycles. That's two years. After that, it takes a decade to recover. Maybe longer. Maybe never.
outcomes.feedback: Scientific assessment: two years to ecological collapse. Dr. Lind's data adds expert backing to the story.
outcomes.note: Marine biologist's data: herring collapse in 2 years, decade to recover

outcomes.response: *reaches into his jacket — pulls out a folded paper and a letter* The directive. A letter from Lindqvist to NordSjö's CEO. It says 'fishing berths released as discussed, three additional available by March.' He's not inflating catch numbers. He's clearing fishermen out of the harbor. Making room for NordSjö's cargo fleet. The quotas are designed to fail.
outcomes.feedback: The quotas aren't for fishing — they're a tool to evict fishermen and hand their berths to the shipping company. This is a planned displacement scheme disguised as fisheries management.
outcomes.note: Letter: Lindqvist selling fishing berths to NordSjö — quotas designed to evict

title: The Sailor's Widow
description: A woman whose husband died at sea has been denied his pension. The shipping company says he wasn't officially employed — but she has his pay slips.
lead_text: My husband Lars drowned in March. NordSjö says he was a 'contract consultant,' not an employee. But I have thirty years of pay slips that say otherwise.
preview: A handwritten letter, tear-stained, with photocopied pay slips enclosed.

interview.opening_line: Lars sailed for NordSjö for thirty years. Thirty years. And when he died, they said he never worked there. They said it to my face.

q1_options.text: I'm so sorry about Lars, Astrid. Tell me about him and what happened.
You said you have pay slips. Can I see them? How many years do they cover?
Is NordSjö systematically denying pensions to avoid paying survivors' benefits?

friendly.q1_response: Lars was a good man. Engine room, mostly. He kept those ships running when they should have been scrapped. In March, the boiler on the MV Kungshamn blew. Lars was the only one below deck. They said it was an 'industrial accident on a contractor vessel.'
friendly.expression_hint: Dry-eyed, past the tears, into anger
friendly.q1_note: Boiler explosion on MV Kungshamn in March — Lars was below deck

q2_options.text: Was there an investigation into the boiler explosion?
What does 'contractor vessel' mean? Wasn't it a NordSjö ship?
How are you managing without the pension, Astrid?

outcomes.response: Investigation? Three paragraphs from the maritime safety board. 'Equipment failure.' No mention that the boiler had been flagged in two previous inspections. I have the inspection reports — Lars kept copies of everything. He knew those ships were death traps.
outcomes.feedback: Boiler flagged in two inspections before the fatal explosion. Lars kept copies. This is negligence, possibly manslaughter.
outcomes.note: Boiler flagged in two previous inspections — Lars had copies

outcomes.response: It is a NordSjö ship. But on paper, it's registered to a shell company — Kusthamn Shipping KB. NordSjö owns Kusthamn, but the employees are technically contractors of the shell company. No pension, no benefits, no liability.
outcomes.feedback: Shell company employment structure to avoid liabilities. Common but hard to prove as deliberately fraudulent.
outcomes.note: NordSjö uses shell company Kusthamn Shipping KB to avoid obligations

outcomes.response: I clean houses now. Three houses a day. I'm sixty-one. Lars was supposed to retire next year. We were going to travel to Gotland — he always wanted to see Visby. Now I clean other people's floors.
outcomes.feedback: Devastating personal cost. Strong emotional angle but you need the systemic story.
outcomes.note: Sixty-one, cleaning three houses a day, Gotland trip cancelled forever

direct.q1_response: Here — every one. *opens a battered suitcase* 1944 to 1974. Monthly pay slips from NordSjö AB. Signed by the paymaster. NordSjö's name on every slip. Not Kusthamn Shipping, not any contractor. NordSjö.
direct.expression_hint: Opens a small suitcase filled with ordered envelopes
direct.q1_note: Thirty years of NordSjö-branded pay slips, 1944-1974

q2_options.text: When did NordSjö switch to calling employees 'contractors'?
Have other widows been denied pensions the same way?
Did Lars ever sign a contract that changed his employment status?

outcomes.response: 1969. That's when they set up Kusthamn Shipping KB. Everyone was told to sign new contracts. Lars refused for three months. They threatened to dock him. He signed. But the pay slips kept coming from NordSjö. They forgot to change the payroll.
outcomes.feedback: The shell company was created in 1969 but payroll was never transferred. The pay slips prove NordSjö was the real employer all along.
outcomes.note: Shell company 1969 but payroll never transferred — NordSjö slips continued

outcomes.response: At least five that I know of. Inger Holmgren — husband died in 1970. Denied. Karin Petersson — husband disabled in 1972. Denied. We've been talking. Five widows. All with the same story. All with pay slips. And now we have a lawyer.
outcomes.feedback: Five widows, same pattern, same evidence, and they've organized. A collective case with documentary proof across decades. This is a systemic labor fraud story.
outcomes.note: Five widows with pay slips have organized — have a lawyer

outcomes.response: He signed something in 1969. A new 'service agreement' with Kusthamn Shipping KB. But nobody explained what it meant. Lars didn't read Swedish perfectly — he trusted them. They used that trust to strip his pension.
outcomes.feedback: Contract signed under misleading circumstances. Sympathetic but legally complex.
outcomes.note: 1969 contract signed without understanding — exploited trust

pressure.q1_response: I believe they are. Lars isn't the only one. But most widows don't fight. They grieve. They accept what they're told. I'm not most widows.
pressure.expression_hint: Iron in her voice, jaw set
pressure.q1_note: Believes systematic denial, fighting back

q2_options.text: Astrid, if NordSjö has been doing this for years, why hasn't anyone exposed it before?
Have you tried going to the union about this?
What would it take to bring NordSjö to account?

outcomes.response: Because widows are quiet. Because the company is the town's biggest employer. Because the people who should be asking questions are the same people who profit from the silence. The union, the harbor authority, the insurance company — they all know.
outcomes.feedback: Institutional complicity. Union, harbor authority, insurance — all know, all silent. She sees the full picture.
outcomes.note: Institutional complicity: union, harbor, insurance all aware

outcomes.response: The union? Olov Strand? He wrote me a letter expressing 'sympathy' and suggested I 'seek alternative support channels.' Not one word about pension rights. The union collects dues from these men and does nothing when they die.
outcomes.feedback: Union failure documented but that's a secondary story. The main target is NordSjö.
outcomes.note: Union offered sympathy letter, no action on pension rights

outcomes.response: Proof. Not emotion — I have plenty of that. Proof that NordSjö knew these men were employees, not contractors. Proof that the shell company was set up specifically to avoid pensions. That's what I need you to find.
outcomes.feedback: She knows what's needed. She's directing you to the corporate structure. Smart source.
outcomes.note: Needs proof shell company was pension avoidance scheme

silence.q1_response: *touches the suitcase of pay slips* ...Lars kept every single one. He said, 'Astrid, one day they'll try to pretend I didn't exist. These are my proof.' He knew. He always knew.
silence.expression_hint: Hand resting on the suitcase like it's a coffin
silence.q1_note: Lars predicted the denial — kept pay slips as insurance

q2_options.text: Did Lars ever tell you why he was so careful to keep records?
What else did Lars know about how NordSjö treats its workers?
What's in that suitcase that NordSjö doesn't want anyone to see?

outcomes.response: Because he saw it happen to others. Old Magnusson. Forty years on NordSjö ships. Died in 1967. His widow got nothing. Lars swore that wouldn't happen to me. *pause* It's happening anyway.
outcomes.feedback: Pattern goes back to at least 1967. The Magnusson case was the first. But it's hearsay without documents.
outcomes.note: Magnusson case 1967 — pattern goes back decades

outcomes.response: Everything. Lars kept a diary. I found it after he died. He wrote about ships that should have been decommissioned, safety inspections that were faked, men who got hurt and were paid off in cash to stay quiet. Thirty years of a shipping company's sins. In one sailor's handwriting.
outcomes.feedback: A sailor's diary covering thirty years of safety violations and cover-ups. That's not just a pension story — it's an archive of corporate negligence.
outcomes.note: Lars's diary: 30 years of safety violations, faked inspections, cash payoffs

outcomes.response: *opens the suitcase* Pay slips, yes. Subject: 'Restructuring to eliminate pension obligations.' It says, and I quote: 'Transferring crew to Kusthamn KB will reduce our retirement liability by an estimated 2.3 million kronor over ten years.' He wrote it down. Lars stole the copy from the boardroom. He kept it for this exact day.
outcomes.feedback: The smoking gun. A board memo explicitly stating the shell company was created to eliminate pensions. 2.3 million in avoided obligations. Karlgren's own words. Combined with the pay slips proving the shell company was a fiction — this is a career-defining story.
outcomes.note: 1969 Karlgren memo: shell company created to 'eliminate pension obligations' — 2.3M

title: The Harbor Pilot's Secret
description: The harbor pilot has been guiding ships through a channel he knows is dangerously shallow. He's been ordered to keep quiet about the survey results.
lead_text: The channel depth readings are wrong. They've been wrong for two years. I guide ships through there every day knowing the bottom is closer than anyone thinks.
preview: A man in a pilot jacket, waiting by the newspaper office at dawn.

interview.opening_line: I pilot ships through the main channel six times a week. The official depth is 8.5 meters. The actual depth in the narrows is under 6. One bad tide and a loaded cargo ship hits bottom.

q1_options.text: That must weigh on you every time you guide a ship in. How did you discover the discrepancy?
Who falsified the depth readings? And do you have the real survey data?
If a ship runs aground on your watch, you'd be held responsible. Is that why you're here?

friendly.q1_response: Two years ago, I noticed my echo sounder readings didn't match the chart. Reported it. A new survey was ordered. The results came back — 5.8 meters in the narrows. Then Lindqvist classified the survey as 'preliminary' and buried it. The old chart stands.
friendly.expression_hint: Calm exterior, professionally alarmed
friendly.q1_note: Survey showed 5.8m depth — classified as 'preliminary' and buried

q2_options.text: Why would Lindqvist bury a depth survey? What's the motive?
Do you have a copy of the real survey results?
How close have you come to a grounding incident?

outcomes.response: Money. The port is classified as 'deep water' — that's a commercial grade that allows large cargo vessels. If the real depth is published, the port gets downgraded. Smaller ships only. Less revenue. Less of everything Lindqvist is building his career on.
outcomes.feedback: Port classification fraud. Correct depths would downgrade the harbor commercially. Lindqvist's entire career depends on the lie.
outcomes.note: Port classification depends on false depth — downgrade would cut revenue

outcomes.response: I kept the carbon copy when they collected the originals. Standard survey form, stamped and signed by the surveyor. Five-point-eight meters at the narrows. Dated March 1973. It's been under my mattress ever since.
outcomes.feedback: Physical evidence — the real survey with official stamp. Two years of concealment make this even more damning.
outcomes.note: Carbon copy of real survey: 5.8m, stamped March 1973

outcomes.response: Last month. The MV Kungsvik, fully loaded. I felt the hull shudder going through the narrows. Low tide. We cleared the bottom by maybe half a meter. If she'd been loaded one container deeper, we'd have a shipwreck in the channel.
outcomes.feedback: Near-miss incident but nobody else witnessed the shudder. Anecdotal.
outcomes.note: MV Kungsvik near-grounding last month — half meter clearance

direct.q1_response: The depth survey was done by a licensed marine surveyor named Holm. He found 5.8 meters in the narrows. Lindqvist took the report, stamped it 'preliminary,' and ordered a 'review' that never happened. I have a carbon copy of Holm's original.
direct.expression_hint: Pulls a blue-backed document from his jacket
direct.q1_note: Surveyor Holm's report: 5.8m — stamped 'preliminary', review never happened

q2_options.text: What happened to Holm? Was he pressured to change his findings?
Does the maritime safety authority know about the real depth?
How many ships have transited that channel since the survey was buried?

outcomes.response: Holm was told his contract wouldn't be renewed if he stood by his numbers. He stood by them. They hired a different surveyor — a company from Malmö that's never surveyed a harbor before. They produced a 'corrected' survey: 8.3 meters. Conveniently acceptable. I checked — the Malmö company is owned by NordSjö's insurance provider.
outcomes.feedback: Replacement surveyor owned by the insurance company. A fabricated 'second opinion' to overrule the real findings. That's institutional fraud interconnecting the port, shipping, and insurance.
outcomes.note: Second survey fabricated — company owned by NordSjö's insurer

outcomes.response: I wrote to them anonymously in April. They sent an inspector — but he only checked the official survey on file. The 'corrected' one showing 8.3 meters. He signed off. The real survey never left this harbor.
outcomes.feedback: Maritime safety authority checked but was shown the fake survey. The system works only if the data is honest.
outcomes.note: Safety authority inspected but saw only the fake 8.3m survey

outcomes.response: By my count, over 200 cargo transits in two years. Including NordSjö's Baltic route ships, which are among the deepest-drafting vessels in the fleet. Every single one has been at risk.
outcomes.feedback: 200 transits at risk. Scale is impressive but the evidence angle is stronger.
outcomes.note: Over 200 cargo transits through shallow channel in 2 years

pressure.q1_response: Yes. That's exactly why I'm here. If a ship grounds in that channel, the pilot gets blamed first. The chart says 8.5 meters. My echo sounder said otherwise. If I didn't report it, I'm negligent. I reported it and was ignored. I can't win.
pressure.expression_hint: Tightly controlled, a professional pushed to the wall
pressure.q1_note: Reported the discrepancy, was ignored — caught between duty and system

q2_options.text: What did Lindqvist say when you reported the depth discrepancy?
If you have the real survey, why not take it directly to the maritime authority?
Are other pilots aware the readings are wrong?

outcomes.response: He said: 'Erik, the port needs to be deep-water rated. Find a way to make it work. That's your job.' When I pressed, he said my pilot license was 'up for review next quarter.' That review is controlled by his office.
outcomes.feedback: Direct threat — pilot license held hostage. Same pattern as the ferry captain. Lindqvist uses licensing power to silence everyone.
outcomes.note: Lindqvist threatened pilot license review

outcomes.response: Because I'd be the source. And Lindqvist would know. And my license, my career, my pension — all gone. I need a newspaper to break this so I'm not the one standing alone.
outcomes.feedback: Explains his motive — needs the press as cover. Credible self-interest.
outcomes.note: Needs press cover to avoid retaliation

outcomes.response: The two other pilots trust the chart. They don't have echo sounders as sensitive as mine. They have no idea they're guiding ships through a death trap.
outcomes.feedback: Other pilots unaware — independently confirms the cover-up has held.
outcomes.note: Other pilots don't know — trust the official chart

silence.q1_response: *stands at the window, looking at the harbor* ...I can see the channel narrows from here. See that cargo vessel? Its draft is seven meters. The channel at low tide is less than six. Do the math.
silence.expression_hint: Professional calm masking deep fear
silence.q1_note: One low tide from disaster — you can see the risk from the office window

q2_options.text: Have you thought about what happens when they stop being lucky?
What keeps you piloting that channel knowing what you know?
Erik — what would it take to close that channel until it's properly dredged?

outcomes.response: Every day. A grounding in the narrows would block the channel completely. No ships in or out for weeks. The oil spill alone would destroy the fishing grounds. The Skärgård spawning area is 200 meters from the narrows.
outcomes.feedback: Environmental cascade — a grounding would block the harbor and poison the spawning ground. Stakes are enormous.
outcomes.note: Grounding would block harbor and devastate spawning ground

outcomes.response: Because if I refuse, they'll find a pilot who doesn't ask questions. At least I know the real depth. I adjust my approach — I pilot those ships through by centimeters. If someone else takes over... they trust the chart. And the chart is a lie.
outcomes.feedback: His presence is the only safety margin. If he's removed, the danger multiplies. He's a human buffer against institutional negligence.
outcomes.note: He's the only safety margin — adjusts for real depth

outcomes.response: It would take a newspaper article and a phone call to the maritime safety authority on the same day. And I have this — *pulls out a second document* — Lindqvist's written order to me: 'Disregard preliminary survey findings and continue operations as per established chart.' His signature. His order. His liability.
outcomes.feedback: Written order from Lindqvist to disregard the real depth data. Combined with the actual survey and echo sounder logs, this is a chain of evidence that proves knowing endangerment. Criminal negligence in writing.
outcomes.note: Written order from Lindqvist: 'disregard survey, continue operations'

title: The Refugee's Testimony
description: A man who arrived by boat from the Baltic has testimony about what's being transported through pier 7 at night.
lead_text: I was on one of those boats. I saw what they carried. It wasn't just people. There were crates — sealed crates with German writing. They made us help unload them.
preview: A note left at the church, passed along by Pastor Hedvig.

interview.opening_line: I shouldn't be speaking to the press. I don't have papers. But what I saw at pier 7 — people need to know. Even if it gets me deported.

q1_options.text: I understand the risk you're taking, Yusuf. Your courage matters. Tell me what you saw.
When did you arrive? What exactly was on that boat besides passengers?
If you witnessed smuggling, why didn't you go to the police? Is it because you're part of the operation?

friendly.q1_response: October. A fishing boat from Gdańsk. Twelve of us. We each paid 5,000 kronor. The captain said it was just people. But when we boarded, half the hold was full of sealed wooden crates. German labels. 'Elektronik-Erzeugnisse.' Electronics.
friendly.expression_hint: Quiet voice, looking at the table, occasionally at the door
friendly.q1_note: October crossing, 12 passengers, sealed crates with German electronics labels

q2_options.text: What happened when you arrived at pier 7?
Did you recognize anyone who was waiting at the dock?
Where are the other passengers now? Can any of them confirm this?

outcomes.response: Men were waiting. With a truck. No lights except hand torches. They made us help carry the crates — said it was 'part of the fare.' Took twenty minutes. The crates went into the old warehouse. Then a man in uniform told us to go — said the church would take us in. He spoke Swedish with a military voice.
outcomes.feedback: Organized reception, truck, enforced unloading, uniformed man directing operations. The refugees are being used as labor. The uniform suggests coast guard or harbor authority involvement.
outcomes.note: Uniformed man directed operations — refugees forced to unload

outcomes.response: It was dark. I didn't see faces well. But there was a man in a uniform — navy blue, maybe coast guard? — who seemed to be in charge. He had a clipboard. He checked the crates against a list.
outcomes.feedback: Uniformed official with a manifest. Confirms organization but no names.
outcomes.note: Uniformed man with clipboard checked crates

outcomes.response: Some have moved to Göteborg. Two are still here — staying at the church. Ibrahim and Ahmed. They saw the same things I did. But they're more afraid than me. They have families back home.
outcomes.feedback: Two potential corroborating witnesses at the church. But approaching them puts them at risk.
outcomes.note: Two corroborating witnesses at the church

direct.q1_response: I arrived October 12th. The boat left Gdańsk on the 10th. Twelve passengers. Forty-three sealed wooden crates. I counted them because we had to move them from the hold to the truck. Forty-three. Each one weighed maybe twenty kilos.
direct.expression_hint: Precise, engineer's mind despite the circumstances
direct.q1_note: October 12, from Gdańsk. 43 crates, ~20kg each. 12 passengers.

q2_options.text: Forty-three crates of twenty kilos — that's nearly a ton of undeclared cargo. What was in them?
Who ran the operation on the Swedish side?
How many boats like this come to pier 7?

outcomes.response: One crate was damaged in transit. The captain taped it shut but I saw inside. Radios. Small consumer electronics — transistor radios, maybe calculators. Brand new, in factory packaging. West German brands. Grundig, Braun. No customs stamps anywhere.
outcomes.feedback: West German consumer electronics — Grundig, Braun — smuggled through people-trafficking boats. Dual-use operation: people and cargo.
outcomes.note: Grundig and Braun electronics: radios, calculators — no customs stamps

outcomes.response: A man in the harbor office gave orders. I heard the truck driver call him 'Herr Lindqvist.' He checked the crates against a list, signed something, and told the driver where to go. Then he turned to us and said: 'You were never here. If you talk, immigration gets a call at dawn.'
outcomes.feedback: Lindqvist personally directing the smuggling operation and threatening refugees with deportation if they talk. Harbor master running a combined smuggling and human trafficking enterprise.
outcomes.note: Lindqvist personally directed — threatened refugees with immigration

outcomes.response: I've been here six weeks. In that time, I've seen boats at pier 7 at least four times. Different boats. Always at night. Always the same truck. The pastor says they've been coming for months.
outcomes.feedback: Weekly operations confirmed over six weeks. But secondhand from the pastor.
outcomes.note: Boats at pier 7 at least weekly for months

pressure.q1_response: *flinches* The police would deport me. I have no papers. The man at the dock told us — 'You talk, you're on a plane.' I came here because the pastor said a journalist might care about the truth. Was she wrong?
pressure.q1_note: Undocumented — threatened with deportation. Pastor as intermediary.

q2_options.text: I'm sorry — I had to ask. I'm not here to judge you. What can you tell me about the operation?
The threat proves they have something to hide. Did the man identify himself?
Your testimony could protect future passengers. Is that worth the risk?

outcomes.response: They used us. Cheap transport for the cargo, cheap labor to unload it. We paid them. And then they made us work. If I refuse, they say immigration gets my name. It's slavery with extra steps.
outcomes.feedback: Labor exploitation built into the smuggling model. Morally powerful but familiar horror.
outcomes.note: Refugees used as unpaid labor under deportation threats

outcomes.response: He wore a uniform. Dark blue. An emblem on the shoulder. He spoke like a man used to giving orders. The truck driver called him by a name — I couldn't catch the first name, but 'Lindqvist.' I remember because of the '-kvist.' Like 'twig' — I know that word in Swedish.
outcomes.feedback: Another witness placing Lindqvist at pier 7 during smuggling operations. Independent confirmation.
outcomes.note: Second independent identification of Lindqvist at pier 7

outcomes.response: There will be more boats. More people. More crates. If nobody writes about it, it just... continues. I was an engineer in Lebanon. I understand systems. This is a system — efficient, profitable, and invisible.
outcomes.feedback: Systemic analysis from an educated source. He sees the machine but can't prove who runs it.
outcomes.note: Engineer from Lebanon — sees the system clearly

silence.q1_response: *sits quietly, hands clasped* ...I came here to be safe. I crossed the sea in a boat meant for fish. I carried crates in the dark for men who think I'm nothing. And now I'm risking deportation to talk to you. Because this is wrong.
silence.expression_hint: Dignity in stillness, the weight of the whole journey on his shoulders
silence.q1_note: Moral clarity despite everything — this is wrong

q2_options.text: What happened to you is wrong. What happens next is up to this newspaper.
Tell me about the crossing. What did you see on that boat?
What do you want people to know, Yusuf?

outcomes.response: That would be something. A newspaper that does something. In Lebanon, the press was controlled. When I came to Sweden, I thought it would be different. Maybe it is. Maybe today.
outcomes.feedback: A press freedom moment. Beautiful but you need the facts, not the philosophy.
outcomes.note: Press freedom in Sweden — his hope

outcomes.response: The captain talked on the radio during the crossing. In Swedish. I understood some words. 'Pier 7.' 'Customs clear.' And a name I heard twice — 'Lindqvist.' The captain was getting instructions from someone at the harbor.
outcomes.feedback: Radio contact between the smuggling vessel and Lindqvist during the crossing. He's coordinating the arrivals in real-time.
outcomes.note: Radio: captain received instructions from 'Lindqvist' during crossing

outcomes.response: I want people to know that on October 12th, twelve human beings arrived at Kuststad harbor. A man in uniform counted the crates and ignored the people. And then he said — I remember his exact words — 'Another clean delivery. Tell Karlgren the harbor authority appreciates the partnership.' Karlgren. That's the shipping family.
outcomes.feedback: Direct quote linking Lindqvist, Karlgren, and the smuggling operation. 'Partnership' between the harbor authority and the shipping dynasty. And the human trafficking dehumanization — counted the crates, ignored the people.
outcomes.note: Direct quote: 'Tell Karlgren the harbor authority appreciates the partnership'
