title: The Scrapyard Secret
description: The harbor scrapyard owner has been paid to crush evidence — literally. Vehicles, machinery, and even a boat have disappeared into his yard on Lindqvist's orders.
lead_text: Lindqvist calls me at 3 AM and says 'I need something gone by sunrise.' I crush it. No questions. But last week he brought a boat. With blood on the deck.
preview: Rough voice on the office phone, breathing hard, asking to meet at the scrapyard at dusk.

interview.opening_line: I'm not a good man. I know that. But I'm not... I don't do what Lindqvist does. There's a line. He crossed it. And he's trying to drag me across with him.

q1_options.text: You wouldn't be here if you didn't care, Arne. Tell me what happened.
The boat with blood — when was it brought to you, and whose boat was it?
You've been destroying evidence for Lindqvist. That makes you an accessory.

friendly.q1_response: Started two years ago. Small stuff first. A filing cabinet from the harbor office — 'records disposal,' he said. Then a car. Then machinery from the docks. He pays cash. Double the scrap rate. I didn't ask why. Then last Wednesday — a fishing boat. And it had blood on the foredeck.
friendly.expression_hint: Smells of machine oil, won't sit still
friendly.q1_note: Two years of evidence disposal — filing cabinet, car, machinery, now a bloody boat

q2_options.text: Did you crush the boat yet?
Whose blood, Arne? Is someone missing?
Do you have records of what Lindqvist has asked you to destroy?

outcomes.response: No. It's behind my yard under a tarp. I told him the crusher was broken — bought myself a few days. But he's calling every night. Wants it gone by Friday.
outcomes.feedback: The boat is still intact. Physical evidence preserved under a tarp. Ticking clock — Friday deadline.
outcomes.note: Boat preserved under tarp — must be crushed by Friday

outcomes.response: I don't know whose blood. But I know whose boat. It belongs to a man named Lindström. He worked the pier 7 night shifts. Nobody has seen him in a week. His wife called the harbor office and they told her he 'resigned.'
outcomes.feedback: Missing night shift worker. His boat has blood on it. Lindqvist wants the boat destroyed. This isn't corruption anymore.
outcomes.note: Boat belongs to missing pier 7 worker Lindström — gone for a week

outcomes.response: Not formal records. But I remember everything. Dates, items, amounts paid. I wrote it down in my ledger — under 'special disposal.' I'm not stupid. I knew this day might come.
outcomes.feedback: He kept his own records. Good documentation instinct but needs the boat itself as evidence.
outcomes.note: Personal ledger records all 'special disposal' jobs

direct.q1_response: Last Wednesday night. Around midnight. Lindqvist drove it to my loading dock himself. A six-meter fishing boat, green hull. Registration scraped off. Blood on the foredeck and the gunwale. Not a lot — but enough.
direct.expression_hint: Big hands clenched on his knees
direct.q1_note: Wednesday midnight, 6m green fishing boat, registration scraped, blood on foredeck/gunwale

q2_options.text: Have you preserved the bloodstains? Could they be tested?
Did Lindqvist say anything about where the boat came from?
Is the boat still in your yard?

outcomes.response: I covered the deck with plastic sheeting. Nothing's been touched. If someone — police, a lab — could take samples before Friday, there's your evidence. I also found this in the cockpit drain. *holds up a small ziplock bag* A man's watch. Engraved on the back: 'To Lindström, 25 years at sea.'
outcomes.feedback: Preserved bloodstains, an engraved watch identifying the victim. Physical evidence connecting the boat to the missing pier 7 worker. This is potentially a murder investigation.
outcomes.note: Bloodstains preserved under plastic — victim's engraved watch found in drain

outcomes.response: He said: 'It was in the harbor basin. It's abandoned. Scrap it.' When I asked about the blood, he said 'fish blood.' At midnight. A boat with its registration scraped off. With 'fish blood.'
outcomes.feedback: 'Fish blood' excuse for a registration-scraped boat at midnight. Lindqvist's explanation is absurd and his tone proves he knew it.
outcomes.note: Lindqvist said 'fish blood' — registration deliberately scraped off

outcomes.response: Behind the yard. Under a blue tarp. I told him the crusher needs a new hydraulic line. It doesn't — I'm stalling. But I can't stall forever. He's getting more insistent every day.
outcomes.feedback: Boat preserved but under time pressure. The story gets stronger if you can get to it before Friday.
outcomes.note: Boat under blue tarp — stalling with fake crusher repair

pressure.q1_response: I know what I am. That's why I'm talking to you instead of the police. The police would arrest me. You — you can print the truth and maybe I come out as the man who stopped, not the man who crushed the evidence.
pressure.expression_hint: Sweating despite the cold, calculating his options
pressure.q1_note: Self-preservation motive — wants to be the man who stopped

q2_options.text: Arne, what has Lindqvist asked you to destroy beyond the boat?
If this boat is connected to a missing person, you need to go to the police regardless.
How much has Lindqvist paid you over two years? How deep are you in this?

outcomes.response: A filing cabinet full of harbor records — before I crushed it, I looked inside. Patrol schedules, cargo receipts, something that looked like a shift log. All from pier 7. He's erasing every record of what happens at that pier.
outcomes.feedback: The filing cabinet contained pier 7 records — patrol schedules, cargo receipts, shift logs. Lindqvist is systematically destroying the paper trail.
outcomes.note: Crushed filing cabinet had pier 7 records — patrol, cargo, shifts

outcomes.response: The police? In this town? The chief of police plays cards with Lindqvist every Friday. You think he'd investigate his bridge partner?
outcomes.feedback: Police-harbor master social connection. Adds to the institutional picture but no documents.
outcomes.note: Police chief is Lindqvist's card partner

outcomes.response: Forty-seven thousand kronor. In two years. I know the exact number because it's all logged under 'special disposal' in my books. I'm not hiding what I did. I'm trying to undo it.
outcomes.feedback: Total amount documented. Shows scale but the boat is the key evidence, not the money.
outcomes.note: 47,000 kr over two years — all logged

silence.q1_response: *rubs his face with oil-stained hands* ...My grandfather started this yard. He scrapped fishing boats that had served their time. Honest work. Now I'm crushing evidence for a man who might be a murderer. What have I become?
silence.expression_hint: Staring at the crusher behind him
silence.q1_note: Third-generation scrapyard — family legacy corrupted

q2_options.text: You can still make this right, Arne.
What do you think happened to Lindström?
What else is in your yard that shouldn't be there?

outcomes.response: *nods slowly* That's what the pastor said. She said God forgives the man who stops. I want to stop. I want to hand you the boat and walk away clean.
outcomes.feedback: Moral turn but you need facts, not redemption. Press for details.
outcomes.note: Wants redemption — pastor involved again

outcomes.response: Lindström saw something he shouldn't have. He worked the pier 7 night shift — loading and unloading. Two weeks ago, he told a friend he wanted to talk to someone about what was happening there. A week later, he's 'resigned' and his boat has blood on it.
outcomes.feedback: Lindström threatened to talk, then disappeared. His boat was delivered for destruction. That's a pattern consistent with silencing a witness.
outcomes.note: Lindström wanted to talk about pier 7 — disappeared a week later

outcomes.response: The boat. Lindqvist didn't see it. *hands over a brown envelope* It's a ledger page. Cargo movements at pier 7 for September. Dates, vessels, weights, and... names. Everyone involved. Lindqvist, Larsson from the Coast Guard, Göransson from NordSjö, and the Karlgren family's private logistics man. In one column. On one page. That's your conspiracy.
outcomes.feedback: The conspiracy in one document. A ledger page listing every key player in the pier 7 operation — harbor master, coast guard, shipping company, and the dynasty. Names, dates, vessels, weights. This connects every story thread in Kuststad.
outcomes.note: Pier 7 ledger page: Lindqvist, Larsson, Göransson, Karlgren logistics — full conspiracy

title: The Council Member's Confession
description: A town council member has been rubber-stamping harbor authority decisions for years. Now he wants to explain why — and who's been pressuring him.
lead_text: I've voted yes on every harbor authority proposal for six years. Not because I agreed. Because I was told what would happen if I voted no.
preview: A manila envelope left at the newspaper reception desk, containing a typed confession.

interview.opening_line: I'm a coward. I've known what Lindqvist is doing for years. I voted to give him more power, more budget, more authority. Because he had something on me. He has something on everyone.

q1_options.text: It takes courage to admit that, Hans. What does Lindqvist have on you?
Which council decisions were compromised? And what did Lindqvist use as leverage?
You enabled years of corruption. Why should anyone trust what you're saying now?

title: The Lighthouse Keeper's Logbook
description: The lighthouse keeper has been recording every vessel that passes at night. His logbook contradicts the official harbor records — and proves ships are entering without being logged.
lead_text: I see every ship that comes and goes. I write them all down. My numbers don't match the harbor authority's numbers. They never have.
preview: A leather-bound logbook left on the newsroom desk with a lighthouse stamp on the cover.

interview.opening_line: I've kept a log every night for eighteen years. Time, bearing, vessel type, lights or no lights. My log has 847 more vessel entries than the harbor authority's official records for the same period. Where did those 847 ships go?

q1_options.text: 847 ships. Eighteen years of records. Viktor, that's extraordinary diligence.
When do the discrepancies start? Is there a pattern to which ships are unrecorded?
Eight hundred unrecorded ships — is the harbor authority running an uninspected shadow port?

friendly.q1_response: It's what the job requires. Every vessel, every light, every bearing. But lately I've been comparing my logs to the harbor's quarterly reports. The gap grows every year. In 1970, 23 unrecorded vessels. In 1974 — 187.

friendly.q1_note: Gap growing: 23 unrecorded in 1970, 187 in 1974

q2_options.text: What kind of vessels are going unrecorded?
187 unrecorded in one year — what happened in 1974 to cause the spike?
Has anyone at the harbor authority ever tried to access your logs?

outcomes.feedback: Baltic vessels arriving during 'closed' hours while pier 7 is manned. Independent corroboration of the smuggling operation from an unconnected witness.
outcomes.note: Baltic cargo vessels, midnight-04:00, pier 7 always manned

outcomes.response: The Baltic route opened in June. NordSjö's official schedule shows two ships per week. My log shows four or five. The extra arrivals are always at night. Always to pier 7. The harbor authority doesn't record them because they happen when the office is 'closed.'
outcomes.feedback: NordSjö's Baltic route runs double the official schedule. The 'extra' ships are the smuggling runs. Your lighthouse keeper just provided the statistical proof.
outcomes.note: NordSjö runs 4-5 ships/week, records only 2 — night runs to pier 7

outcomes.response: Lindqvist asked to 'review' my logs two years ago. I said they were maritime safety records and only I was responsible for them. He was not pleased. Since then, my budget requests have been denied three times.
outcomes.feedback: Lindqvist tried to access the logs and retaliated when denied. The lighthouse budget cuts are punitive.
outcomes.note: Lindqvist tried to access logs — punitive budget cuts since

direct.q1_response: The discrepancies cluster around specific dates and times. Night arrivals, Thursday to Sunday, from Baltic bearings. My log entries align with new moon phases — they come when it's darkest. I've catalogued the pattern over three years.

direct.q1_note: Thursday-Sunday night arrivals from Baltic, correlated with new moon phases

q2_options.text: You've correlated vessel movements with lunar phases? Show me the data.
Can your logs identify specific vessels that appear in the harbor records under different dates?

outcomes.response: Here — three years of data on one chart. *unfolds a hand-drawn graph* Unrecorded arrivals peak within two days of every new moon. The correlation is 94%. This isn't coincidence. It's a schedule. Someone is running an operation that depends on darkness, and the harbor authority records are edited to erase it.
outcomes.feedback: 94% lunar correlation over three years. Statistical proof of an organized smuggling schedule. No court could call this coincidence. The lighthouse keeper just provided the mathematical smoking gun.
outcomes.note: 94% correlation between unrecorded arrivals and new moon — 3-year chart

outcomes.response: Yes. I found seven instances where a vessel appears in my nighttime log as 'unlit, Baltic bearing, pier 7' and the same vessel — matched by length and profile — appears in harbor records two days later as an 'inbound cargo, routine inspection.' They dock twice. Once in secret, once for show.
outcomes.feedback: Vessels dock secretly at night, then 'officially' two days later. The double docking explains how they pass inspection — the contraband is unloaded before the official arrival.
outcomes.note: Seven vessels docked twice — once at night (pier 7), once officially 2 days later

outcomes.response: The Coast Guard logs are incomplete. Larsson's night patrol records have suspicious gaps — exactly the same nights my logs show unrecorded arrivals. It's as if someone erased their records to match the harbor's.

outcomes.note: Coast Guard log gaps align with Viktor's unrecorded arrivals

pressure.q1_response: Shadow port is exactly what it is. The harbor operates a legitimate daytime business and an unrecorded nighttime one. My logs prove it. The question is why the harbor authority's 'official' record-keeper allows 847 ships to go unlogged.

outcomes.feedback: Dignified stand. But you need the data package, not the philosophy.

outcomes.note: November 3rd vessel confirmed — cross-references Engström's missing logbook

title: The Retired Engineer's Blueprint
description: A retired trawler engineer finds old blueprints showing that the harbor's supporting structures are critically weakened. A major pier collapse is a matter of when, not if.
lead_text: I helped build pier 3 in 1952. I still have the structural blueprints. Some bolts were substandard — we reported it. Nobody fixed them. That was twenty-two years ago.

B-grade steel in saltwater for twenty-two years.

outcomes.response: Because a pier didn't collapse in 1952 or 1970. It might collapse now. Every winter storm, every loaded crane, every day that goes by makes it more likely. The physics don't care about politics. When it goes, it goes.

A NordSjö man — Göransson — who handles the cargo side. They work in layers. Each knows their part. A pastor sees the whole picture because they all come to church eventually.

title: The Harbor Master's Gambit
description: Axel Lindqvist himself wants to meet. He says he has information about who's really running Kuststad. But is this a peace offering or a trap?
lead_text: You've been asking questions about my harbor. Good. Someone should. Meet me at the harbor office tonight. There are things even your sources don't know.
preview: A typed note on harbor authority letterhead, slipped under the office door.

interview.opening_line: Sit down. You think I'm the villain of your story. Maybe I am. But I'm not the only one. And I'm certainly not the one at the top.

q1_options.text: I'm listening, Axel. Not many people in your position would agree to meet a reporter.
Who's at the top? You've been running this harbor like a personal fiefdom. If someone is above you, name them.
Multiple witnesses place you at pier 7 during illegal operations. This meeting doesn't change that.

friendly.q1_response: Not many people in my position have Henrik Karlgren calling them at midnight threatening to destroy their career if they don't cooperate. I was the harbor master of a fishing port. Then NordSjö came, and everything changed.

q2_options.text: When did Karlgren first approach you? What did he want?
If you were coerced, why didn't you report it?

outcomes.response: 1969. He said: 'Axel, this harbor is changing. NordSjö will bring jobs and money. All I need is... flexibility. After hours. A pier nobody uses. And your signature on some papers.' I signed. And signing once made me a prisoner forever.
outcomes.feedback: The origin story. 1969 — same year as the shell company. Karlgren recruited the harbor master with promises of prosperity and trapped him with complicity.
outcomes.note: 1969: Karlgren recruited Lindqvist with 'flexibility' request — trapped by first signature

outcomes.response: Report to whom? The police chief plays cards with me because Karlgren told him to. The council votes my way because I have leverage — leverage Karlgren gave me to use. The system is designed to be unreportable.
outcomes.feedback: The institutional capture was designed. Karlgren built the network. Lindqvist was a tool. But self-serving narrative — tread carefully.
outcomes.note: Claims Karlgren designed the institutional capture

outcomes.response: I have letters. From Karlgren to me. Specific instructions. 'Clear pier 7 Thursday night.' 'Hold the ferry until 06:30.' 'Ensure the Baltic manifest shows eight containers.' His handwriting. His letterhead. I kept them because I'm not stupid — I knew this day would come.
outcomes.feedback: Written orders from Karlgren to Lindqvist. Handwritten, on letterhead. If authentic, this proves the chain of command goes above the harbor master.
outcomes.note: Written orders from Karlgren: pier 7, ferry, manifests — handwritten originals

direct.q1_response: Henrik Karlgren. Old money. Shipping dynasty. NordSjö is his family's company. Everything that happens in this harbor — the night landings, the manifests, pier 7, the coast guard gaps — it's his operation. I'm the manager. He's the owner.
direct.expression_hint: Opens a drawer, pulls out a folder
direct.q1_note: Names Karlgren as the principal — Lindqvist claims to be the agent

q2_options.text: Prove it. What do you have that ties Karlgren to specific criminal acts?
Even if Karlgren gives the orders, you executed them. Blackmail, evidence destruction, threatening workers.
Why are you telling me this? What do you want?

outcomes.response: *opens the folder* Five years of written instructions from Henrik Karlgren. He's the brain.
outcomes.feedback: Five years of written orders connecting Karlgren to every aspect of the conspiracy — the November 3rd cover-up, the berth transfers, the fake depth survey. If these letters are authentic, this is the command structure of the entire operation.
outcomes.note: 5 years of Karlgren's written orders — connects to every story thread

outcomes.response: I know what I've done. Every bit of it. But I had a choice between being Karlgren's manager or being his victim. The last harbor master who said no — my predecessor, Johansson — took early retirement at fifty-two. Lost his pension. Lives in a one-room flat in Borås. That was Henrik Karlgren's handshake.
outcomes.feedback: Predecessor destroyed by Karlgren. Establishes the pattern of coercion. But Lindqvist is still trying to minimize his own agency.
outcomes.note: Previous harbor master Johansson destroyed for refusing — lives in Borås

outcomes.response: I want immunity. Or at least... consideration. I'll give you everything. Every document, every name, every account number. In exchange, I want the story to show that there's someone above me. That I was pressured. Not forgiven — just... accurately placed in the hierarchy.
outcomes.feedback: He's negotiating his narrative. He wants to be the corrupted, not the corruptor. Useful but self-serving — every fact he gives must be independently verified.
outcomes.note: Wants narrative immunity — 'accurately placed in the hierarchy'

pressure.q1_response: I know what your witnesses say. I was there. I don't deny it. But do you want the harbor master or do you want the man who owns the harbor master? Because I can give you Henrik Karlgren on a plate.
pressure.expression_hint: Cornered animal making a deal — calculating every word
pressure.q1_note: Admits presence at pier 7 — offers Karlgren in exchange

q2_options.text: I want both. But start with Karlgren. What can you prove?
This sounds like a man trying to save himself by sacrificing his boss.
A man is missing. Lindström. His boat had blood on it. You delivered it to the scrapyard. Start there.

outcomes.response: Karlgren runs a parallel accounting system. I've seen it. The real books are in his Göteborg office — a safe behind the painting in his study. Everything — the smuggled cargo values, the insurance fraud profits, the cut for every participant. My name is in there too. But so is every name that matters.
outcomes.feedback: Location of the master ledger — Göteborg office, safe behind a painting. If this is true, it's the key to the entire operation.
outcomes.note: Karlgren's real books: Göteborg office, safe behind painting — all names inside

outcomes.response: It is exactly that. And you know what? It's also the truth. Would you rather have my head on a plate while Karlgren sails away on one of his 'sunken' ships? The man owns everything. I just held the door open.
outcomes.feedback: Rhetorically effective but still self-serving. He's right about the hierarchy, wrong about his own innocence.
outcomes.note: Deflecting to Karlgren — 'I just held the door open'

outcomes.response: *silence* ...Lindström was a problem. He saw things at pier 7 and started asking questions. Karlgren called me and said: 'Handle it.' I didn't... I didn't kill anyone. I told Lindström to leave town. Gave him money. He took his boat and said he was going to his brother in Halmstad. That's the last I know. The blood on the boat... I don't know. I swear to you, I don't know.
outcomes.feedback: Partial admission about Lindström — told to 'handle it' by Karlgren, paid him to leave. Claims ignorance about the blood. Credible or convenient? The Karlgren order is the key detail.
outcomes.note: Karlgren ordered 'handle it' — paid Lindström to leave — claims no knowledge of blood

silence.q1_response: *pours the aquavit, stares at it* ...I used to love this harbor. I grew up on these docks. My father was harbor master before me. He was an honest man. I thought I could be an honest man in a dishonest job. I was wrong.
silence.expression_hint: An aging man in a chair too big for him, surrounded by papers
silence.q1_note: Father was the previous harbor master — family legacy corrupted

q2_options.text: What would your father say about what you've done to this harbor?
When did you stop being honest, Axel?
Is it too late to make it right?

outcomes.response: My father would have walked into the sea. He was that kind of man. Upright to the bone. He'd be ashamed. He IS ashamed — wherever he is.
outcomes.feedback: Raw emotion. But his father also signed the bad bolt order in 1952. The family legacy is more complicated than he admits.
outcomes.note: Claims father was honest — but father signed the bad bolts too

outcomes.response: 1969. The year I signed Karlgren's first paper. One signature. That's all it took. After that, every 'yes' was easier than the last 'no.' People think corruption is dramatic. It's not. It's just... not saying no.
outcomes.feedback: The psychology of institutional corruption from the inside. The first signature as the point of no return. Honest self-analysis from a corrupt man.
outcomes.note: 'One signature in 1969 — every yes was easier than the last no'

outcomes.response: Maybe. *opens his desk drawer — pulls out a thick folder and a set of keys* This folder has everything. And these keys open the pier 7 warehouse. If you go there tonight, you'll find the current shipment — 200 crates of electronics, a manifest that doesn't exist, and the truck that moves them. Or you can have me. You can't have both.
outcomes.feedback: The complete evidence package — and the perpetrator's escape. He's trading everything for a head start. The folder, the warehouse keys, the current shipment in place. This is the final piece — but publishing it means Lindqvist walks free. The ultimate editorial decision.
outcomes.note: Full folder + warehouse keys + current shipment — Lindqvist fleeing tonight

title: The Coast Guard's Report
description: A coast guard officer sends a stolen copy of the weekly patrol schedule. Every Thursday for 18 months, pier 7 was removed from the route — but not by accident. Someone at headquarters is editing the schedules before they're printed.
lead_text: I copied our patrol schedules going back to January 1973. Every Thursday night, the same thing: pier 7 is removed from the route. The original schedule includes it. The printed version doesn't. Someone between typing and printing is erasing it.
preview: A manila envelope containing 78 photocopied patrol schedules, with discrepancies circled in red ink.

interview.opening_line: I shouldn't be here. If Larsson finds out I copied those schedules, I'm finished. But 78 weeks of altered patrol routes isn't a clerical error — it's a system.

q1_options.text: You're doing the right thing. Walk me through how you noticed the discrepancies.
78 altered schedules. Who changes them and when exactly does it happen?
You've been on these patrols for two years. You must have known something was wrong long before you started photocopying.

friendly.q1_response: It started small. I noticed we never patrolled pier 7 on Thursday nights. I mentioned it to Larsson — my supervisor — and he said it was 'rotation optimization.' But I pulled the original typing carbon from the secretary's desk. Pier 7 was on the original. Someone changes it between the carbon and the mimeograph.
friendly.expression_hint: Leans forward, voice barely above a whisper
friendly.q1_note: Claims schedules are altered between typing and printing — implicates supervisor Larsson

q2_options.text: Who has access to the schedules between the secretary typing them and the mimeograph?
What happens at pier 7 on Thursday nights that someone wants unpatrolled?
Has Larsson ever directly told you to skip pier 7?

outcomes.response: Three people. The secretary types them Monday. They go to Larsson for approval. Then to the print room. Larsson's initials are on the altered version — I can prove that. The original carbon has pier 7. His approved copy doesn't. Every single Thursday for 78 weeks.
outcomes.feedback: Chain of custody established: secretary types original (with pier 7), Larsson approves altered version (without pier 7). His initials on 78 altered schedules — strong documentary evidence of systematic tampering.
outcomes.note: Larsson's initials on 78 altered schedules — pier 7 removed between typing and approval

outcomes.response: I've only been able to observe twice without being noticed. Both times: lights off at pier 7 warehouse, but engine noise. Trucks backing up to the loading dock around 23:00. No harbor log entries for those nights. Whatever moves through pier 7 on Thursdays doesn't officially exist.
outcomes.feedback: Direct observation of nighttime activity at pier 7 — trucks, engine noise, no harbor logs. Combined with the patrol gap, this suggests coordinated smuggling with coast guard complicity.
outcomes.note: Observed Thursday night activity: trucks at pier 7, no harbor log entries, lights off

outcomes.response: Once. October 17th. I was on the Thursday route by accident — schedule mixup, my partner was sick. Larsson radioed me at 22:40: 'Engström, redirect to the outer breakwater. False alarm report from a fishing vessel.' There was no fishing vessel. I checked the radio log later — no distress call was ever made. He invented a reason to pull me away from pier 7.
outcomes.feedback: Critical testimony: Larsson fabricated a distress call to redirect Engström away from pier 7. October 17th — check the coast guard radio log for that night. If the distress call doesn't exist in the log, Larsson was actively covering for pier 7 operations.
outcomes.note: Oct 17th: Larsson fabricated distress call to redirect patrol from pier 7 — verifiable in radio log

direct.q1_response: Larsson. Patrol Supervisor Erik Larsson. The secretary types the schedule Monday morning from the standing rotation. Larsson reviews it Tuesday. By Wednesday when it's mimeographed, pier 7 is gone from Thursday's route. I have the carbons and the prints side by side. His approval stamp is on the altered version.
direct.expression_hint: Pulls documents from inside his jacket
direct.q1_note: Names Larsson directly — has documentary comparison of original vs altered schedules

q2_options.text: Who does Larsson report to? Is he acting alone or on orders?
Do you have the October 17th documents? The night you were redirected?
Why 78 weeks? What started in January 1973?

outcomes.response: Larsson reports to Commander Nilsson at regional headquarters. But here's the thing — I've seen Larsson make phone calls from the harbor payphone, not the office phone. Always Tuesday afternoons, after he gets the schedule. The harbor payphone. Why would a coast guard supervisor use a public phone unless he doesn't want the call logged?
outcomes.feedback: Larsson uses the harbor payphone Tuesday afternoons — after receiving schedules but before altering them. He's reporting to someone and avoiding the logged office phone. The payphone angle could help identify who he's coordinating with.
outcomes.note: Larsson makes unlogged calls from harbor payphone every Tuesday — coordinating schedule changes

outcomes.response: I have everything from October 17th. The original schedule with pier 7 on the Thursday route. The radio log showing NO distress call at 22:40 even though he radioed me about one. And my partner's sick note — proving the schedule mixup that put me on the route by accident. Four documents that prove Larsson fabricated a distress call to protect pier 7.
outcomes.feedback: Four corroborating documents for October 17th: original schedule, altered schedule, clean radio log, and the sick note explaining the mixup. This is a tight evidence package proving fabricated distress calls to cover pier 7 operations.
outcomes.note: Oct 17th evidence package: 4 documents proving fabricated distress call — original, altered, radio log, sick note

outcomes.response: January 1973 is when NordSjö Shipping signed the expanded pier contract. Before that, pier 7 was a derelict fishing dock. The contract gave NordSjö exclusive after-hours access for 'maintenance and equipment storage.' The patrol changes started the same month. Coincidence? I was naive once. Not anymore.
outcomes.feedback: Timeline correlation: NordSjö's pier 7 contract and patrol alterations both started January 1973. The 'after-hours maintenance' clause gave NordSjö legitimate-sounding cover for nighttime access. But Engström is connecting dots — verify the contract terms independently.
outcomes.note: Jan 1973: NordSjö pier 7 contract coincides with patrol alterations — 'after-hours maintenance' clause

pressure.q1_response: I— yes. Fine. I knew after three months. The routes didn't make sense. But Larsson is my supervisor. He writes my evaluations. He controls my assignments. You think it's easy to question the man who decides whether you get promoted or posted to some rock in the outer archipelago?
pressure.q1_note: Admits knowing for months — delayed reporting due to career pressure from Larsson

q2_options.text: So what changed? Why come forward now after all this time?
Have you personally benefited from the altered schedules — easier shifts, fewer night patrols?
If Larsson controls everything, how did you copy 78 schedules without him noticing?

outcomes.response: Three weeks ago, a fisherman's body washed up near the outer breakwater. Officially: drowning. But I saw the body before the medical examiner arrived. Those weren't drowning injuries. And that fisherman — Lindström's cousin — had been asking questions about pier 7. I can't prove it's connected. But I can't sleep either.
outcomes.feedback: A death that may not be what it seems — fisherman connected to missing worker Lindström, found dead with suspicious injuries near the breakwater. Engström links it to pier 7 questioning. This deepens the Lindström disappearance thread.
outcomes.note: Lindström's cousin found dead — suspicious injuries, was asking about pier 7

outcomes.response: No! I haven't— well. Thursday nights are shorter shifts because pier 7 isn't on the route. So yes, technically I go home earlier. But I didn't ask for that. It's just... the schedule. Everyone benefits from the shorter route. That doesn't make me complicit.
outcomes.feedback: He benefits from the altered schedules — shorter Thursday shifts. He may not be complicit by design, but he had a personal reason not to question the changes. This undermines his whistleblower credibility somewhat.
outcomes.note: Admits benefiting from shorter Thursday shifts — weakens whistleblower credibility

outcomes.response: Larsson takes a long lunch every Tuesday. 12:00 to 14:00. The filing cabinet where he keeps the week's schedules — it's a standard government lock. Same key as every cabinet in the building. I started copying in March. One schedule per week, during his lunch. He's not careful because he doesn't think anyone would dare.
outcomes.feedback: Methodical document collection during Larsson's Tuesday lunches. 78 copies over 18 months. The standard government lock detail is plausible. But this level of planning suggests Engström has been building a case for months — or building leverage.
outcomes.note: Copied schedules during Larsson's Tuesday lunches — 18 months of methodical collection

silence.q1_response: ...you're not going to make this easy for me, are you? Fine. I'll say it plainly. My supervisor, Erik Larsson, has been removing pier 7 from Thursday night patrols for a year and a half. I have proof. I'm risking my career and possibly my life to bring it to you. A little acknowledgment wouldn't kill you.
silence.expression_hint: Shifts uncomfortably, then straightens with resolve
silence.q1_note: Frustrated by silence but doubles down — names Larsson explicitly

q2_options.text: You mentioned your life. Has anyone threatened you directly?
Walk me through the documentary evidence you have — what would hold up in court?
Why bring this to a newspaper instead of internal affairs?

outcomes.response: Not directly. But two weeks after I started copying schedules, someone slashed my car tires. A week later, a note on my windshield: 'The archipelago is lovely in winter.' That's where they send coast guard officers who cause problems. Could be coincidence. Could be a warning. I don't know who left it.
outcomes.feedback: Possible intimidation — slashed tires and a threatening note referencing remote posting. But no direct connection to Larsson or pier 7 operations. Could be unrelated. The note text suggests someone knows he's a coast guard officer causing problems.
outcomes.note: Possible intimidation: slashed tires, threatening note about archipelago posting — no proven connection

outcomes.response: I have a filing cabinet's worth. 78 original carbons with pier 7 on Thursday routes. 78 mimeographed versions with pier 7 removed — each bearing Larsson's approval stamp, dated and initialed. And six months of notes on Larsson's Tuesday payphone calls — dates, times, duration. I can't prove who he called, but I can prove the pattern.
outcomes.feedback: Comprehensive evidence package: 156 schedule comparisons, radio log discrepancy, and six months of payphone surveillance notes. This is a methodical whistleblower with documentary proof of systematic patrol manipulation. The payphone pattern is circumstantial but compelling.
outcomes.note: Full evidence: 156 schedules, Oct 17th radio log, 6 months payphone surveillance — comprehensive case

outcomes.response: Because internal affairs IS the coast guard. Commander Nilsson at regional HQ signed off on Larsson's posting here. Nilsson and Karlgren sit on the same Rotary Club board in Göteborg. I checked the membership records. The man who would investigate my complaint about Larsson has dinner with the man Larsson is probably protecting.
outcomes.feedback: Institutional capture: the internal affairs chain leads to Commander Nilsson, who has Rotary Club connections to Karlgren. If true, reporting within the system would be useless — or dangerous. But verify the Rotary connection independently.

title: The Fisherman's Letter
description: A trawler captain writes a detailed letter about what fishermen see from the water at night — unmarked vessels, cargo transfers without lights, and a dead zone where nothing lives anymore. The harbor's secrets look different from the sea.
lead_text: We fish these waters every night. We see things. Boats that aren't in any register. Cargo moving without dock lights. And a stretch of seabed near pier 7 where nothing grows and nothing lives. I'm writing because nobody has asked the people who know this harbor best — the ones who work it from the water side.
preview: A handwritten letter on ruled paper, smelling faintly of diesel and salt, with a hand-drawn chart of nighttime vessel movements.

interview.opening_line: Twenty-three years I've fished these waters. My father fished them before me. We know every current, every shoal, every rock. So when I tell you something is killing the harbor floor near pier 7, I'm not guessing. And when I tell you unmarked boats run dark on Thursday nights, I'm not imagining it.

q1_options.text: You clearly know these waters intimately. Tell me what you've been seeing out there.
Two claims: dead seabed and unmarked boats. Let's start with whichever one you have hard evidence for.
Fishermen complain about harbors — it's practically tradition. What makes your complaints different from dock gossip?

friendly.q1_response: The water tells you everything if you know how to listen. Three years ago, we'd pull full nets within 200 meters of pier 7 — herring, cod, flounder. Now? Nothing inside 400 meters. Dead zone. The seabed is covered in a grey sludge that wasn't there before. And the smell — when you pull empty nets through it, the rope stinks for days. Chemical. Not natural.
friendly.expression_hint: Weathered hands trace imaginary map on the desk
friendly.q1_note: Describes expanding dead zone near pier 7 — 200m to 400m over 3 years, chemical sludge

q2_options.text: Have you kept any samples of this sludge or documented the dead zone's growth?
Tell me about the unmarked boats. What exactly have you seen on Thursday nights?
Have other fishermen reported the same thing? Could this be organized testimony?

outcomes.response: I have rope samples in jars — dated, labeled, the grey stuff still on them. And my catch logs going back five years. Pier 7 was my best herring ground. You can see the numbers drop: 1971 was 340 kilos per week. 1972 was 280. 1973 was 90. This year? I don't even set nets there anymore. Something is being dumped, and it's poisoning the seabed.
outcomes.feedback: Physical evidence: dated rope samples with chemical sludge, and catch logs showing dramatic decline (340kg→90kg over 3 years). The fisherman's documentation is systematic. Independent lab testing of the sludge could confirm contamination.
outcomes.note: Rope samples with sludge (dated), catch logs showing 340→90kg/week decline near pier 7

outcomes.response: Thursdays, between 22:00 and 01:00. Boats running without navigation lights — which is illegal and dangerous. Mid-size cargo vessels, maybe 30-40 meters. They dock at pier 7's outer face — the side you can't see from shore. I've watched them through binoculars from my boat at anchor. They're there for two, maybe three hours. Then they leave the same way. Dark.
outcomes.feedback: Consistent Thursday night pattern matching the coast guard patrol gaps. Vessels running dark (illegal), 30-40m cargo class, using pier 7's blind-side dock. 2-3 hour operations. This corroborates that pier 7 is active on the nights patrols are diverted.
outcomes.note: Thursday 22:00-01:00: unmarked 30-40m vessels at pier 7 outer face, running dark, 2-3hr operations

outcomes.response: Every trawler captain from here to Simrishamn knows the pier 7 area is dead. Ask Bengt Sjödin — he lost his best ground too. Ask old Ragnar's crew. But organized? No. Fishermen don't organize. We complain in the harbor bar and go back to sea. I'm the only one stupid enough to write a letter about it.
outcomes.feedback: Multiple fishermen have noticed the dead zone — Bengt Sjödin named specifically. But this isn't coordinated testimony; Petersson acted alone. The widespread knowledge among fishermen means this is common harbor knowledge, just never reported officially.
outcomes.note: Multiple fishermen know about dead zone — names Bengt Sjödin — but uncoordinated

direct.q1_response: Hard evidence? The seabed. I can take you there tomorrow. Bring a rope and drag it through the bottom 300 meters from pier 7. It'll come up grey and stinking. Then drag it anywhere else in the harbor — clean. I've done this test myself. I have twelve rope samples, dated and jarred. And I have my catch books showing the area went from productive to dead in three years.
direct.expression_hint: Reaches into a canvas bag and sets a glass jar of grey-coated rope on the desk
direct.q1_note: Brings physical evidence — jar of contaminated rope, offers to demonstrate dead zone

q2_options.text: Good evidence. Now the boats — give me times, dates, descriptions. Everything you've logged.
Has anyone tested this sludge? Do you know what's in it?
Who would be dumping near pier 7? And why hasn't the harbor authority investigated?

outcomes.response: I started keeping a log in March. Every Thursday I anchor 500 meters out and watch with binoculars. September 12th I got lucky: moonlight caught the stern of a vessel pulling away. Swedish registry. NordSjö Shipping subsidiary. Same address.
outcomes.feedback: Critical evidence: a vessel registration number linked to Västerhavet Transport AB — a NordSjö subsidiary. If the maritime registry confirms this, there's a direct connection between the unmarked Thursday vessels and Karlgren's shipping empire. The September 12th observation is the key date.
outcomes.note: Sept 12th: vessel registration traced to Västerhavet Transport AB — NordSjö subsidiary

outcomes.response: I'm a fisherman, not a chemist. I gave her a sample — off the record. She said it's 'consistent with industrial solvent waste' but wouldn't put it in writing without a formal request. She was scared. Said I shouldn't have brought it to her. I don't know what industrial solvents means exactly, but I know it's not herring.
outcomes.feedback: Informal lab analysis suggests industrial solvent waste — but not documented officially. The lab contact was frightened, which suggests awareness of what the finding implies. A formal, independent lab test would be needed to confirm.
outcomes.note: Informal Lund lab analysis: 'industrial solvent waste' — not in writing, contact was scared

outcomes.response: Who? NordSjö has exclusive after-hours access to pier 7. As for the harbor authority — I filed a complaint with Lindqvist's office in April. Written. Signed. I got a form letter back saying 'water quality is within acceptable parameters based on our most recent survey.' I asked to see the survey. They said it was 'undergoing review.' That was six months ago.
outcomes.feedback: Filed a formal complaint with harbor authority in April — got a dismissive form letter citing a survey that may not exist. The 'undergoing review' dodge for six months is suspicious. This connects NordSjö's pier 7 access to both the dead zone and the administrative cover-up.
outcomes.note: April complaint to Lindqvist dismissed — cited water survey 'undergoing review' for 6 months — may not exist

pressure.q1_response: Dock gossip? Dock gossip is 'Sven's wife left him' and 'the price of herring is criminal.' What I'm telling you is that the seabed near pier 7 is dead, I have physical evidence, and unmarked boats are running dark in a working harbor where my crew is at night. This isn't gossip. This is a safety issue and a crime.
pressure.q1_note: Defensive but passionate — frames as safety issue beyond gossip

q2_options.text: Fair enough. But why write to a newspaper instead of the environmental authority?
Other captains know about this too. Why are you the only one talking?
Running dark in a harbor is a collision risk. Have there been any incidents?

outcomes.response: I did write to the environmental authority. County of Malmöhus, Environmental Protection Office. August 1974. I have the registered mail receipt. No response. I called in September. It means they sent it to Kuststad's own town hall. The fox reviewing the henhouse.
outcomes.feedback: Environmental complaint forwarded from county back to municipal level — effectively buried. He has the registered mail receipt as proof. This shows the standard reporting channels have been neutralized, which is why he turned to the newspaper.
outcomes.note: Aug 1974 environmental complaint forwarded back to Kuststad town hall — no action, has receipt

outcomes.response: Because the others have families and boats to pay for. The good spots near the fish market. If you make trouble, you end up berthed at the far end where the tourist boats are, adding twenty minutes to every trip. It's not a threat — it's just how things work. Quietly. Petersson is the only one stupid enough to not care.
outcomes.feedback: Economic coercion through berthing assignments — harbor master controls which spots fishermen get. Making trouble means worse dock positions and lost income. Explains why other fishermen stay silent despite knowing about the dead zone. But this is Petersson's assessment, not direct evidence of retaliation.
outcomes.note: Claims Lindqvist uses berthing assignments to control fishermen — economic coercion

outcomes.response: Last March. No lights, no radio, doing maybe eight knots in the inner approach. If he hadn't heard the engine and turned hard to starboard, we'd have been cut in half. I reported it to the coast guard. Officer on duty — young kid, Engström — took my statement. I asked for a follow-up. Never came. The incident report seems to have disappeared.
outcomes.feedback: March near-collision with a dark-running vessel — reported to coast guard, statement taken by Engström. The missing incident report connects to the coast guard's pattern of institutional cover-up. Engström himself may confirm this report existed.
outcomes.note: March near-collision reported to Engström — incident report disappeared from coast guard files

silence.q1_response: ...not much of a talker? Good. Neither am I. I'd rather be on my boat. Here — look at this chart. I drew it myself. Every Thursday night since March, I've plotted the movement of the dark boats. Arrival bearing, dock time, departure bearing. Twenty-eight observations. You see the pattern?
silence.expression_hint: Unfolds a hand-drawn nautical chart covered in pencil markings
silence.q1_note: Responds to silence by going straight to evidence — hand-drawn tracking chart

q2_options.text: This chart is remarkable. What's the pattern you want me to see?
Twenty-eight observations. Same vessel each time or different ones?
You've been doing surveillance for seven months. That's more than concern — that's a mission. Why?

outcomes.response: at the bearings. Every vessel approaches from 285 degrees — northwest. They dock at pier 7's outer face for exactly two to three hours. Then they depart at 195 degrees — south-southwest. That's not back to Göteborg. That's toward Copenhagen. And on September 12th — this mark here — I got close enough to read a partial registration. It led me to a NordSjö subsidiary.
outcomes.feedback: Sophisticated surveillance: 28 Thursday observations with compass bearings showing a consistent route — Göteborg approach, pier 7 dock, then south toward Denmark/Germany. This describes a transit smuggling operation. The September 12th registration match to NordSjö is the critical evidence.
outcomes.note: 28 observations: 285° approach (Göteborg), pier 7 dock, 195° departure (Copenhagen/Germany) — transit route

outcomes.response: Hard to tell in the dark without lights. The Thursday regular is mid-size, maybe 35 meters, diesel twin-screw. There's a larger one that comes once a month — deeper engine, slower. And twice I've seen a smaller, faster boat — like a pilot cutter — that arrives an hour before the cargo vessel and leaves when it docks. A scout, maybe.
outcomes.feedback: Three distinct vessels identified by sound and silhouette: a regular weekly cargo ship, a monthly larger vessel, and a scout/pilot cutter. The scout vessel suggests organized operations with advance reconnaissance — this is more than casual smuggling.
outcomes.note: Three vessels: weekly 35m cargo, monthly larger ship, plus scout cutter that arrives first

outcomes.response: My brother fished pier 7 waters his whole life. Started getting headaches, skin rashes. His wife said his fingernails turned grey. The doctor in town said it was 'occupational exposure.' My brother died in February. The death certificate says heart failure. He was forty-one years old and strong as an ox. Whatever's in that water killed him, and I intend to prove it.
outcomes.feedback: Personal tragedy driving the investigation — brother died at 41 after fishing contaminated pier 7 waters. Grey fingernails and skin rashes suggest heavy metal or chemical poisoning. Death certificate says heart failure. This transforms the dead zone from environmental concern to potential manslaughter.
outcomes.note: Brother died Feb at 41 after fishing pier 7 — grey nails, rashes, 'heart failure' — possible poisoning
